HERSHEY, Pa. â€” Republican John Kasich kicked off the presidential primary
season in Pennsylvania with a town hall meeting here Friday morning.The Ohio
governor, who later in the day spoke at the Pennsylvania Leadership Conference
in Harrisburg, is the first candidate from either party to visit the area in
advance of the April 26 primary election. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz spoke at the
Harrisburg conference later Friday.Kasich, a Pennsylvania native, was greeted
by about 600 people at the Antique Automobile Club of America Museum,
according to a museum official.After telling some stories about growing up in
the coal town of McKees Rock near Pittsburgh, Kasichâ€™s tone grew more serious
as he spoke about a number of the nationâ€™s challenges and hit common
Republican themes, such as lower taxes and less government regulation to
stimulate small businesses and job growth.Speaking about the threat of
terrorism abroad, Kasich said defeating Islamic State, also known as ISIL or
ISIS, would require the U.S. to build a coalition of Islamic Arab nations with
European cooperation."We need to have them in the coalition, because we don't
want just us going to destroy ISIS," he said. "And we need to go in the air
and on the ground and we need to destroy ISIS. That would be the biggest blow
that we could do to these crazy people, these murderers."One of the few times
Kasich referred to his Republican opponents, Cruz and businessmanÂ Donald
Trump, was in regard to the treatment of Muslims in this country. Contrary to
Trump, who has called for banning the entry of Muslim refugees, except if they
are wealthy, and Cruz, who has advocated for patrolling Muslim neighborhoods,
Kasich said he favors an inclusive approach."If you want to find out what is
happening in the Muslim community and who is being radicalized, who do you
think you ask? Do you ask you?" he said pointing to the crowd. "Or do you ask
someone who lives in the Muslim community."Ohio Governor and Republican
Presidential candidate John Kasich speaks at a town hall event at the Antique
Automobile Club of America Museum in Hershey on Friday, April 1, 2016. Kasich
said is the only Republican capable of beating Democratic front runner Hillary
Clinton,Â (Photo: Jeremy Long, Lebanon Daily News)Kasich trails both Trump and
Cruz in the delegate count and faces an uphill climb to win the GOP
nomination, but he confidently predicted that none of the three remaining
Republican candidates will have the required 1,273 delegates to win the
nomination, which would lead to a brokered convention in Cleveland this
summer."It's going to be really, really, really cool," he said.Kasich drew
some of his loudest applause when he said he is the only Republican capable of
beating Democratic front-runner, Hillary Clinton, a statement supported by
several recent polls."I'm the only one who consistently beats Hillary Clinton
because I can get crossover votes," he said.Kasich also said he would be able
to unify a divided Congress and fractured nation."We can fix these problems,
but there is one thing that we have to remember. We may be Republicans and we
may be Democrats, but when I grew up, and even now in my lifetime, we are
Americans before anything else," he said.Kasich was introduced by Rep. Charlie
Dent, whose district includes Hershey and parts of Lebanon County. Dent, who
endorsed Kasich about a month ago and helped arrange the event, called him â€œa
common sense conservative.â€â€œI think that we are going to find that John Kasich
is our favorite son,â€ Dent said. â€œHe will be the first president from
Pennsylvania since James Buchanan. Except, unlike Buchanan, heâ€™ll really be a
good president.â€Nick Aragon of Palmyra, who came to the town hall with his
wife, Elisabeth, and their 3-month old son, Alexander, said he was pleased
with Kasich's performance.â€œI think the town hall style really fits him well
because he is folksy and he likes connecting with the people. I think this was
a great opportunity to showcase that,â€ Aragon said.Some who came to the town
hall said they see Kasich as a better alternative to Trump and Cruz.â€œHeâ€™s not
Donald Trump, Ted Cruz or Hillary Clinton,â€ said Andy Ruggiero of Hummelstown,
who initially supported former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum and then
Florida Sen. Marco Rubio before settling for Kasich.Elliott Weinstein, a
Realtor from York County, said he is in Kasich's camp for the same reason.â€œWe
have to stop the insanity,â€ Weinstein said. â€œI might not agree with everything
he says, but at least he is normal.â€
title: Kasich campaigns in native Pennsylvania

HENDERSONVILLE, Tenn. â€” Itâ€™s been 10 years since the sky opened up, swooped
down in a swirl of fury and nearly ended Amy Hawkinsâ€™ vibrant life.And yet,
even from the confines of a wheelchair she hopes one day to leave behind, the
Hendersonville mother who shielded her sons from a tornado on April 7, 2006,
still has no regrets.She also doesnâ€™t spend a lot of time feeling sorry for
herself.â€œIâ€™ve never asked why,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m here. I saved the boys. If it
meant that I died then so be it.â€Why she is paralyzed from the waist down â€” a
maze of rods winding through her back â€” matters less than having an earlier,
more important prayer answered.â€œFor three generations in my family, a parent
has died,â€ said Hawkins who lost a stepfather who helped raise her just before
her 12th birthday.â€œSo I asked God while I was young to never take me away from
my kids. He didnâ€™t take me away, so thatâ€™s why I donâ€™t ask why.â€**â€˜I KNOW ITâ€™S
HERE. GOTTA GOâ€™**At first, Hawkins had little memory of that day. Through the
years, the events have come back to her in a patchwork of recollections,
stories told to her by others and even dreams of that day.She had picked up 6
-year-old son Jair from kindergarten and taken him and his brother Cole, 3, to
get pizza. Her husband Jerrod, a firefighter in Brentwood, called to let her
know that strong storms were headed her way.Once home, she heeded the warnings
on television and headed to the basement.â€œI know itâ€™s here. Gotta go,â€ she
told Jerrod before dropping the phone. He didnâ€™t hear anything from anyone for
45 minutes.Hawkins says she remembers lying on top of the boys reciting the
Lordâ€™s Prayer.â€œThrough dreams I remember the last brick that hit me,â€ she
says.Jair and Cole, now 16 and 13, have their own bare memories.â€œI remember my
mom opened up the doorâ€¦ and seeing a cloud coming at us,â€ said Cole who closed
his eyes and woke up to â€œbricks everywhere.â€While a neighbor rushed the boys
to nearby Hendersonville Medical Center, Hawkinsâ€™ twisted and crumpled body
required more care.Sumner County sheriffâ€™s Deputy Tim Sebring was the first
responder on the scene.â€œThe whole house, it was just gone,â€ recalls Sebring.
â€œI noticed a female all mauled up underneath some bricks.â€Sebring said Hawkins
was making noises and trying to move, but he knew how important it was for her
to stay put until EMS arrived.â€œI just grabbed her neck and held her there,â€ he
said. â€œI just kept talking to her and praying over her. It seemed forever
until EMS got there.â€Hawkins was treated first at Vanderbilt University
Medical Center and then the Shepherd Center in Atlanta, a rehabilitation
center for those with brain and spinal cord injuries.**A NEW HOME**Her story
of heroism and survival made international news after parents on her sonâ€™s
baseball team started a petition for the television show _Extreme Makeover:
Home Edition_ to replace the familyâ€™s destroyed home.In four days in August of
that year, more than 2,000 community volunteers helped build the new home in
Hendersonville. The show aired nationally and in Europe. Hawkins says the
showâ€™s producers told her their episode was â€œEuropeâ€™s favorite.â€ Interviews
for publications in England and Germany followed.For the one-year anniversary
of the devastating twister, the family appeared on the _Oprah Winfrey Show
_where the young mother was again hailed as a hero.Amy Hawkins makes herself
coffee in her home that was built by Extreme Makeover TV show which built it
to accommodate her wheelchair. Hawkins was paralyzed trying to save her two
sons following a 2006 Sumner County tornado, The family was featured on
Extreme Makeover and will soon be moving out of the home .Â (Photo: Shelley
Mays / The Tennessean)Her story continues to inspire.In December 2014, Hawkins
underwent spinal surgery on the television show _The Doctors _to relieve
unrelenting back pain that required fog-inducing medications.Now 44, Hawkins
says the surgery, in which the surgeon inserted â€œtitanium rods that look like
train tracks back there,â€ has taken away about 90% of her back pain.It has
also, she believes, brought her closer to walking again. Over the years she
has gained more feeling in her legs and feet, she says, and is cautiously
optimistic that sheâ€™ll one day be able to leave her wheelchair behind.For the
moment though, the family has undergone another milestone recently by moving
out of the house a community helped build for them.**MOVING ON**The family
recently purchased a 31-acre farm in Portland and plans to first move into an
apartment and then build a home.Amy admits she has mixed feelings about
leaving the home, but is glad to pass it on to another family with young
kids.Ten years after saving her sons, Jair,left, and Cole from a tornado that
destroyed their Hendersonville home, Amy Hawkins and her family reflect on the
day that changed their lives. Hawkins was paralyzed trying to save her two
sons following a 2006 Sumner County tornado, The family was featured on
Extreme Makeover and will soon be moving out of the home . Ten years after
saving her sons from a tornado that destroyed their Hendersonville home, Amy
Hawkins and her family reflect on the day that changed their lives. Hawkins
was paralyzed trying to save her two sons following a 2006 Sumner County
tornado, The family was featured on Extreme Makeover and will soon be moving
out of the home . Â (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean)â€œIâ€™m excited about
moving but a little sad about leaving the history thatâ€™s here,â€ she said.Jair
is currently a volunteer firefighter who plans to follow in his fatherâ€™s
footsteps by becoming a full-time firefighter/paramedic.â€œWe have some good
memories in this house but I feel like weâ€™ll have good memories out there
too,â€ he said.Both sons, once afraid of storms, say they are now fascinated by
them. Jair said he even thought of becoming a storm chaser at one time.Amy
says she no longer needs to assure them like she used to after that dark day.
But still, she wouldnâ€™t do anything differently.â€œIâ€™ve always told them, â€˜I
saved you once,â€™ â€ she says. â€œIf Iâ€™ve got to do it again, Iâ€™ll fall out of my
wheelchair and do it again.â€
title: Mom paralyzed saving sons says sheâ€™d â€˜do it againâ€™

You know the frustration of a computer that keeps getting slower and slower
every year? There are ways you can keep the speed up on an old computer \- but
eventually, the hardware is going to get too outdated to run the latest
software you need.In the past, that's the point where you'd just go buy a new
computer; I've talked before about how to know you've reached that point.
However, it's now become easier to give your old computer a second lease on
life, or it into a usable computer for a friend or relative. All you need is
one simple thing.I'm talking about the operating system. And, I don't just
mean that you should upgrade to Windows 10. While Windows 10 does run a lot
better than past versions of Windows on low-powered hardware, it doesn't play
nicely with your old hardware. To avoid this problem, you'll need to update to
an operating system that isn't Windows.Many people like using Linux for this
purpose. Linux is a free, secure operating system that comes in a lot of
versions, from full Windows replacements to tiny versions that can run a $35
Raspberry Pi computer. Linux Mint running the MATE desktop and elementary OS
are two consumer-friendly options you can check out that work well on older
hardware.While these are powerful Windows replacements, there is a simpler
option. Over the last few years, you've probably heard about Chromebooks.
These are sub-$250 laptops that run Google's Chrome OS, which is an operating
system version of Google's popular Chrome browser.An operating system like
this has a number of advantages, such as running very well on low-powered
hardware. It has the same strong security as Chrome, and gets regular updates
with performance and security fixes.In addition, Chrome OS works a lot like
Windows with a start button, taskbar and apps, so you can pick it up quickly.
Most of the time, it's as easy to use as a standard Web browser. Plus, it can
do many of the same things other operating systems can do, like video chat,
play music, print documents andÂ play games.The Chrome OS programs are actually
Web apps it runs from the cloud, and many of them are free. This also means
that it stores your files online so you can access them anywhere on any
gadget. If one of your Chrome OS computers crashes, you can log in on any
other Chrome OS gadget and have your entire computer ready to go just the way
you want it.In the past, to get Chrome OS you'd need to shell out a few
hundred dollars for a Chromebook or a Chrome OS-based desktop. That isn't the
case anymore.A company called Neverware has an operating system called
CloudReady, which is a version of Chrome OS that works on a wide range of
laptops and desktops, including Apple hardware. The best part for you is that
it's free for home use (there's also a paid educational version that's great
for school environments).Installing a new operating system on a computer is
always a little tricky, but Neverware has extensive step-by-step directions on
its site. It has also tested CloudReady on each of its "certified hardware
models" so it knows what features do and don't work correctly.You can check
the list of certified hardware models to see if your laptop or desktop
qualifies and how well CloudReady will work. Even if your model isn't on the
list, you can install the OSÂ anyway and see what happens. Many people have
found it works just fine.In general,Â CloudReady runs on laptops and desktops
made in 2007 or newer, and Netbooks from 2009 and on. It needs at least 1GB of
RAM to run smoothly, but because it relies a lot on cloud storage and Web
apps, it only needs 8GB of storage space.On some computers, you can dual-boot
CloudReady and Windows if you don't want to give up Windows entirely. As
always, be sure your information is backed up in case something goes wrong
during the installation.If you're installing CloudReady on your main computer,
you can back up your files by moving them to Google Drive. You can also move
your photos to Google Photos and upload your music to Google Music. By doing
this, they'll all be there when you install and sign in to CloudReady.
CloudReady also supports other cloud services like Dropbox if you'd prefer to
use a non-Google product.Of course, some people want to stick with Windows. If
that's the case for you personally, then it's probably time to start looking
for a new computer. The process can feel daunting, but it won't be if as long
as you know what to look for. Or, you might decide you don't need a computer
at all. These days, there are also plenty of tablets that make excellent
alternatives._On theÂ Kim Komando Show, the nation's largest weekend radio talk
show, Kim takes calls and dispenses advice on today's digital lifestyle, from
smartphones and tablets to online privacy and data hacks. For her daily tips,
free newsletters and more, visit her website atÂ Komando.com. Email her at
techcomments@usatoday.com._
title: One free step to make an aging computer run like new

PALM SPRINGS, Calif.Â â€”Â A frail-but-feisty great-grandmother with a long white
ponytail was evicted from her apartment Friday, in part for being too
loud.Evelyn Heller of Palm Desert, Calif.,Â was orderedÂ to pay $616 in prorated
rent and more than $800 in court and lawyer's fees.â€œIâ€™m 100 years old!â€ Heller
shouted at the judgeÂ before turning her attention to a lawyer on the other
side of the courtroom. â€œAnd I donâ€™t understand what they are talking
about.â€Despite reluctance voiced by both the judge and the plaintiffâ€™s lawyer,
Heller was ordered out of her home after a brief trial.Â She now has about two
weeks to leave her apartment and said she does not know where she will go.â€œI
have four grandsons, but I donâ€™t want to be dependent on them,â€ Heller told
the judge. â€œI canâ€™t be a burden to my family. They donâ€™t have room for me.
That happens in life.â€Officials for Hellerâ€™s landlord, Deep Canyon Desert LLC,
said they wanted her evicted because her apartment was kept in â€œdeplorable
conditionsâ€ and that Heller often had loud, disruptive arguments with her
daughter. The company had threatened to evict her twice beforeÂ but nothing
improved, so representatives followed through this time.The apartment complex
manager, Melody Morrison, told the judge thatÂ Heller kept the apartment in
"deplorable conditions." AÂ _Desert Sun_Â reporter who visited the apartment
Friday afternoon found the carpet dirty and the living room cluttered with
boxes and stacks of magazinesÂ but far fromÂ the point of hoarding.After court,
MorrisonÂ declined to commentÂ then walked briskly away from a reporter to avoid
questions. The companyâ€™s lawyer, eviction specialist William Windham, said his
client did not want to evict HellerÂ but felt it was a reality of the
business.Windham said he felt conflicted, too.â€œIâ€™ve evicted people off of
their death beds and regretted every second of the trial,â€ Windham said. â€œBut
my job is unfortunately to set my feeling aside and do what my clients ask me
to do.â€œIt would be same if this was a lady who was 30 years old and had five
childrenÂ or a little old man with cancer,â€ he said. â€œIf you have a commotion
being caused on the property, and the people wonâ€™t stop, you have no choice
but to take action.â€In this case, that action came in the form of an â€œunlawful
detainer,â€ which is a mundane court filing in which a landlord asks a judge to
force a tenant from a property. Cases like these are rarely worthy of media
attention, but the trial Friday was a strange one.Heller defended herself
despite the fact that she could barely see or hear. After she took an oath to
tell the truth, she kept her hand raised and did a brief hula danceÂ then
laughed under her breath.Her eyesight was too poor to read court documents
until someone volunteered a pair of eye glasses from the courtroom
audience.And finally, when it came time for arguments, Heller refused to stay
at the defendantâ€™s tableÂ and instead hovered on the edge of the judgeâ€™s bench,
unwilling to sit. For most defendants, this would result in a firm response
from the bailiffs â€” including possible arrest â€” but as Heller pleaded with the
judge, barely out of armâ€™s reach, deputies stood back and watched, uncertain
how to react.This leniency appeared to be a sign of sympathy, but in the end
it didnâ€™t matter. Riverside County Judge Charles Haines ruled against Heller
without any deliberation.He issued his judgment in a low, hushed tone that she
couldnâ€™t hear.Outside the courtroom, a deputy had to explain to her that she
had lost.â€œWhat? What kind of ridiculous thing is that?â€ she snapped, as the
reality of the ruling set in. â€œBut I donâ€™t have any money.â€_Follow Brett
Kelman on Twitter: @TDSbrettkelman_
title: 100-year-old woman booted from her Calif. home

LAS CRUCES, N.M.Â â€” A plumber trying to fix a sink in a customer's home is in
critical condition FridayÂ after being shot in the stomach, and the man accused
of pulling the trigger was arrested in his apartmentÂ after a two-hour
standoff.The 54-year-old victim, whose name was not released, managed to
escape shortly before 6 p.m. MT Thursday and called 911 while attempting to
drive away in his Roto-Rooter van, police said. Emergency responders found him
a couple of blocks away and tended to his injuries before transporting him to
University Medical Center in El Paso.At the apartment, officers attempted to
make contact with tenantÂ John T. Haynie, 69, who was inside and believed to be
armed. A hostage negotiator saidÂ that Haynie appeared to be intoxicated,
according to court documents made available Friday.Shortly after 8 p.m., he
was removed from his apartment and taken toÂ the Las Cruces Police Department
for questioning. Haynie told officers that he â€œblacked outâ€ and could not
remember what happened but also told them he had had only had two beers,
police said.Inside the apartment, officers found a 0.22-caliber revolver and
blood.Â HaynieÂ wasÂ booked into DoÃ±a Ana County Detention Center on a charge of
first-degree attempted murder, whichÂ carries a maximum sentence of up to nine
years in prison and up to $10,000 in fines.Before 11 a.m. Friday, the victim
alreadyÂ had undergoneÂ surgery, according to his daughter.â€œHeâ€™s had surgery and
there was organ damage, but heâ€™s doing fine,â€ Kendrah Vallee said. â€œThe family
is with him currently, and we are asking for privacy.â€Vallee said her father
would be hospitalized for at least 48 hours. She said she and other family
members were stunned by the shooting.â€œAnybody that has said anything has
immediately said, 'Heâ€™s the nicest man in the world. Why would anyone shoot
him?' Heâ€™s the gentlest man youâ€™ll ever meet. Heâ€™d do anything for anyone,â€
she said. â€œSo we are actually 100% baffled right now about why this happened
to him.â€Vallee said her father has worked for Roto-Rooter for about six years
and has lived locallyÂ for more than 20 years.Investigators have not released a
motive.Haynie initially was held without bond, but in a Friday hearing, a
judge set it at $75,000.Â As of Friday night, he had been released, according
to jail records._Follow Carlos Andres LÃ³pez on Twitter:Â @carlopez_losÂ _Las
Cruces, N.M., SWAT team members carry shooting suspect John T. Haynie, who was
unable to walk on his own, March 31, 2016, after he barricaded himself his
apartment in Las Cruces, N.M. He is accused of shooting a plumber who was
working on his sink.Â (Photo: Robin Zielinski, Las Cruces (N.M.) Sun-News)

SHEBOYGAN, Wis. â€” Democratic hopeful Bernie Sanders came out swinging at rival
Hillary Clinton and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker on Friday in a wide-ranging
speech in Sheboygan, where he urged his supporters to push a "political
revolution" beyond the presidential campaign.The independent Vermont Senator,
who spoke for about an hour to a crowd of 2,000 at a Sheboygan high school,
drew a clear dividing line between himself and Clinton, the former secretary
of state who leads the delegate count in the Democratic contest.Sanders
referenced a video posted Thursday in which Clinton argued she was "sick" of
his campaign for "lying" about her ties to the fossil fuel industry, saying
she hasn't taken money from the industry during her campaign.Sanders countered
that records cited by Greenpeace showed she'd received $4.5 million in
contributions â€” either through her campaign or her SuperPAC â€” from lobbyists
for the fossil-fuel industry."These are not just workers, these are paid,
registered lobbyists," Sanders said. "Secretary Clinton, you owe our campaign
an apology. We were telling the truth.â€A statement from Clinton's
communications director released after the speech made it clear that she would
do no such thing."It's disappointing that they've doubled down on negative
character attacks that deliberately mislead voters rather than debate the
issues," the statement read. "Their latest attack over campaign contributions
ignores their own donations from individuals who work for oil and gas
companies, and most importantly it ignores Hillary Clinton's record and
agenda."Later FridayÂ Sanders spoke in Green Bay, attributing his campaignâ€™s
momentum to the broad coalition behind him. He told about 2,000 people at the
Kress Events Center on the UW-Green Bay campus thatÂ if they stay energetic and
engaged, he can defeat Clinton in the Wisconsin primary Tuesday and continue
battling for the Democratic presidential nomination.Democratic presidential
candidate Bernie Sanders waves to the crowd before speaking during his
campaign stop Friday at the Kress Events Center at UWGB.Â (Photo: Evan
Siegle/USA TODAY NETWORK-Wisconsin)â€œWith your help, weâ€™re going to win
Wisconsin,â€ Sanders said. â€œWe cannot go forward as a nation unless we have the
courage to put the real issues out there on the table, dissect them, solve
them and go forward.â€Before he took the stage, Sanders said, he met with
leaders of several local Native American tribes and pledged to reset the
nationâ€™s relationship with tribes. He noted unemployment and poverty are very
high among Native Americans and access to health care and education is
poor.â€œBefore we became a nation, when the first settlers came here, the Native
American community was lied to, was cheated and treaties that were negotiated
were abrogated,â€ Sanders said. â€œThe truth is the relationship of the United
States government to the native people of this country is nothing less than
shameful. â€¦ All I can say is if elected president of the United States, our
government will establish a new relationship with the Native American
communities.â€in Sheboygan,Â Sanders continued to hammer Clinton's record on
foreign policy, pointing to her vote to authorize the war in Iraq as one of
the largest blunders in American foreign policy. In contrast to some other
points Sanders made throughout his speech, this comment received only
scattered applause.Sanders also took specific aim at Walker, the Republican
governor, for what he said was not properly funding education, pushing anti-
union legislation and promoting voter ID requirements in the state. The April
primary vote will be one of the biggest tests of voter ID on a statewide level
since it was fully implemented.â€œI say to Scott Walker and other governors
around the country: If you are afraid of free and fair open elections, get out
of politics,â€ Sanders said.Sanders arrived to the cheers of supporters and one
person who shouted out that they loved the Vermont Senator, to which he
responded: "You know what, I love you, too.â€â€œIt is time to not only elect a
new president but to transform our country,â€ Sanders said after taking the
stage.Sanders spent a good deal of his speech emphasizing the need to
eliminate income inequality in the United States, saying ordinary Americans
are being undermined by a "rigged economy" that abandons the middle class. He
has advocated a $15 minimum wage as part of that plan.He also spent time
blasting the Supreme Court's Citizens United decision, which struck down
campaign spending limits on corporations, saying it's opened the door to
"billionaires buying elections."Later, he outlined his plan to offer free
college tuition at public universities,.He proposed funding that plan by
implementing a tax on financial transactions that he said would target "Wall
Street speculation."But the one line that got some of the loudest applause of
the afternoon was an attack on Republicans regarding their stance on gay
marriage."When they talk about family values they are talking about making it
impossible for our gay brothers and sisters to get married. I disagree,â€
Sanders said.Sanders closed the event by saying that income inequality, health
care, tuition and other issues that he's made central to his campaign are the
defining challenges of our time."I believe that today we are in a pivotal
moment in American history," he said. "These are the issues that people are
now thinking about, and what people are saying is, 'enough is
enough.'"Supporters began lining up as early as 8 a.m. for a chance to hear
Sanders speak.JoAnn Masche-Daane, of Beaver Dam, was second in line. She said
she'd been apathetic about politics before Sanders got her attention with his
honesty about the issues facing this country."He really woke me up ... when he
started talking about stuff and about what's really going on in this country,"
she said.Hazel Dulmes, a Sheboygan native and freshman at UW-Madison, said
she's supporting Sanders over Clinton because she views Sanders as more
trustworthy. She also favors his proposals to provide free public college
tuition and to legalize marijuana."I think he's been consistent throughout his
political career," she said.The independent Vermont Senator is the first
presidential candidate on either side to visit Sheboygan in advance of
Wisconsinâ€™s April 5 primary and is looking for supporters to help deliver a
big win, with 86 delegates at stake._Contributing: Jeff Bollier, Shelby Le Duc
and Patti Zarling, Green Bay (Wis.) Press-Gazette; Phillip Bock, Sheboygan
Press; The Associated Press_
title: Sanders to Clinton: You owe us an apology

Belgian authoritiesÂ have banned a far-right European youthÂ group from mounting
an anti-IslamÂ demonstration Saturday in Brussels'Â predominantlyÂ Muslim
neighborhood of Molenbeek, but community leaders fear police are unprepared to
keep them out.The youth group Generation Identitaire announced its "Expel the
Islamists!" demonstration on its website, callingÂ MoleenbeekÂ "a real Islamist
breeding ground."Generation Identitaire urgedÂ "European youth" to gather in
Molenbeek's town square Saturday 3 p.m. "with a clear and simple message:
'Islamists out of Europe!'"The new French political movement Generation
Identitaire has called for a an "anti-Islamists" demonstration for April 2,
2016, in the predominantly Muslim community of Molenbeek in Brussels.Â (Photo:
Generation Identitaire)LastÂ week. hundreds of black-clad youth shouting Nazi
slogans disrupted a memorial at Brussels' Borse Square that had been called on
behalf ofÂ 32 people killed in the March 22 terrorist attacks at Brussels
airport and subway system.The protesters, whoÂ were driven out by police using
water cannon,Â helped prompt authorities to ban Saturday's demonstration in
Molenbeek.There was no sign the group would heed the ban.Molenbeek mayor
Francoise Schepmans tells the AFP news agency that the decision to ban the
demonstratiionÂ came after talks with police and other district mayors."If we
had let it happen, there could have been clashes," Schepmans says.Molenbeek
was thrustÂ into the headlines in November following the terrorist attacks in
Paris that killed 130 people. Several of the terrorists had ties to the
Brussels community, including Salah Abdeslam, who was captured four months
later in Molenbeek, where he grew up.Abdeslam's brother, Ibrahim, who blew
himself up in the Paris attacks, also grew up in Molenbeek, as did at least
two of the terrorists in the Brussels attacks.Abdeslam even returned to
Molenbeek the night of the Paris attacks after heÂ scrapped his suicide vest
and fled the city.In the neighborhoodÂ itself, community leaders haveÂ expressed
fear that its predominantly Muslim young people will fight back if the
protesters attempt to mount their demonstration despite the ban.â€œThey donâ€™t
trust the police and they arenâ€™t going to take it,â€ said Fouad Ben Abdelkader,
a teacher in the neighborhood, the Associated Press reported.Â On Thursday he
joined a meeting of a couple dozen community leaders and mentors to
neighborhood youths who feel adrift in mainstream Belgian society.At the
meeting, Molenbeekâ€™s youth organizers planned for the worst, expressing doubt
thatÂ police are prepared for a confrontation and worried that the authorities
areÂ unwilling to listen to their concerns.â€œThere are some messages that are
clearly calling for violence against Muslims,"Â said Sarah Turine, a Molenbeek
councilwoman who called the meeting in hopes of heading off problems. "And
there have been repercussions on social networks among young people, families,
saying we have to get mobilized to defend our little brothers, our sisters,
our mothers. Seeing that last weekend the police didnâ€™t do their job and
didnâ€™t succeed in avoiding clashes, that creates mistrust.â€Brussels is still
reeling from last week'sÂ attacks. The Brussels airport, where two bombs caused
major structural damage in addition to the killings, was set to reopen at only
20 per cent capacity Friday, but even that was postponedÂ because of a strike
by airport policy over security concerns, the BBC reports.
title: Clashes feared at banned anti-Islamist rally in Brussels

The U.S. Soccer Federation has a tough task ahead if the Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission investigates the wage discrimination claims made by
five star players on U.S. women's national soccer team, former EEOC chief Ida
Castro told USA TODAY Sports on Friday.â€œThey are talking about performing
substantially equal work,â€ said Castro, who chaired the EEOC under Presidents
Bill Clinton and George W. Bush. â€œThey are both soccer teams, right? There is
no significant difference between the soccer games that I can see. If they
have met all that and can show their male counterparts do not have
substantially additional duties --- which based on what Iâ€™ve seen they donâ€™t
have -- it will be difficult for the employer to justify the differential in
pay.â€Carli Lloyd, Megan Rapinoe, Rebecca Sauerbrunn, Hope Solo and Alex Morgan
filed the complaint with the EEOC on behalf of the entire team on Thursday
that alleged that players on the womenâ€™s national team make about half of what
their male counterparts earn. Unless itâ€™s dismissed for procedural reasons,
the EEOC can take up to 10Â months to investigate a claim.â€œI believe they have
a claim that is certainly worth looking and (the EEOC) should beÂ looking at it
seriously.,â€ Castro said. â€œAs an American, Iâ€™m extremely proud of this womenâ€™s
team. In sports, women have traditionally been behind the 8-ball, so to speak.
Itâ€™s about time that we look at women in sports and we begin to treat them
with the same value and equity that they merit.â€Castro, currently the chief
diversity officer and a vice president at Pennsylvaniaâ€™s Commonwealth Medical
College, said she feels there's plenty to trigger an investigation.â€œWhat the
plaintiffs need to prove in an equal pay case is that something that they
appear to have already done: There are males and females working in
substantially equal jobs with the same employer yet they are receiving
different compensation," she said.Â "From what hasÂ been reported, it seems like
the reached that prima facie threshold.â€Once the investigation --- if one is
launched by the agency --- is complete and the EEOC finds that U.S. Soccer
violated federal law, the agency will attempt to reach a voluntary settlement
with the federation. If a settlement can't be reached, the agency or, in some
instances, theÂ Department of Justice,Â would determine whether to file a
lawsuit.If either the EEOC doesn't find U.S. SoccerÂ broke any laws, the
players could bring a civil suit. The players would have to take the same
route if a settlement is not reached if a violation is uncovered and there's
no settlement orÂ legal action taken by the government.Along with noting that
the womenâ€™s team --- which has won three World Cup titles and four Olympic
gold medals --- is more successful on the field, the EEOC complaint also lists
U.S. Soccerâ€™s own projections that the womenâ€™s squad will be more profitable
in 2016 and 2017 than the men.â€œNormally, that couldâ€™ve been perhaps, an
affirmative defense,â€ Castro said of a potential argument that the menâ€™s team
pulls in more revenue to justify a higher pay structure.The EEOC filing
follows a February lawsuit brought by U.S. Soccer that soughtÂ to confirm the
validity of the collective bargaining agreement between the womenâ€™s players
and the federation. U.S. Soccer claims the CBA runs through the end of this
year, while the women claim the CBA has expired.

APPLETON, Wis.Â â€”Â Former President Bill Clinton, making a campaign stop here on
behalf of his wife took a swipe at GOP front-runner Donald Trump for wanting
to build a wall on the countryâ€™s southern border.â€œWe can do this, but we canâ€™t
do this until we tear down barriers,â€ he told a crowd of 650 at Lawrence
University downtown. â€œBuilding a wall is a bad idea.â€The remark brought the
biggest cheer from the crowd during Clintonâ€™s 50-minute stump speech for
Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton.A recent Marquette
University poll showed Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton in a statistical tie
in Tuesday's Democratic primary.Among likely voters, Sanders led with 49% to
Clinton's 45%Â with 6% undecided. The difference between the candidates falls
within the poll's error margin ofÂ Â±6.3 percentageÂ points.Hillary Clinton has
been campaigning in Milwaukee and Green Bay ahead of Tuesday's Wisconsin
primary. She will be making stops Saturday in Madison and Eau Claire.Bill
Clinton also hit Wisconsin's governor, Scott Walker, during his speech for
making cuts to the University of Wisconsin System budget and for requiring
identification for voters.His talkÂ to the crowd of mostly students was policy
heavy, touching on HillaryÂ Clinton's ideas to reform Wall Street, lower the
cost of collegeÂ and diversify the country's energy usage, which he said would
bring jobs by creating new wind and solar energy infrastructure.Bill Clinton
also mentioned his wife'sÂ early work before politics, where she went
undercover for a civil-rights advocateÂ to investigate segregation in Alabama
schools in the 1970s."That was gutsy for 40 years ago," he said.Clinton spoke
highly of his wife, saying she is the only candidate with good ideas and
relevant experience."Experience is a dry, old term that old people like and
young people don't," he joked to the crowd of mostly students.Minnesota Sen.
Al Franken, who introduced Bill Clinton at the campus event,Â said he was not
concerned about poll numbers showing HillaryÂ Clinton behind with young people
in Wisconsin.The Marquette Law School Poll showed Sanders with 83% of the
support from Democrats ages 18 to 29 in Wisconsin."As a senator, Iâ€™m really
interesting in getting things done," Franken said. "Iâ€™m not going to break
down poll demographics.â€Ahead of Bill Clinton's talk, state Rep. Amanda Stuck,
an Appleton Democrat, spoke of her first time seeing the former president when
he campaigned in the 1990s in Wisconsin.Â She talked about visiting a fourth-
grade classroom for the first time as legislator earlier this year and getting
this question from a female student: â€œCan girls be president?â€â€œCome November,
I hope no little fourth-grade girl has to ask me that question," she said.The
Warch Campus Center, overlooking the Fox River, filled up quickly with
supporters after the doors opened at 9:30 a.m. CTThe former president made a
surprise stop at Copper Rock Coffee in downtown Appleton before heading to the
university, chatting with patrons. He told the Lawrence University crowd that
he likes to seek out small coffee shops wherever he goes to talk casually with
people about issues.Hillary 2016 volunteers had been handing out coffee they
got from the campus center cafe to people waiting in line this morning.Those
at the front, like 58-year-old Suzi Perlewitz â€” one of a few baby boomers
queued up â€” said she began standing in line at about 6:30 a.m. Perlewitz saw
Hillary Clinton at her Green Bay campaign stop earlier in the week, and
proudly displayed her "selfie" with the candidate.But Friday was about Hillary
Clinton's husband."I got to vote for him twice," she said, noting she was one
of the few in line to do so.She was right. Based on those in line, Bill
Clinton would be speaking to a mostly young crowd.Lawrence University students
Abbi North, Natalie Ortega-Wells and Becca Tapia got in line about 7:30.They
said their professors had encouraged students to come to the event. By Friday,
aÂ majority of students had been to one campaign event or another, North
said.On Tuesday, Democratic challenger Bernie Sanders had a rally at the Fox
Cities Performing Arts Center, and Republican Donald Trump was across the
street Wednesday at the Radisson Paper Valley Hotel."A lot of people have gone
to Sanders," North said. "But this is on our campus."_FollowÂ Katherine Lymn
and Madeleine Behr on Twitter:Â @kathlymnÂ andÂ @madeleinebehr_

The Pentagon reported Friday thatÂ 265 active-duty service members killed
themselves last year, continuing a trend of unusually high suicide rates that
haveÂ plagued the U.S. military for at least sevenÂ years.The numbers of
suicides among troops was 145Â in 2001 and began a steady increase until more
than doubling to 321 in 2012, theÂ worst year in recent history for service
members killing themselves.The suicide rate for the Army that year was nearly
30 suicides per 100,000 soldiers, well above the national rate of 12.5 per
100,000 for 2012.Military suicidesÂ dropped 20% the year after that, andÂ then
held roughlyÂ steady at numbers significantly higher than during the early
2000s.Â The 265 suicides last year compares with 273 in 2014 and 254 in 2013.
By contrast, from 2001 through 2007, suicides never exceeded 197."Suicide
prevention remains a top priority, and the Department will continue its
efforts to reduce deaths by suicide among its service members," said Â Marine
Lt. Col. Hermes Gabrielle, a Pentagon spokeswoman. "Reducing suicide risk
entails creating a climate that encourages servicemembers to seek help,
reducing access to lethal meansÂ and broadening communication and awareness to
Service members and their families."Among efforts by the military to combat
suicide was a $5 million, long-term study by the Army that eventually produced
algorithms for predicting what group of soldiers isÂ most likely to commit
suicide. The Department of Veterans Affairs has embraced the science and will
soon launch a pilot program for helping its therapists concentrate efforts on
those veterans with strong self-destructive tendencies.Â .The increase in
suicide in the military was driven largely by the Army, where suicidesÂ rose
sharply from 45 in 2001 to 165 in 2012. The Army reported 120Â suicides last
year, the same as in 2013 and down from 124 in 2014.Data released Friday also
show that suicides among reserve troops â€”Â reservists in the Army, Navy, Air
Force and Marine Corps and the National Guard â€”Â wereÂ 210 last year. That is an
increase fromÂ 170 suicides in 2014Â but down from 220 suicides in 2013.U.S.
troops have been at war since 2001 in Afghanistan, and fought in the Iraq war
from 2003 to 2011.

NAIROBI, Kenya â€” Annita Musyoka, a student who survived the Garissa University
attack by militants a year ago, still hears the sound of gunshots ringing in
her ears.Although she now studies far from her former school in eastern Kenya,
the massacre still haunts her."It was a terrifying moment,"Â said 22-year-old
Musyoka.Â "All my roommates were killed by the militants. There were sounds of
guns all over. I was the only person in my room who survived the attack after
hiding inside a suitcase."Musyoka, like many of the other surviving students
now attends Moi University in Eldoret in western Kenya. Even though Garissa
University reopened in January, most non-Muslim students opted to leave: The
Al Shabab killers targeted Christians in their assault.One year after the
Islamic militant group Al Shabab mounted one of the most deadly terror attacks
ever to happen here, this East African country is still combating extremism,
and dealing with the aftershocks â€“ while preparing for the next attack.After
Al Shabab killed 148 students and staff at Garissa University in northern
Kenya on April 2, 2015, many students opted to move out of the region. At the
same time, Garissa is building a stronger perimeter wall to safeguard campus
in the future. And they hold drills â€” staging mock terrorist attacks â€” to
ensure preparedness.These drills are controversial, and sometimes, they
backfire â€” rather than following directions, students often run amok. Three
students in recent months died when they thoughtÂ a real attack was occurring.
Two jumped from high windows while a stampede of students crushed another
student."When this happens most students think itâ€™s a real attack,"Â said
Joshua Wekesa, a student at Nairobiâ€™s Strathmore University, who was injured
during a mock terror drill. "Most of them are terrified."That's because the
Al-Qaeda-linked group continues to launch fatal attacks along the Somali
border and Kenyaâ€™s northern coastline before retreating into hideouts in the
Boni forest, a remote area known for its elephants.The cumulative effect of
recent deaths on the coast, the Garissa massacre and the 2013 Westgate Mall
attack that killedÂ 67 has severely undermined peopleâ€™s confidence in the
Kenyan government, said Peter Wafula Wekesa, a political scientist at Kenyatta
University."It made Kenyans aware of the folly of the security apparatuses in
the country, which are inept, inefficient and reactionary,â€ Wekesa said. â€œAt
the very least, Kenyans are now more alive to the fact that they are on their
own on matters of security since they canâ€™t trust the government to provide
the same."Eldoret Police Commissioner Abdi Hassan said he was most hopeful
about a nation-wide program to train student leaders to help stop their Muslim
peers from becoming terrorists."We are committed to fighting terrorism by
ensuring that all students in universities are not radicalized by this terror
groups,"Â Hassan said. "We are offering lessons to help them reject any attempt
to be radicalized."Still, in spite of the drills, the beefed-up security, and
de-radicalization programs, Musyoka says she fears that another attack could
happen at her new school."When I hear a bang or an explosion within the school
compound, I panic,"Â Musyoka said. "My heart begins to pound. I live in fear of
attack. I want to finish my studies and get out of this place."At Garissa
UniversityÂ students and staff will honor the victims of the attacks with a
series of events, including interfaith prayer sessions Saturday."We want to
remember our students who perished during the attack,"Â said Garissa University
Principal Ahmed Warfa. "This was the lowest moment of my life. The incident
will remain deep in our hearts as teachers for as long as we live because we
lost our beloved innocent students."
title: Kenya university massacre haunts victims year later

Donald J. Trump is probably not going to win Wisconsin and everyone is
wondering what that means.Is it that having his campaign managerÂ charged with
battery against a female reporter, a thing that actually happened this week,
was the actual last straw for Trump voters otherwise inured to outrageous
behavior by the campaign? Is it that Wisconsin's conservative talk radio
hosts, in pointed contrast to their nationally syndicated peers,Â have been
forceful and unyielding anti-Trump voices? Is it that we polite, reserved
Midwesterners are just immune to Trump's abrasive style?Who knows. But
multiple public opinion polls in the last few daysÂ have shown Texas Sen. Ted
Cruz comfortably ahead of the blustering billionaire,Â set to pick up a bunch
of delegates in Tuesday's primary. In particular, the data showÂ Trump to be
especially unpopularÂ among Republicans in the state's reddest and most
populous Republican counties: the crescent of suburbs around Milwaukee. The
Marquette University Law School poll, which usually gets Wisconsin right,
shows Trump withÂ only 28 percent support from Republican voters in Milwaukee
suburbs.If those numbers hold, Trump is going to lose here. But in true
Trumpian fashion, he won't lose without doing a bunch of damage to the state's
Republican Party infrastructure.That's because Trump's lines of support in
Wisconsin reveal some regional fault lines that ought to be worrying
Republicans. In the more rural north and the west of the state, he is winning,
or at least heÂ _couldÂ _win. On CNN on Thursday, Rep. Sean Duffy said he
suspects his vast district, which extendsÂ from Wausau to Bayfield,Â will vote
for Trump. Duffy earlier in the weekÂ told the _Wall Street Journal_Â that
"Thereâ€™s a number of people in my district who are quiet Trump supporters." A
profile in political courage himself, Duffy, who previously endorsed Florida
Sen. Marco Rubio, said he would remain neutral in this primary.As far as
anyone can tell, Trump's first and only endorsement among Wisconsin state
legislatorsÂ came from James "Jimmy Boy" Edming of Glen Flora.Â Edming, whoÂ ran
for state Senate in 2010, told the Wausau _Daily Herald_Â editorial board back
then that his platform wasÂ "garage logic" and that everything he needed to
know about legislatingÂ he'd learned from fixing old cars â€”Â making him sort of
the perfectÂ Trump-supporting politician. This week he told the _Wall Street
Journal_ not only that he would vote for Trump but also how the GOP's internal
civil war is affecting him:Â "NowÂ that Iâ€™m seeing that the Republicans are
trying to tackle Donald Trump," he said, "the more I see on the news, the more
pissed off I get."The polls show nothingÂ like this sort of Northwoods-
vs.-Milwaukee split within Wisconsin'sÂ Democratic Party. Hillary Clinton edges
out Bernie Sanders in Green Bay and suburban Milwaukee; Sanders beats Clinton
in Madison, obviously, and in the north. But it's not a particularly stark
divide, and it doesn't feel like much of a civil warÂ even in comparison to the
2008 Democratic primary, which at the time felt quite heated but now seems
like a bygone era of civility and substance.**POLICING THE USA:Â AÂ look at
race, justice, media**If the polls hold and Cruz wins most of Wisconsin's
delegates on Tuesday, that will have serious consequences for the rest of the
Republican nomination battle, and will increase the likelihood of a chaotic,
contested GOP convention. That's exactly theÂ outcomeÂ a lot of Republican
leaders want, and as a national story it's seen asÂ a sort of comeback byÂ the
GOP establishment.But the Wisconsin Republican Party still has a lot of voters
like Jimmy Boy Edming. And if Trump loses, and especially if he losesÂ at the
convention,Â they are going to see it as a Republicans "trying to tackle Donald
Trump." In Wisconsin, they'll blame suburban Milwaukee, and they'll be right
to. How mad will they be, and for how long? Mad enough to break with
Wisconsin's Waukesha County-dominated Republican Party?The election is
Tuesday. The fallout from the chaos this election has sown has barely
begun._Robert Mentzer is central Wisconsin storytelling coach and a columnist
for USA TODAY NETWORK-Wisconsin, which is where this piece first appeared.
Follow himÂ on TwitterÂ @robertmentzer.__In addition to its own editorials, USA
TODAY publishes diverse opinions from outside writers, including ourÂ Board of
Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to theÂ Opinion front page._

Jersey lawmaker wants to make it illegal, with a fine of $50 and/or 15 days in

pedestrian has changed dramatically in the last 10 years, and people rarely

wheel, even with texting and driving illegal in 46 states, many are still
looking down at their phones while driving.So this is a real problem. But

_#TalkingTech Roundtable_Â podcast.Garrett Henricksen of the Shootly app calls

We should pay attention to real criminalÂ activity."A pedestrian text messages
while crossing the street in downtown Washington.Â (Photo: Pablo Martinez
Monsivais, AP)Photographer Rob Greer would consider a law that made it illegal
to text--only while crossing the street. "Many of us are looking down at our
phones to navigate our way around. We use the maps for walking
directions."Also on this week's show:--We talk SEO--industry jargon for how to

President Obama said Friday that Donald Trump doesn't understandÂ foreign
policy or the world in general, and U.S. allies are increasingly concerned
about the Republican front-runner's looseÂ rhetoric about nuclear
weapons."People pay attention to American elections," Obama said at a news
conference following the bi-annual Nuclear Security Summit in Washington,
adding that the topic of Trump surfaced on the sidelines of thoseÂ meetings.
"What we do is really important to the rest of the world."TrumpÂ has said the
United StatesÂ is spending too much on defense assistance to a host of nations,
from NATO allies in Europe to Japan and South Korea in Asia. The New York
billionaire said these nations should spend more on their own defense,
including the development of nuclear weapons if necessary.The candidate making
these kinds of statementsÂ "doesnâ€™t know much about foreign policy or nuclear
policy or the Korean peninsula, or the worldÂ generally," Obama said.Obama said
U.S. alliances â€”Â many dating from World War II â€”Â have promoted peace and
prosperity for decades. Those alliances, he said, involveÂ extensive national
interests, such as theÂ cooperation with Japan and South Korea in confronting

Just some former boy band members hanging casually.Â (Photo: The
Asylum/Syfy)Your favorite 90s boy bands are back, kids, and they're fighting
zombies. Seriously._Dead 7_, a TV movie featuring members of your favorite boy
bands like Nick Carter, Joey Fatone and Erik-Michael Estrada taking on zombies
in the post-apocalyptic west, debuts tonight on Syfy. 90s nostalgia, meet
zombie action. A match made in heaven, right?As you, me and everyone we can
think of are probably wondering, how did this all go down?Â We caught up with
Estrada, a member of O-Town,Â in a recent phone interview to break down how the
movie happened andÂ what was going on on set. We wish we could have been
there."About nine years ago, Nick Carter decided he wanted to write a movie,"
Estrada told us, saying that eventually his script was able to get into the
hands of the production company responsible forÂ _Sharknado_. Once the premise
was down, all they needed were the boy band-ers."They were casting, and
obviously they were casting for as many other boy band members as they could,"
Estrada said. "And during that time they reached out to the guys in my band
and I guess they reached out without him necessarily knowing and when he found
out that I was available to be in it â€” originally I had a much small role and
after I had agreed to do that smaller role I got another call from casting
saying â€˜Nick has asked if you would be interesting in playing one of the (main
characters).â€™"Erik-Michael Estrada as Komodo in 'Dead 7.'Â (Photo: Raymond Liu,
The Asylum/Syfy)When you're a former boy band member, who do you talk to? Who
do you reminisce with? Who justÂ _gets_Â you? Other former boy band members,
obviously."Weâ€™ve all crossed paths in different times over the years, during
the heights of our careers. And when we got to all be in the same room
together, we just started telling each other stories," Estrada explained.
"Stuff we did in the quick change room, after-show parties. Itâ€™s interesting
because I think each one of the bands has its own dynamic, but when weâ€™re all
together, it was the first time we had all had people we could talk about that
with, that shared that similar experience. I think it was cathartic (for all
of us). For us to be able to just talk to other people who could really relate
to us, because weâ€™re a pretty unique fraternity of sorts."If they hadn't
broken out into song at least once (besides the official track they recorded
for the film) we would have been sincerely disappointed. So good thing they
went to karaoke to let off some steam."There was a couple nights that we did
karaoke," Estrada said."That was fun. I know the production crew got a thick
out of that. (We sang)Â _I Want it That Way_, I believe. It was was whatever
the karaoke guy had readily available."We are really good at singingÂ _I Want
it That Way_Â at karaoke as well. Just for future reference."I know everyone
would love to do another one," he said. "So we just have to mash our heads
together and weâ€™ll come up with something."Maybe a different genre mashup?
Estrada, for one, had a really brilliant idea when we asked. "Maybe some type
of old gangster movie meets vampires?"We'd watch._Dead 7_Â airs on Syfy at 8:00

Is it OK for a cop to lie?A federal appealsÂ court, considering aÂ drug
trafficker's conviction in Montana, ruled earlier this week that sometimes it
doesnâ€™t matter.Attorneys for Hector Magallon-Lopez argued that crucial
evidence at the man'sÂ 2012 trial â€” two pounds of methamphetamine seized in a
2012 search of his car â€” should have been excluded because the police officer
lied about why the suspectâ€™s vehicle was being stopped.The officer told
Magallon-Lopez that he had failed to signal properly before changing lanes, an
intentional ruse so as not to arouse suspicion about the true nature of the
stop.The realÂ reason for the stop, according to court records, emerged from a
Sept. 27, 2012, Drug Enforcement Agency wiretap intercept, which indicated
that two Hispanic males, one bearing a distinctive arm tattoo depicting a
ghost and skull, would be transporting a supply of methamphetamine from
Washington state to Minneapolis.According to the intercept, the route would
take the two men traveling in "green, black or white'' car with Washington
plates through Bozeman, Mont., between 3 a.m. and 4 a.m. onÂ Sept. 28.Police
set up a surveillance operation on the main interstate running through
Bozeman. And around 3 a.m., officers spotted a green Volkwagen Passat with
Washington plates, registered to Hector Lopez at an address in the Yakima
Valley where, according to the wiretap, the drug shipmentÂ was to originate.The
sighting set in motion the traffic-stop ruse, when officers observed that one
of the occupants â€”Â Magallon-Lopez â€”Â sported what appeared to be a ghost or
"grim reaper'' on his right forearm, while the other man was identified as
Juan Sanchez whose name was first disclosed on the wiretap intercept. A
subsequent search of the vehicle resulted in the seizure of methamphetamine
hidden in a compartment under the trunk."The details that the officers
confirmed before making the stop sufficed to establish reasonable suspicion,''
Judge Paul Watford of the Ninth Circuit U.S. Court of AppealsÂ wrote in the
opinion supporting the officers' action. Â "Green, black or white passenger car
with Washington plates? Check. Traveling eastbound through Bozeman, Mont., on
the correct date and during the predicted, quite narrow time frame? Check.
Occupied by two Hispanic males? Check. Registered to an owner who lived in a
town associated with the investigation and who, at least in terms of stature,
fit the description of the person expected to be accompanying Sanchez? Double
check."That the officer lied about seeing Magallon-Lopez make an illegal lane
change does not call into question the legality of the stop,'' Watford wrote.
"The standard for determining whether probable cause or reasonable suspicion
exists is an objective one; it does not turn either on the subjective thought
processes of the officer or on whether the officer is truthful about the
reason for the stop.''In a concurring opinion, Judge Marsha Berzon
acknowledged some distress in reaching the same conclusion."Is it fine for
police officers flatly to tell the drivers they stop that they observed â€”Â or
thought they observed â€”Â a traffic violation when they really did not?'' Berzon
wrote. "We hold today that it is. And I cannot disagree, as the line of
(prior) cases...seems to lead to ineluctably to that distressing
conclusion...So long as the facts known to the officer establish reasonable
suspicion to justify an investigatory stop, the stop is lawful even if the
officer falsely cites as the basis for the stop a ground that is not supported
by reasonable suspicion.''
title: Federal court: OK for cops to lie -- sometimes

Many Americans are unaware of the basic facts about the Zika virus, which is
spreading rapidly through the Americas and could reach the continental U.S.
this summer.While 87% of people know that Zika is spread by mosquitoes, nearly
one in three people mistakenly believe that it also can be spread by coughing
or sneezing, like a cold, according to a survey of 1,275 adults from the
Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health and theÂ National Public Health
Information Coalition, a group that serves public relations officers."These
misperceptions about Zika virus transmission could lead people to take
unnecessary or inappropriate precautions, as we have seen in other kinds of
outbreaks,"Â saidÂ Gillian SteelFisher, director of the poll and a research
scientist in the department of health policy and management at the Harvard
Chan School.Doctors agree that pregnant women and their babies have the
greatest risk from Zika, which is linked to an alarming increase in birth
defects in Brazil. Yet even adults in homes where someone is pregnant or
considering pregnancy knew relatively little about Zika.Among people in
households where someone is pregnant or considering getting pregnant, 23%
didn't know about the link between Zika and microcephaly, a condition in which
babies are born with abnormally small heads and, in most cases, incomplete
brain development. Forty-two percent didn't know that Zika can be transmitted
sexually; 20%Â mistakenly believe there is a vaccine to prevent Zika; and 25%
mistakenly believe people infected with the virus are "very likely" toÂ show
symptoms.

whose reservation borders Winslow,Â Ariz., saidÂ Loreal Tsingine, 27, suffered
discrimination and excessive force, and theyÂ demandedÂ that the officer's name

The officer felt a substantial threat, Sepi said, and shot Tsingine five

On the first day of the newÂ quarter, the Dow tracedÂ out the same pattern it
traveled in the first quarter of the year: a big early drop has been followed
by a rebound rally that has pushed the blue-chip stock gauge to solid gains
for the day.Driving the volatile trading today was an early negative reaction
to tanking Japanese stocks and plunging oil prices. But those negatives were
offset by a better-than-expected March jobs report in the U.S. and good news
on the domesticÂ manufacturing front, where March data pushed back into
expansionary territory after months of suffering through its own private
recession. Any signs of a manufacturing bounce back bodes well for the
economy.Wall Street earlier today was also trying to interpretÂ what another
strong jobs report might mean for the Federal Reserve's interestÂ rate-hike
plans.After the market's miraculous comeback in the first quarter, when it
rallied late in the quarter to erase a double-digit percentage decline to
finish up close to 1%, U.S. stocks kickedÂ off the new quarter with a similar
trading pattern as it confrontedÂ a slew of cross currents that are weighing on
investor sentiment.Forty-five minutes after the opening bell on Wall Street,
the Dow Jones industrial average, which gained 1.5% in the first quarter and
was down 117 points earlier in the session, had erased its gains and turned
positive. The rally gained steam in the afternoon and the Dow closed the
session up 108 points at 17,793 -- a new 2016 high.The Standard & Poor's
500 index also set a new 2016 high, rising 0.6% to 2073. TheÂ Nasdaq composite
index gained 0.9% to 4915.For the year, the Dow is now up 2.1% and the S&P
1.4%. Only the Nasdaq remains in the red for 2016, down 1,9%.Weighing on
stocks early in the sessionÂ were many of the same worries that sparked a
correction earlier this year. Losses were again mounting up in the oil patch,
where U.S. produced crude fell 4.3%Â and ended belowÂ the $37 per barrel
mark.Market turbulence abroad has also been a factor today.Â Stocks in Japan
suffered a major downdraft overnight, tumbling nearly 4% as investors got a
case of the jitters after a survey indicating a dip in confidence among
Japanese businesses.A strengthening dollar, which hurts U.S. multinationals
and depresses commodities, is also fanning the bearish flames today.Add on
Wall Street trying to figure out what another strong jobs report might mean
for Fed monetary policy, and you end up with a confluence of negatives that
have given investors reason to sell.But the strong manufacturing report,
coupled with good news on jobs,Â helped offset the negatives.Wall Street
digestedÂ the release of the March jobs report, which came in solid and a tad
better than expected. The government reported that the U.S. economy created
215,000 new jobs last month, slightlyÂ topping expectations. The unemployment
rate ticked up to 5%, vs. an estimate of 4.9%. Other plusses in the report:
average hourly earnings for workers rose 0.3% and the labor participation rate
ticked up to 63%.The continued strength in the job market suggests the U.S.
economy continues to chug along, further reducing fears of a recession.Jim
Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management, sums up the
confusing cross-currents best."The jobs report was 'good,'Â but not so good
that it immediately raises fears that the Fed is behind the curve (and will
have to change course and hike rates sooner or more aggressively than
thought)," Paulsen says. "The bottom line:Â this report will calm recession
fears and is positive for risk assets."But Paulsen does add in a disclaimer of
sorts, and offers other reasons which might explain the market's wobbly start
to Friday's session."However, the probability of Fed tightening has risen
again since this report ..., so worries about the Fed and rate increases are
also climbing a bit since the report.Â I think the stock market is reacting
thus far to a bad Tanken surveys (on business sentiment) in Japan (where the
NikkeiÂ fell 3% overnight) and to the big drop in the price of oil.Â These two
things are more than offsetting a jobs report, which is kind of neutral, as it
showsÂ solid economic growth (that will)Â probably leadÂ to faster Fed
tightening."Paulsen correctly predicted stocks would turnÂ higher as Friday
moves on as fears of recession fade further from view.In the just-completed
first quarter, the S&P 500 rose 0.8%, the Nasdaq fell 2.7% and the small-
company Russell 2000 was off 1.9%. Both the Dow and S&P 500 are less than
3.0% off their record highs from May 2015.The start to the quarter was gloomy
in foreign stock markets as well. Shares were trading sharply lower in Europe,
where the broad Stoxx Europe 600 index was down 1.6%. In France, the CAC 40
was off 1.6% and in Germany, the DAX was off 1.6%.

Iâ€™m all for second chances. A third one? Maybe not.Greg Hendrix coached
freshman football and served as an assistant on the varsityÂ in Bentonville
(Ark.) Highâ€™s powerhouse football program, up until he was fired in 2014 for
allegedly calling a former player turned cheerleader a â€œ[expletive] queerâ€ and

sheetâ€ that asked, among other questions: Did seeing the movie change your

â€œSo, weâ€™re going to watch the news, yâ€™all got something you want to do, do it,

Hendrix has been suspended with pay pending the administrationâ€™s

OK, so when the MLB season opens up with a televised â€œtriple-headerâ€ starting
at 1 p,m. ET this Sunday, I will probably watch most of it, as enjoying
baseball is not only an important part of my job but also an important part of
my constitution. I have a game of my own Sunday morning, but Iâ€™ll probably go
out toÂ eatÂ with some friends afterward, and weâ€™ll probably watch the first
game because we all know each other through baseball and share a common love
of baseball. Then, wiped out from playing, Iâ€™ll head home and watch the 4 p.m.
game because it features the Toronto Blue Jays and their incredible offense,
which is always fun, and because I can think of no better way to pass a lazy
Sunday afternoon than watching baseball. Once thatâ€™s done, Iâ€™ll certainly DVR
_The Walking DeadÂ _so I canÂ tune into the night game, because it so happens to
be a World Series rematch between the Mets and Royals, and because, again,
itâ€™s among the first games of real, meaningful Major League Baseball after far
too much time without it.But I will watch all of it begrudgingly. Do you hear
me? Begrudgingly, I say!It happens that I am so dedicated to watching baseball
that I will watch baseball even when I strongly believe, on principle, that
the specific baseball in question should not be undertaken at that particular
time. Theyâ€™ve got me hooked, and so I willÂ participate in Major League
Baseballâ€™s continued trivialization of what should be the greatest and most
important holiday of the year: Opening day.And I understandÂ that, rationally,
the league andÂ _ESPNÂ _and everyone else involved have good reasons for kicking
off the season with a Sunday triple-header â€” making more money, mostly, which
is in their best interests as businesses. And typically, I believe the
nostalgia-driven calls for baseball to go back to doing things the way
baseball used to do things are silly and unnecessary, and that progress just
sort of happens and we have no choice but to plow forward.But this isnâ€™t a
rational thing. Opening day should serve as a celebration of baseball to be
enjoyed by all fans of all teams on the same day. A couple of years ago, teams
actually played their season openers onÂ _four different days_. At that point,
why even bother giving it a name?True story:Â One April afternoon in 1987, when
I was six years old and toiling through a lesson on whatever the heck you
learn about in Kindergarten, the principalâ€™s voice came over the classroomâ€™s
P.A. and called me down to his office so I could leave school and go attend my
first-ever baseball game with my family: Opening day atÂ Shea Stadium. The same
thing happened pretty much every year after, but that first time probably
stands as the greatest day of my life. All downhill from there, really. I got
toÂ _leave schoolÂ _to go to a baseball game! Take that, all you suckers staying
behind in school! You guys stay here learning how to add; Iâ€™ll be watching
baseball.Everyone deserves that type of excitement, I think. And the best way
to guarantee it is to scrap the Sunday-night nonsense and have all 30 Major
League teams start their seasons with day games on the first Monday in April,
then get about ensuring that the first Monday in April become a national
holiday in which everybody exceptÂ those of us who get to attend baseball games
for work is excused from work.If you check out MLB.com or any teamâ€™s website,
youâ€™ll find â€œOpening Dayâ€ capitalized as though itâ€™s a real thing and a proper
noun. It should be both, but itâ€™s neither now. Itâ€™s just a couple of days on
which teams Major League teams play their first games.

HAWTHORNE, Calif. -- Tesla Motors CEO Elon Musk said Friday that "pre-orders"
for theÂ Model 3Â electric car had hit 198,000, an encouraging sign a day after
the novel vehicle aimed at a mass market was unveiled here to an enthusiastic
crowd.The Model 3Â drove onto a stage through a curtain of fog atÂ a lavish
ceremonyÂ in a converted hangar adjoining the SpaceX factory in this Los
Angeles suburb. Tesla CEO Musk vowed that the car will seat five, hit the
highest safety marks andÂ have a range of at least 215 miles a charge.While its
performance won't be nearly as breathtaking as its larger sibling, the super-
luxury Model S, will be impressive: Zero to 60 miles per hour in less than 6
seconds. To prove the point, Tesla offered test rides with a long straightaway
in which the car hurtled down a side roadÂ atÂ push-you-back-in-your-seat speeds
in near silence.The Model 3, Musk said, will be priced at $35,000, about half
the cost of its two current models, the Model S sedan and Model X crossover.
Musk tweeted Friday that with options, the average order was closer to
$42,000.Â The car is considered critical to Tesla's success, its first attempt
to lure average car buyers -- not just the rich -- Â to electric
vehicles.Initial reaction to the car appeared favorable. After lines formed
outside Tesla showrooms around the country where customers could make
reservations for a refundable $1,000, which it terms "pre-orders."Â Musk
announced the figures had hit 115,000 by the time the car was revealed. Then
on Friday, Musk tweeted that the order bank had hit 180,000, then later that
it was 198,000. "Future of electric cars lookingÂ bright!," he wrote.Tesla
"will set the all time record for any consumer tech company," wroteÂ Trip
Chowdhry, analyst for Global Equities Research, in a note before the
unveiling. Musk says Tesla is aiming to produce 500,000 cars a year, up from
about 50,000 last year. To accomplish the goal, Tesla is building what Musk
says will be the largest lithium-ion battery factory in the world outside
Reno, Nev.The car's profile is similar to the Model S, lacking any adornment
on the front where a grille would normally be. Musk says the car has trunks
both front and rear. The extra space is due to its lack of aÂ gas engine since
it hasÂ only batteries and electric motors. Inside, the car has a huge screen
on the center console like other Teslas, though it is slightly smaller than on
the Model S or X. It is also distinguished by a huge glass roof over both the
front and rear seats,Â which Musk says affords better headroom.Experts say they
expectÂ different versions of the Model 3, some fancier than others. In the
process, it could experience price creep."Tesla has a history of introducing a
vehicle with a reasonably low price and then selling versions that are much
more expensive," says Jack Nerad, executive editorial director for Kelley Blue
Book, in a statement. "There was no mention of EV's major Achillesâ€™ heel --
recharge time. The 215-mile range and low recharge times make EVs Â (electric
vehicles) impractical for many buyers.â€Musk says Model 3 carsÂ will start
delivery to customersÂ in late 2017.In another plus for the Model 3, Musk says
it will have access to Tesla's Supercharger network, which will be expanded.
Superchargers are high speed recharging units, both in cities and on major
highways.
