PARISÂ â€”Â Parisians are flocking to first-aid training centers to become
qualified first respondersÂ as nightmarish thoughtsÂ of terrorists Â grip their
minds."Weâ€™re not trained enough," Web designer Marc Lamard, 26, said after
completing his first-aid trainingÂ at aÂ town hall near the site of terrorist
attacks in the city last year."In case of a wave of panic, you need to stay
calm and know what to do."Parisians know terror all too well. On March 22,
neighboring Belgium was hit by coordinated attacks that left 32Â dead. Last
Nov. 13,Â Islamic militants went on a rampage in the heart of the capital,
killing 130 people. Â Those attacksÂ followed Â mass shootings in January 2015 at
the satirical newspaper _Charlie Hebdo_ and a Jewish grocery store, in which
17 people were killed.Afterward, many wondered how they could have helped the
wounded, saidÂ Christophe Talmet, head of the French Red Cross emergency and
first-aid training program. TalmetÂ coordinated rescue teams during the
attacks."People were saying, 'I have to do something, but I don't know what,'
" TalmetÂ said.Â "Something happened, people really felt involved â€” it touched
them very deeply."As a result, Paris City Hall has been overwhelmed by the
scale of the public response to its offer of free classes to teach Parisians
how they can help save lives before emergency services arrive on the scene."We
had originally thought we would do this once a year, but we will have to do it
again soon," said Bernard Jomier, Paris' deputy mayor in charge of health, who
initiated the first training event last weekend.Â "Our new goal is to give
initiation classes to up to 10,000 Parisians this year and to train 10,000
more to become qualified rescuers."Jomier, a physician who was at Paris
hospitals the day after the attacks Nov. 13, recalled long lines of people
wanting to donate blood. The mobilization "was impressive," he said "to the
point that we had to tell them not to go because the stocks were full."The
French Red Cross normally offers comprehensive emergency training sessions on
the weekends. But two days after the attacks Nov. 13, the number of Parisians
registering to attend via the humanitarian organization's website rose by 40%,
Talmet said.Â Extra training sessions were set up to cater for the
demand."People are knocking on our doors, they want to become players," Talmet
said.All 3,500 slots were booked during the day-long training sessions
organized in each of the city's districts, Jomier said."What can a citizen do
in the face of terror,Â take a weapon, confine himself at home?" Jomier asked.
"Here we tell him, 'You can act. If something terrible happens, you can be
useful.' It is the responsibility of the authorities to show them how they can
do it."Participants said they were grateful for the training.Some 3,500 people
signed up for the training organized by city hall in the aftermath of deadly
terror attacks.Â (Photo: J. Riffaud/ J. Haller, French Red Cross)"When I heard
about the attacks, I was both scared and sad, even if it wasnâ€™t in my
neighborhood," Prune Lambert,Â 16, said as she lined up with her family to
observe a Red Cross volunteer demonstrating aÂ CPR technique.Lambert's brother,
Pierre, 13, initially didn't understand why his mother insisted he go, but he
said after the training that itÂ would be useful "should there be another
attack."Patrick Pelloux, a former _Charlie Hebdo_ columnist and emergency
doctor, was first on the scene after the shooting at the paper's editorial
office. He gave first aid to surviving colleagues and also treated victims of
the attacks in November."Civilian defense was abandoned after World War II, so
we need to reinvent it," Pelloux said.In 2004, the French government passed a
law to teach children basic lifesaving skills. Â  Pelloux said that did not go
far enough.Almost half of French citizens Â have some first-aid training,
Talmet said. Still,Â Northern European countries are better prepared.Â Ninety-
five percentÂ of Norwegians and 80% of Germans areÂ qualified, according to a
report in 2009 by the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent
Societies."This training must be made very popular so that people train
regularly," said Pelloux,Â who worked with the Paris Fire Brigade to help
organize the training event. "At least once a year so that people remember
what to do."
title: With terror in mind, Parisians train to be first responders

Jess and Ryan Weaver of Elkhart, Indiana, canâ€™t qualify for a mortgage. The
couple have a household income of around $70,000 per year, four kids age 7 and
under â€” and $200,000 in combined student loan debt. That makes their total
debt high compared to their income â€” a red flag for lenders.Jess and Ryan, who
went to Bethel College in Mishawaka, Indiana, arenâ€™t unusual. Theyâ€™re part of
a growing group of graduates who are delaying major life milestones because of
their student loan debt, according to a 2015 study by the Boston-based
nonprofit American Student Assistance.â€œWhen we first took out student loans,
we couldnâ€™t see the impact it was going to have later in our lives,â€ Jess
says.For others, like Cyndi and Rick Blalock of St. Charles, Missouri, student
loan debt isnâ€™t debilitating; itâ€™s just a means to an end.â€œWe kind of just
consider student loan debt the cost of doing business,â€ says Cyndi, who owns
her own dental practice. She and Rick, a chiropractor, had $375,000 in student
loan debt when they graduated in 2011. But with six-figure incomes and no
kids, the couple was still able to purchase a home in 2014 through Health Care
Family Credit Union, which offers mortgages specifically for healthcare
professionals. And now, after years of aggressive payments, Cyndi and Rick
have eliminated around $169,000 of their principal student loan
balances.Whether your student loan debt is paralyzing or just a pain, itâ€™s
possible to ease your burden so you can buy a home, have a family or start a
business. Here are five ways to get started.Income-driven repayment plans are
one of several solutions the government offers federal student loan borrowers
who are struggling with debt. These arrangements â€” which include income-based
repayment, Pay As You Earn and the Revised Pay As You Earn plans â€” allow
qualifying borrowers to cap their payments at a percentage of their income,
and have their remaining debt forgiven after 20 or 25 years of payments.Given
their income and their four kids, the Weavers qualified for an income-based
repayment plan that currently allows them not to make payments on their
$100,000 in federal student loan debt. The couple has to reapply for the plan
every year, and if their income increases, they may have to start making
monthly payments. But as long as they qualify for income-based repayment â€“ no
matter what their monthly payment is â€“ their remaining federal student loan
balance will be forgiven at the end of their repayment period.They still pay
around $900 per month toward their $100,000 in private student loans. Loans
taken out from a private lender, rather than the government, arenâ€™t eligible
for federal repayment plans.Â The government offers federal borrowers whoâ€™ve
worked for the government or a nonprofit for 10 years full student loan
forgiveness. Another federal program partially forgives federal student loans
for teachers who work in low-income public schools for five years. You can
maximize the amount youâ€™ll save through these programs by making payments on
an income-driven repayment plan.Deferment and forbearance are both programs
that allow certain borrowers to temporarily stop making monthly loan
payments.The government allows borrowers to defer their federal loans if
theyâ€™re facing an economic hardship, going back to school or serving in the
military; it grants forbearance to borrowers with medical issues or other
financial challenges.Some private lenders offer deferment and forbearance, but
their programs arenâ€™t typically as generous as the federal governmentâ€™s.Rick
Blalock opened his chiropractic clinic shortly after graduation and didnâ€™t
turn a profit right away. That qualified him for two years of loan deferment.
His loans still accrued interest, but he used the the cash he saved on monthly
payments to build his business.â€œCash flow was so important,â€ he says. â€œWhen
youâ€™re starting a new business from scratch, itâ€™s hard to get a bank to give
you a loan.â€Â Â You can lower your interest rate by refinancing your student
loans, whether theyâ€™re federal or private. However, bear in mind that
refinanced federal loans become private and no longer have federal borrower
protections and benefits, including access to income-driven repayment plans,
forgiveness programs, deferment and forbearance.An increasing number of
employers, including PricewaterhouseCoopers and Fidelity Investments, are
contributing to employeesâ€™ student loan payments. A March 2016 NerdWallet
study found that borrowers can save more than $4,000 in interest by taking
advantage of this perk.Even if your employer doesnâ€™t officially offer to help
repay your student loans as part of your compensation, it doesnâ€™t hurt to
negotiate for it, says Kevin Fudge, manager of consumer advocacy and community
affairs at American Student Assistance.â€œYou never know whatâ€™s possible until
you ask,â€ he says.More from NerdWallet:

theÂ majorityÂ fromÂ Republicans,Â analysts predict.To gain control of the House,
Democrats would haveÂ to winÂ 30 of the 31 Republican-held House seats that are
considered at-riskÂ without losing a single seat of their own, said David
Wasserman, who analyzes House races for the non-partisan Cook Political
Report."It's a long shot, but it's not impossible,"Â said Wasserman, who
predicts that Democrats are likely to gain up toÂ 15 seatsÂ but adds thatÂ the
election remains volatile and his estimate could change.The fact that a
Democratic takeover is no longer being dismissed by analysts as completely
absurdÂ shows just how unpredictable this election season has become, thanks in
large part to the emergence of Trump as the Republican presidential front-
runner."A year ago, if you had asked me what would it take to put the House in
play, I'd have said it would take Republicans nominating someone who
frequently insulted women, immigrants, religious minorities and ignored basic
facts. And we're there,"Â said Wasserman. "The election has become a referendum
on Donald Trump instead of Barack Obama."The Democratic Congressional Campaign
Committee â€” the Democrats' House campaign operation â€”Â Â is not assertingÂ at
this point that Democrats will take over the House. But the party clearly
believes the divisiveness of Trump's campaign has opened up new opportunities
for its candidates, especially in suburban districts with well-educated voters
and in districts where the percentage of Latino voters is in double digits.
National polls have shown that aboutÂ 80%Â of Latino voters have an unfavorable
view of Trump, as do about 70% of Republicans with college degrees.Among the
districts where Democrats believe they may be able to take advantage of those
demographics: Virginia's 10th Congressional District, which is represented by
Republican Barbara Comstock and isÂ made up of high-income, highly educated
suburban residents and has a growing Hispanic and Asian population; and
Pennsylvania's 8th Congressional District, an open seat thatÂ includes affluent
suburbs north of Philadelphia."The political environment is as unpredictable
as Trump's explosive rhetoric, but one thing is for sure: House Democratic
candidates are ready to seize on the electoral winds at their back, and win
big in November," said Meredith Kelly, national press secretary for the
Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.But aÂ spokeswoman for the National
Republican Congressional Committee said it is too little, too late for
Democrats. Democrats have run out of time to field competitive candidates in
many states, where the filing deadline to run for Congress has closed,Â said
NRCC Communications Director Katie Martin."House Democrats' first issue is
that they've had recruitment failures across the country," Martin said. "In
very competitive races, if they do have a candidate, they are very weak
candidates. They have a math problem and they having a filing problem when it
comes to deadlines, which makes themÂ taking back the House impossible."She
said Republican incumbentsÂ running for the House are not focusing on
Trump."Our members are very focused on working for their districts, regardless
of what's happening anywhere else," Martin said.Â "IÂ think when you open up any
local newspapers inÂ our members' districtsÂ back home, you're going to read
great headlines aboutÂ what they'reÂ accomplishing for their communities."Most
Republican candidates are doing their best to avoid talking about Trump,
trying instead to focus on local issues, said Eric Herzik, chairman of the
political science department at the University of Nevada, Reno."A month ago,
the safe line for Republican congressional candidates was, 'I'll back the
Republican nominee, whomever that is,' " Herzik said. "Now that it looks like
it's going to be Trump or Cruz, the safe line is, 'We still have primary
states to go through, we have to see how this plays out, let the people
speak.' The other safe thing for them to do is avoid talking about what's
going on in the Republican Party and say, 'We've got to save the nation from
Hillary Clinton.' "But some GOP candidates in close elections have decided to
denounce Trump. Republican Reps. Carlos Curbelo, R-Fla., and Bob Dold, R-Ill.,
both running in Democratic-leaning districts, have said they will never
support Trump. Curbelo has called Trump "insulting and offensive" and Dold has
denounced him for "disgusting and offensive" comments about women, Muslims,
and Hispanics.Only seven of the 246 Republicans in the House haveÂ endorsed
Trump.Part of the problem for GOP congressional candidates is that Americans
are increasingly voting party-line, making it unlikely that they would vote
for Clinton for president and a Republican for Congress at the same time, said
Jack Pitney, a political science professor at Claremont McKenna College in
California."That puts the Republican majority in jeopardy, especially in
suburban districts, where Trump is about as popular as head lice," Pitney
said. "Trump is definitely going to cause damage for Republicans. It may not
be quite enough to cost them control of the House, but he is going to make the
party bleed. The only question is how much."

Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland once blocked Donald Trump's current
campaign manager from recovering his gun after an arrest.Â (Photo: SAUL LOEB,
AFP/Getty Images)WASHINGTON â€” Long before they made headlines,Â President
Obama's embattled Supreme Court nominee and Donald Trump's beleaguered
campaign manager had a legal altercation over a gun.Merrick Garland was one of
three federal appeals courtÂ judges who denied Corey Lewandowski's effort to
get his pistol back after his arrest in 1999 for carrying itÂ into a House
office building.Garland, who is under fire from gun-rights groups for two
other rulings that supporters say have been misrepresented, was joined in
ruling against Lewandowski in 2003 by two conservative judges.Lewandowski was
charged with battery this week for grabbing a female reporter while she was
trying to ask Trump a question. That prompted media reports that cited his
earlier brush with the law.Seventeen years ago while working for former
RepublicanÂ congressman Robert Ney, Lewandowski was arrested for carrying what
court records say was a loaded pistol, three magazines, a holster and several
rounds of ammunition in an overnight bag into the Longworth House Office
Building.Trump campaign manager Corey LewandowskiÂ (Photo: Joe Raedle, Getty
Images)He was charged with a misdemeanor, claimed it was an accident, and the
charges eventually were dismissed. Then for four years he fought to get the
gun back, filing lawsuits in fourÂ District of Columbia and federal
courts.After losing in two D.C. courts, Lewandowski tried to recover the gun
from the police department and was again denied. He filed a federal lawsuit
for loss of property and mental anguish,Â seeking $50,000 in damages, but the
judge ruled it was "simply an attempt to sue the government again." That
prompted the appeal toÂ the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit â€”
Garland's court.In May 2003, a panel composed of Garland and conservative
Judges Douglas Ginsburg and David Sentelle became the fourth court to deny
Lewandowski's effort to recover the gun in a brief, unsigned opinion.Garland,
nominated earlier this month by President Obama for the Supreme Court seat
left vacant by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, has been denouncedÂ by the
National Rifle Association over two more substantive cases.In 2007, he was
among several judges who sought to reconsiderÂ a three-judge panel's decision
striking down the District of Columbia's handgun ban. Conservative critics say
that shows he favored the ban. Supporters note that judges often seek
rehearings simply because of an issue's importance, not because they disagree
with the earlier ruling.In 2000, GarlandÂ was on a panel that upheld the
Justice Department's maintenance of background checkÂ data for six months. The
NRA had challenged the policy as constituting a national gun registry.

WACO, Texas â€” Jasmin Hernandez, a former Baylor student who claims she was
sexually assaulted by a former Bears football player, has filed a lawsuit
against the school alleging Title IX violations and negligence by the
university.Hernandezâ€™s lawyers gave her name to the media to use in reporting
on the case.According to the lawsuit, an alleged victim of former Bears
defensive end Tevin Elliott said that she had been raped by the football
player. The lawsuit named the victim as Jane Roe to protect her identity. The
lawsuit said that Baylorâ€™s chief judicial officer, Bethany McCraw said there
was â€œnothing McCraw could do in response to Roeâ€™s complaint that she had been
raped by Elliott.â€Elliott was convicted of sexual assault and sentenced to 20
years in prison and fined $10,000 for crimes while he was at Baylor.The
lawsuit said McCraw told Roe that she was â€œthe sixth female student to come in
to McCrawâ€™s office to report that they had been sexually assaulted by
Elliott.â€ The suit further stated that Baylor coachÂ Art Briles â€œwas aware of
the reports.â€According to the suit, McCraw allegedly told Roe that there was
â€œnothing the school could do for Roe unless there was a court determination
that Elliott had indeed raped Roe. Otherwise McCraw said it would come down to
a â€˜he said-she saidâ€™ situation, and the school could not act on it.â€The
lawsuit stated that Hernandez enrolled at Baylor in the fall 2011 and that on
April 15, 2012, she was attending a party at a residence near campus. The suit
says Elliott invited Hernandez and her friends to the party as he knew one of
the friends.The lawsuit stated that at one point in the evening, Hernandez
became separated from her friends and that Elliott grabbed her by the wrist
and led her outside. The suit states that as Hernandez continued to protest,
the player picked her up over his shoulder and carried her behind a secluded
shack on the property.According to the lawsuit, one behind the shack, â€œElliott
pushed Hernandez up against an embankment, ripped off her pants and began to
rape her.â€ The suit says Hernandez began to pull her pants back up and Elliott
grabbed her again, pulled her pants back down and raped her again.Hernandez
went back into the party and told her friends what had happened and they took
her to a nearby hospital so a rape kit could be performed, according to the
suit. The suit said Hernandez also gave an account of what happened to a Waco
Police officer.The lawsuit says Hernandezâ€™s mother arrived to help the next
day and was turned away for help by: the Baylor Counseling Center, the
psychology department at Baylorâ€™s Student Health Center, and Baylorâ€™s Academic
Services Department which allegedly told the mother, â€˜If a plane falls on your
daughter, thereâ€™s nothing we can do to help you.â€According to the suit,
Hernandezâ€™s mother and father both contacted Brilesâ€™ office multiple times to
follow-up on the incident. The suit said the mother received a call saying the
coach was looking into it and the father never received a return phone
call.The suit said despite Hernandezâ€™s report to several administrative
offices, â€œBaylor did not take any action whatsoever to investigate Hernandezâ€™s
claims.â€The suit accuses Baylor of multiple failures to comply with federal
law, Title IX, and that the school acted â€œwith deliberate indifference towards
Hernandezâ€™s reports of rape to several different Baylor departments as
reflected by Defendantsâ€™ actions and inaction alleged herein.â€The lawsuit also
alleged that a former member of Baylorâ€™s advisory board that â€œreviewed sexual
assault response issues with community leaders has publicly stated that Baylor
officials have known abou the larger problem of sexual assaults committed by
student-athletes for years.â€ The suit said the former member is a nurse who
â€œhas estimated that despite only making up 4% of the student population at
Baylor, male student-athletes are responsible for 25% to 50% of all reported
assaults that occur at Baylor.â€Baylor had another player convicted of sexual
assault last year. Defensive end Sam Ukwuachu was convicted of sexually
assaulting a Baylor student following a football game against Iowa State in
2013. The victim in that case reached a settlement with the university late in
2015._Follow Tim Kephart on Twitter:Â @timkephart33_

The way, truth and the Hive...Â (Photo: Ezra Shaw)From rallying brown girls to
get in _Formation_ to her unapologetic Black Lives Matter tribute at the 2016
Super Bowl, from her mic-dropping announcement of an international tour to the
debut of her Ivy Park "athleisure" line, BeyoncÃ© is once again all on our
mouths like liquor. And theÂ Queen Beeâ€™s renewed buzz can be only mean one
thing: Another edge-snatching album is upon us.BeyoncÃ©'sÂ camp previously
confirmed the album would drop sometime in April, which got us thinking, â€œWhy
_not_Â this Monday (April 4)?â€Hereâ€™s the calculatedÂ reasoning behind our
prediction.BeyoncÃ© has largely eschewed interviews over the course of the last
two years, relying instead on a painstakingly curated social media profile and
HBO documentary, quiet contributions to grassroots movements campaigning
against systemic racism, and sumptuous music video visuals that leave critics
wringing their handsÂ in a bid to parse throughÂ her embedded political
messages.Â And yet, on the verge of increasing clamor about her sixth studio
album, Bey agrees to a cover story. The _Elle_ profile (on newsstands and
online April 4) is either incredibly serendipitous or incredibly strategic.
Based on the mogul's business savvy, weâ€™re inclined to lean toward the
latter.Time is running out for BeyoncÃ© to release new music before her
_Formation_Â world tour kicks off April 27 in Miami. Of course, nothing's
stopping her from touring without new material. But we're not talking about an
amateur here â€” we're talking aboutÂ _BeyoncÃ©_, one ofÂ music's savviest
marketers,Â who's ascended the pop music throne by making sure there's always
something new for her fans to buzz about. Launching a tour without releasing
an album first? Both we and Bey know that's a wasted opportunity.From the
_Formation_ video's pointed policeÂ brutality references to Bey's Black Panther
homageÂ at the Super Bowl, all signs point towardÂ BeyoncÃ© highlightingÂ social
justice issues on her new album. And April 4 marks an important and tragic
anniversary for the BLM movement â€” it's the one-year anniversary of the death
of Walter Scott, who was killed by police after a traffic stop in South
Charleston on April 4, 2015. Combined with the rumors that Bey will honor
Trayvon Martin, Tamir Rice and Mike Brown in one of her new music videos,
remembering Scott by releasing her album on the 4th isn't beyond the realm of
possibility.BeyoncÃ© previously opened up about the significance of the number
4 during her press tour for her fourth studio album, the aptly titled _4_.
During an July 2011 interview with _Good Morning America_, the singer
explained: "My birthday is on the fourth. My mother's birthday is on the
fourth. My husband's (Jay Z)Â birthday is on the fourth. I got married on the
fourth." So, why not debutÂ her highly anticipated LPÂ on the fourth day of the
fourth month of the year â€” a day which also marksÂ her 8th anniversary with
Jay? It's only right.

Each dayÂ seems to bring a new reasonÂ for Republican leaders to contemplateÂ how
they might derail Donald Trump at the GOP convention, along with hand-wringing
over whether itÂ would be appropriate to violate the will of the people â€” or at
least the will of mostÂ Republican primary voters.Â But there is one group that
would wholeheartedly support party officials: the Founding Fathers.The
FoundersÂ were far more worried about a demagogue seizing power than they were
about following the voice of the people. Most important, they clearly intended
the election of the president to be well-insulated from a direct expression of
the popular will. That is why we have the Electoral College, which was
designed to temper the sometimes clamorous voice of the people.Although this
has led several times to candidates winning the popular vote but losing the
election, most recently in the case of Al Gore in 2000, the Founders would not
necessarily have had a problem with such a result. They were far more worried
about too much democracy than they were about too little democracy.The reason
for this was simple: The Founders did not entirely trust the people, whoÂ were
too likely to be ruled by their passions, rather than guided by their reason.
As James Madison wrote, â€œIt is a misfortune, inseparable from human affairs,
that public measures are rarely investigated with that spirit of moderation
which is essential to a just estimate of their real tendency to advance or
obstruct the public good; and that this spirit is more apt to be diminished
than promoted by those occasions which require an unusual exercise of it.â€No
one would argue that â€œspirit of moderationâ€ has presided over theÂ Republican
nomination contest. Much as Madison and the other Founders feared, passion
instead of reason is the driving force this election cycle, as the recent
violence at political rallies has amply confirmed.The figure whom the Founders
most feared was the demagogue, whose inflammatory rhetoric stirred the very
passions that the Founders hoped to control â€” a fairly apt description of
Trumpâ€™s campaign to date. That is one of the main reasonsÂ the Constitution
contains so many roadblocks to the direct expression of the peopleâ€™s will.
Much of Madisonâ€™s Federalist No. 10 is an outline for how the new republic
wouldÂ control demagogues. Enlarging the size of the nation would help â€œto
refine and enlarge the public viewsâ€ and make it more difficult for â€œmen of
factious tempers, of local prejudices, or of sinister designsâ€ to use
â€œintrigue (to) betray the interests of the people,â€ he wrote.In other words,
many of the checks and balances built into the Constitution were put there
precisely so that people such as Trump would not be able to win an election.
Actually, the Founders feared men such as Patrick Henry, with his impassioned
and persuasive oratory, although I believe they'dÂ have found Henry a virtual
Pericles compared with The Donald.**POLICING THE USA:Â AÂ look at race, justice,
media**The role of political parties in all of this complicates matters
somewhat but would not have changed their overall view. The Founders almost
universally hated political parties and were deeply distressed when the new
republic quickly gave rise to protoparties (true political parties in the way
that we think about them did not exist until well into the 19thÂ century). As
Thomas Jefferson wrote, â€œIf I could not go to heaven but with a party, I would
not go there at all.â€ For the Founders, the problem with a political party was
that it went directly against the kind of dispassionate reason they hoped
would guide all political debates by requiring men to hew to the party line,
regardless of their conscience.What would the Founders have thought of party
leaders who undermined their own nominating process to keep a man such as
Trump from winning? They'dÂ likely have congratulated them for doing exactly
what wise statesmen are supposed to do â€” dampening the passions and allowing
reason to rule.The Founders found many ways to bridle the voice of the people
to avoid what they saw as the â€œexcesses of democracy,â€ particularly when it
came to the office of the presidency. They'dÂ undoubtedly find fault with this
election season, but not with Republicans for subverting their own nominating
process._Andrew Trees is an adjunct professor of history at Carthage College
and author of _The Founding Fathers &Â the Politics of Character._In
addition to its own editorials, USA TODAY publishes diverse opinions from
outside writers, including ourÂ __Board of Contributors__. To read more columns
like this, go to theÂ __Opinion front page__._
title: The Founders would have dumped Trump: Column

PALM SPRINGS, Calif.Â â€”Â GunTV, a shopping channel that has been billed as
similar to iTunes, but for guns, will begin broadcasting from a California
studioÂ FridayÂ at 1 a.m. Eastern.The channel will start with programming from 1
a.m. to 7 a.m. but plans to expand to a 24-hour lineup by the end of its first
year. GunTV also will sell ammunition, firearm accessories and outdoor
apparel.It has not yet been announced what television providers or channels
will carry the controversial shopping channel, so it is unclear who will
actually be able to tune in.Â However, the channel alsoÂ willÂ be broadcast on
the GunTV website.GunTV is filming in a renovated television studio in
Thousand Palms, Calif., formerly known as the Palm Springs Film Factory, that
was designed for a cooking show or commercials. The channel's founders are
Doug Bornstein and Valerie Castle, a couple with professional backgrounds in
shopping networks who live inÂ Rancho Mirage, Calif.â€œWe are very excited to
bring our new concept of shopping for firearms and accessories to live
television," Castle said in a news release. "Our unique platform allows
industry manufacturers to showcase products through our talented and
experienced on-air hosts. Viewers will receive in-depth, entertaining product
demonstrations, and see the products in action, an important component of the
purchasing decision.â€The development of GunTV became public knowledge in
November when _The (Palm Springs, Calif.) Desert Sun_, which like USA TODAY is
ownedÂ by Gannett Co. Inc.,Â broke a story revealing that the network was
setting up in the Coachella Valley. A few weeks later, two Islamic State-
inspired terrorists killed 14 people in San Bernardino, a city only an hour's
drive from the Thousand Palms filming location. The nationwide debate over gun
control came to focus on the Inland Empire, with national media criticizing
the shopping channel as ill-timed.Soon after, GunTV's launch was delayed. The
shopping channel grew quiet, stopping all public statements and social media
postings, until the channel's launch was abruptly announced in a news release
Thursday morning.According to the release, GunTV will dedicate three minutes
of every hour to firearms safety.â€œWe understand that the more informed we are
as consumers, the better purchasing decisions we make," Castle said in the
release. "At GunTV, safety is our number one priority.GunTV appears to be
modeled after existing shopping channels, such asÂ the Home Shopping Network
and QVC TV, but will face more stringent restrictions. Unlike the jewelry,
commemorative coins or decorative plates sold on other channels, firearms
canâ€™t be mailed across state lines or sold to just anyone.To work within gun
laws, GunTV wonâ€™t actually sell firearms directly to its viewers. Instead,
when a viewer calls GunTV, the network will place an order on behalf of that
viewer with Sports South, a Louisiana firearms distributor. Sports South will
then ship the weapon to a local gun store, where it can be purchased as normal
by the viewer.In a prior interview, an official from the Law Center to Prevent
Gun Violence said the sales process appears to adhere to the laws that
regulate gun sales.Â However, she still argued that GunTV was trivializing the
sale of firearms.â€œBuying a gun is a serious decision,â€ said Laura Cutilletta,
senior staff attorney for the Law Center.Â â€œIf you are going to buy a gun for
your home, itâ€™s not a decision you should be making at three in the morning
because you are watching TV.â€_Follow Brett Kelman on Twitter: @TDSbrettkelman

If youâ€™ve ever read and loved a Maisie Dobbs mystery, and the two tend to go
together, you should rush to buy _Journey to Munich _(Harper, 284 pp.,Â *** Â½
out of four stars).And if you havenâ€™t, well, this _Journey_, wonderful as it
is, may not be the best place to start.That doesnâ€™t mean there arenâ€™t joys for
a newcomer to discover in Jacqueline Winspearâ€™s taut, tense, beautifully
written novel, or that its story is impenetrable to all but the fully
initiated: this isnâ€™t college calculus, there are no prerequisites. Nor does
it mean you necessarily have to start in at the beginning of this now 12-book
series; there are other entry points that would allow you to move backwards
and forwards, if you so choose.But taken together with its equally good
immediate predecessor _A Dangerous Place, Journey_ serves as a bridge that
takes the series'Â main character, World War I nurse turned psychologist and
investigator Maisie Dobbs, into a new chapter of her life. And like most
transitions, this one has more impact if you know what came before.More
perhaps than any book so far, _Journey_ finds Maisie in a reflective mood,
taking stock of prior cases and retracing prior steps. Newcomers might find
the effort confusing, but no one should find it repetitive: Winspear is
unearthingÂ new riches buried deeper in old ground,Â as Maisie comes to realize
that some of her views on past events were wrong, or at least one-sided.Author
Jacqueline Winspear.Â (Photo: Stephanie Mohan)Set in 1938, _Journey_ continues
to follow the havoc wreaked by the First World War as the world makes its
inexorable way toward the Second. Maisie, however, is seeking a break from
world events, returning to England and, she hopes, some degree of normalcy
after the death of her husband and child.Friends and enemies alikeÂ seek her
out, however, and sheâ€™s soon off to Munich on an undercover mission for the
British government. As _Journey_ is a mystery, you expect things will not go
as planned. What you may not expect is theÂ inventiveness of Winspearâ€™s twists,
the on-edge excitement they provoke, or the philosophical issues and
psychological depths they allow her to explore.There are some great new
characters we may hope to see again, along with anÂ antagonist who is a more
interesting creation than your standard stock Nazi villain. Where _Journey_
truly shines, though, is in Winspearâ€™s recreation of a citizenry on the brink
â€” some caught up in and rushing toward madness, others shrinking back, hoping
it will pass.Like its heroine, this is an intelligent, tough but compassionate
book, one that immerses us in history without swamping us in details or excess
foreshadowing. Maisie is on a journey of self-reclamation, and if that
involves feeling lost at times, thatâ€™s fine with a woman who hasÂ learnedÂ never
to fear going in circles because â€œthe next time around, youâ€™ll see something
you missed before.â€For Maisie fans, the next time around canâ€™t come soon
enough.

A snapshot of the first _Star Wars: The Force Awakens_ cast read-through was
fansâ€™ initial glimpse seeing John Boyega in the sci-fi universe â€”Â though with
more couches than starships.That iconic day comes to life as a featurette when
_The Force Awakens_ hits digital platforms Friday and Blu-ray/DVD Tuesday, and
Boyega â€”Â who plays Stormtrooper-turned-hero Finn â€”Â admits it was wholly nerve-
racking.â€œThis is the first time I spoke Finnâ€™s words, especially in the
American accent, out loud in front of everyone else, with real Americans
around me, so I didnâ€™t want them to be like, â€˜Oh my gosh, his accentâ€™s off,â€™ â€
says Boyega.Thereâ€™s a lot of him in the bonus extras, from deleted scenes to a
featureÂ showing director J.J. Abrams working with Boyega, Adam Driver (as evil
Kylo Ren) and Daisy Ridley (as the heroic Rey) to create the final lightsaber
battle.Boyega phones in from London to talk about _Force Awakens_ secrets and
what folks can expect from the now-filming _Episode VIII_ (out Dec. 15,
2017):Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and Finn (John Boyega) are cornered by
Stormtroopers in a deleted scene from "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."Â (Photo:
Lucasfilm)**Which of the deleted scenes were you gutted to lose?**It was the
scene between Finn and Han when theyâ€™re cornered by the Stormtroopers in Mazâ€™s
castle. That was the first time me and Harrison (Ford) got in our flow in
terms of the banter and the jokes. We were having fun and ended up shooting
like 13 different versions just because it was a lark to do it.**What was the
key to connecting with all your co-stars?**Finn gets along with everybody:
Heâ€™s got a great chemistry with Poe, a great chemistry with Rey, a great
choppy chemistry with BB-8 and Chewie, and the thing with Han. I had to work
with everyone and to do that, youâ€™ve got to have a little bit of a reputation.
Youâ€™ve got to be the popular kid. (Laughs)Finn (John Boyega) wields a
lightsaber in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."Â (Photo: Lucasfilm)**What single
plot point was the hardest to not spill?**I really wanted to tell people that
Finn wasnâ€™t going to be the Jedi of _Force Awakens_, that you wouldnâ€™t see any
signs of him being Force-sensitive. Because they had all the posters (of Finn)
with the lightsaber, I was really scared and didnâ€™t want people to be somewhat
disappointed. But you know, Daisy looks good with a blue saber, too â€” she took
on the helm and I was able to sneak off being unconscious!**Whatâ€™s impressed
you the mostÂ about _Episode VIII_ director Rian Johnson?**Rian has really
touched a deep chord in my heart. Moving forward in the story, you can tell
that Rian and J.J. are of the same ilk artistically, and Rian is bringing his
own perspective and feel to the film. If youâ€™ve watched _Looper_, you know
that Rian is great especially with the darker style of narrative, but also
thereâ€™s a lot of fun and it still feels like a _Star Wars_ movie.**Whatâ€™s the
biggest lesson you learned doing _Force Awakens_ that youâ€™ve taken to heart
for the new film?**When I first got the role, I made myself a promise that I

FOSTER CITY, Calif.Â â€” When it comes to TVs, the mantra is simple. Itâ€™s the
picture quality, stupid.But life in the real world isnâ€™t always that easy.
There are many different factors that can influence what your eyes actually
perceive when theyâ€™re looking at various TV screens. Sure, the quality of the
TV itself probably has the biggest influence, but the quality of the source
material plays a nearly equal role.Each of these elements, in turn, is
influenced by a number of supporting pieces. On the TV side, thereâ€™s the type
of technology used (LCD, OLED, etc.), the screen resolution, color range,
contrast ratioÂ and much more. On the content side, quality goes all the way
back to how the material was first recorded, edited, encoded and stored, and
then the means of distribution. Even the bandwidth of a network connection if
the source is being streamed.Frankly, itâ€™s enough to confuse just about
everyone.Thankfully, the TV and content industries have recognized the
challenge and are working on means to make things simpler. Even better, the
fruits of those efforts are just starting to come to market. The problem is,
there are a few of these consumer-friendly monikers that vendors are now
using.Probably the biggest effort comes from the UHD (Ultra High Definition)
Alliance â€” a group of more than 35 consumer electronics, broadcast and film
production companies â€” and itâ€™s called UltraHD Premium.The original work on
the alliance and its logo program â€” meaning products that meet the
certification can carry the UltraHD Premium logo on their packaging â€” started
at CES 2015 and at this yearâ€™s CES, the logo became official. The UltraHD
standard covers TVs and BluRay players on the hardware side, and recorded and
streamed video on the content side.Dolby has come up with a somewhat similar
certification program of its own that it calls Dolby Vision, which also has a
logo. Finally, some companies, notably Sony, are sticking with labeling of
their own. In Sonyâ€™s case, it's using 4K HDR.Despite the potential confusion,
what unites all of these different efforts is not just an increase in
resolution to 4K â€” more than four times the resolution of standard HDÂ â€” but
improvements in the quality of each of those 4 million pixels. Specifically,
the visual improvements involve two key elements: a higher dynamic range
between light and dark signals, hence HDR, and a broader range of colors â€”
sometimes called a wider color gamut.Sony's X900C ultra-slim 4K UHD TV seen at
the 2015 International CES at the Las Vegas Convention Center.Â (Photo: David
Becker, Getty Images)Together, the greatly improved contrast ratio offered by
HDR and the increase to more thanÂ 1 billion possible colors, thanks to whatâ€™s
called 10-bit color, offer a visually noticeable improvement even over
standard 4K TVs.Arguably the HDR and color gamut features are much more
important to overall picture quality than the resolution increase of 4K
because they can be seen from any distance on any size screen. Appreciating
the resolution enhancements of 4K alone, on the other hand, often requires an
uncomfortably up-close glance at a large screen.Thatâ€™s why the recent
introduction of these enhanced UHD (Ultra HD) specs, which combine both 4K
resolution along with HDR and a 10-bit (or higher) color gamut, is a bigger
deal than the introduction of 4K. (To be clear, not all 4K or even UHD TVs
feature HDR or a wider color range. You need to specifically look for those
features.) The new TVs that meet these specs from vendors like LG, Samsung,
Sony, Panasonic, Vizio and others offer stunning images, particularly when
combined with new Ultra HD Premium or Dolby Vision-logoâ€™d content.Of course,
to get the full impact, you need to be on the lookout for high-resolution
audio capable components (sometimes called HD Audio), as well as Dolbyâ€™s new
Atmos audio surround specification support as well. That way youâ€™ll get sound
quality that matches the visuals.Even better, many companies are combining
increasingly sophisticated smarts into their new UHD TVs. Chinese brand, TCL,
for example, just announced they will be offering a series of Roku TVs, which
incorporates all the capabilities of a standalone Roku Smart TV box. In
particular, the company has announced a Dolby Vision enabled unit called the
X1 thatâ€™s expected to be released later this year.If youâ€™ve been living with a
standard HDTV for some time, you might want to check out the brand-new UHD+HDR
offerings just becoming available. Your eyes will thank you._USA TODAY
columnist Bob O'Donnell is president and chief analyst of TECHnalysis
Research, a market research and consulting firm that provides strategic
consulting and market research services to the technology industry and
professional financial community. His clients are majorÂ technology firms that
includeÂ Microsoft, HP, Dell, and Nvidia. You can follow him on Twitter
@bobodtech_
title: Forget 4K, it's time for Ultra HD

If the networks donâ€™t want us to rush to judgment, they should make rushing
more difficult.Consider CBSâ€™s _Rush Hour _(Thursday, 10 ET/PT, ** out of
four), a dispiriting,Â derivative buddy-cop comedy based on the hit movie
franchiseÂ starring Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker. Which means odds are good
you'll come to the series knowing that most shows based on movies donâ€™t work,
and will leave thinking _Rush Hour_ does not feel like an exception, in large
part because Jon Foo and Justin Hires feel like awfullyÂ bland substitutes for
Chan and Tucker.Now to be fair, many of us â€” myself included â€” reachedÂ similar
conclusions about CBSâ€™s _Limitless_, which has become one of the network's
brighter lights. Even in its flawed pilot, however, _Limitless_ showed a gift
for inventive storytelling that's missing here.Here's another difference:
Rather than try to shoveÂ Jake McDorman into theÂ role played by Bradley Cooper
in the film, _Limitless_ created a new character for him, which helped lessen
the inevitable comparisons. _RushÂ _seems to be begging us to compare old to
newÂ â€” and in Thursday's premiere, "new" doesn't fare so well. Indeed, it
barely even registers.John Foo as Detective Lee, Justin Hires as Detective
Carter, and Wendie Malick as Captain Lindsay Cole in 'Rush Hour.'Â (Photo:
Richard Cartwright, CBS)Here, however, is one moreÂ _Limitless_ lesson worth
learning: Itâ€™s never wise toÂ count an actor out. Those of us who assumed that
McDorman could not carry_ Limitless _have been proved wrong: He's turned out
to be one of the seasonâ€™s most engaging performers. So we should avoid making
the same assumptions about Foo and Hires because who knows â€” given better
material and more time to develop their own takes on the characters, perhaps
theyâ€™ll improve.But goodness, they have a steep climb ahead of them.Foo plays
Hong Kong Detective Lee, sent to Los Angeles to retrieve some stolen objects
and, he hopes, a missing person. Heâ€™s teamed with Hiresâ€™ Detective Carter,
whoâ€™s assigned the job as punishment by his boss, Captain Cole (Wendie Malick,
one of the best reasons to retain hope). Naturally, the Captain is exasperated
by Carterâ€™s tendency to break the rules, as well she (and we) should be,
because there's noÂ more by-the-book TV than aÂ cop who doesn't behave by the
book.Even without seeing the film, you can probably guess where_ Rush Hour_ is
headed, as it does nothing to subvert a single stereotype or cliche. Lee is
laconic and, in his halting English, a bit sardonic. Hires is over-stimulated,
chattyÂ and funny, or at least written as funny. They clash, but of course they
will bond:Â there isnâ€™t a second episode if they donâ€™t.Justin Hires as
Detective Carter and John Foo as Detective Lee are partners in 'Rush Hour.'
(Photo: Neil Jacobs, CBS)Perhaps by that point, the show will begin to
establish its own identity and the stars will begin to seem a little more at
ease and a lot more distinctive. Weâ€™ll just have to try to remember that
patience is a virtue.Just as CBS had better remember that our patience is not
limitless.
title: Review: Don't rush to see CBS's 'Rush Hour' remake

WASHINGTONÂ â€” Starting April 30, the Navy will allow service members to have
larger tattoos on their bodies and allow smaller pieces of body art on their
necks and behind their ears, according to a new directive issued
Thursday."This policy change is about honest with ourselves, and putting
policies in place that reflect tattoo realities in the nation we serve," Lt.
Cdr. Nate Christensen, the spokesman for the chief of naval personnel, said.
"It is also meant to ensure we don't miss opportunities to bring in talented
young men and women willing to serve."The new policy will allow members of the
Navy to have a tattoo on the neck that "shall not exceed one inch in
measurement in any dimension, (height/width)," the directive says. "Tattoos
meeting these requirements are acceptable behind the ear."Only tattoos on the
neck or behind the ear will be limited in size, the directive says. Those
elsewhere on the body "can be of any size."The Navy prohibits tattoos that are
obscene, symbolize membership in gangs, supremacist or extremist groups or
advocate illegal drug use, Navy policy says.

LOS ANGELES â€“ Kobe Bryant has seen enough theÂ past two decades to realize the
effect that twists of fate can have on a career. Or the twist of a knee.â€œThe
sports gods have a sense of humor,â€ Bryant told USA TODAY Sports. â€œThatâ€™s what
I think. It is pretty amazing that it seems like in sports you always have
those weird connections.â€For Bryant, who is retiring after an historic 20-year
NBA career, one of those connections dates back to when he wasÂ just 3 years
old.It involved Mitch Kupchak. The Los Angeles LakersÂ general manager since
2000, Kupchak also played in the NBA for nine seasons. In 1981, he was signed
by the Lakers to a seven-year, $5.6 million contractÂ â€” big money for that era
â€” and expected to be a key member of a team that would go on to win the NBA
title. But that ended in December 1981.â€œMy first year in L.A. we were playing
the San Diego Clippers,â€ Kupchak said. â€œMagic (Johnson) kind of shuffled me
the ball for a layup and a player stepped in front of me to draw a charge.â€œSo
I tried to stop rather than get the charge and have a big collision, but I
couldnâ€™t stop so I ended up injuring my knee, tumbling into this player and
going on the floor together.â€Kupchak missed the rest of the season and the
following one. Coach Pat Riley promoted Kurt Rambis to a starting position and
owner Jerry Buss soon traded for another big man, Bob McAdoo. Both would play
a crucial role on thatÂ championshipÂ team. However, the long-term effects were
even greater.Although Kupchak came back to play an additional three seasons
with the Lakers, appearing in 147 games, he was never the same. But he stayed
with the team, even after retirement, going to business school, working as
assistant GM to Jerry West, then eventually taking over the main job.It was
thenÂ his path began to intertwine with that of Bryant, though things were
fairly straightforward at first, with Bryant and Shaquille Oâ€™Neal forming an
unstoppable combination that produced three titles from 2000-'02.However,
Oâ€™Nealâ€™s departure in 2004 left the Lakers at a crossroads. The fruitless
years that followed caused Bryant to demand a tradeÂ â€“ unless Kupchak could do
something to turn things around.â€œI was pissed,â€ Bryant said. â€œNot even kind
of, it was fury. I had to win a championship without Shaquille Oâ€™Neal. It was
just the challenge. It wasnâ€™t fair. But it is what it is. That was just an
obsession.â€œSo I (wasnâ€™t) going to sit here and play for this organization, no
matter how beautiful the city is, no matter how much I love the franchise. I
(was) out here scoring 40-50 points, breaking my back trying to win, and money
(was) not being spent on getting talent here to win a championship.â€Bryant
flirted with joining the Clippers, thought about the Chicago BullsÂ and
eventually stayed in purple and gold. His faith was rewarded when Kupchak
traded forÂ Pau Gasol, laying the foundation for a new double act that would
lead to two more titles, in 2009 and '10.Kupchak says he was aware of the
tension.â€œWe were stuck in a period where he was in his prime and we were a
playoff team but we were not good enough to get where he wanted to go,â€
Kupchak said. â€œSo the frustration reared its head. (Then) we got lucky with
the Pau deal and for him that put him back in the finals.â€Bryant, at the time,
summed up his thoughts by telling the _Los AngelesÂ Times_ that Kupchak had
gone â€œfrom an F to an A-plus.â€NowadaysÂ Kupchak shakes his head when he
reflects on the way things turned out. He admits it is unlikely he would have
ended up as a GM, anywhere, let alone the Lakers, had his playing career
panned out the way he wanted it to.â€œIn terms of Laker lore and winning
championships, maybe my injury was a good thing,â€ Kupchak said.He still
remembers the missed step that caused his knee to buckle. He can visualize the
play, and almost feel the pain. And he certainly remembers the San Diego
Clippers player, a blameless participant, who stood in his path and caused him
to change direction before his knee crumpled beneath him.It was Joe
â€œJellybeanâ€ Bryant, Kobeâ€™s father.
title: How the twist of a knee brought Kobe Bryant, Lakers GM together

The race for delegates continues in nine states in April in the Republican and
Democratic contests.Â (Photo: Otto Kitsinger, AP)_This post has been
updated._April is National Stress Awareness Month, so there's no better time
than now to be aware of the political calendar in the weeks ahead.Groups
stressedÂ about the role of money in politics, voting rights and the Supreme
Court vacancy plan to stage marches, rallies and other protests April 2-18.
The first round of events, called â€œ**Democracy Spring**,â€ kicks off Saturday
in Philadelphia with a 10-day, 140-mile march to Washington.**North Dakota
Republicans** choose 25 delegates to the Republican convention, plus three
state officials who are already assured a ticket. The state party chose not to
have a presidential preference poll this year, so these delegates are not
bound to anyone, but some may publicly endorse a candidate.It's **Opening
Day** for most Major League Baseball teams, which could mean little talk of
politics for at least one day of the month. (Not that any hardworking
political journalists would escape their desks early for the
ballpark.)**Wisconsin holds its primaries** for both parties, withÂ 42
delegates at stake on the GOP side and 86 pledged delegatesÂ for Democrats (the
state also has 10 Democratic "superdelegates" who get to back whomever they
want).Ted Cruz speaks at a campaign stop on March 25, 2016, in Oshkosh, Wis.
(Photo: Darren Hauck, AP)This marks **onlyÂ ****seven months** (and yet, STILL
seven months)Â **until Election Day**.**Wyoming holds its Democratic
caucuses**, with not a lot of Democrats butÂ 14Â delegatesÂ at stake.â€œDemocracy
Spring" continues with aÂ **sit-in at the U.S. Capitol**.While this is the only
Tuesday in April without a primary, it's a notableÂ date for another reason:
the **one-year anniversary ofÂ Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign
launch**. Seems like we were all so young then.Screengrab of Hillary Clinton's
campaign announcement video.Â (Photo: AFP/Getty Images)All three Republican
candidates â€” Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and John Kasich â€” are slated to appear at
the **New York Republican State Committee's annual gala** in New York City,
five days before the state's primary.This marks** Emancipation Day,** the
annual holiday celebrating Abraham Lincoln's freeing of the slaves in the
DistrictÂ of Columbia. If you don't live in D.C. you could easily miss this
holiday, but this year, you get a special benefit: Since it falls on April 15,
the IRS is closed, and everybody gets until Monday to file their
taxes.â€œ**Democracy Awakening**â€ events start April 16 and will feature a rally
and march around the Capitol on April 17. More than 230 organizations,
including the AFL-CIO, NAACP, the National Organization for Women, Public
Citizen and Greenpeace, are involved in the efforts.**Tax Day.** Fun's over,
people. Pay your taxes.The **Supreme Court holds oral arguments inÂ United
States v. Texas,** the major immigration case that'll determineÂ whetherÂ the
president has the authority to protect millions of undocumented immigrants
from deportation without going through Congress.Â The case comes up in the
midst of a presidential campaign in which front-runner Trump has called for
building a wall along the Mexico border and deporting more than 11 million
people who came to the U.S. illegally.Immigration activists demonstrate at the
Supreme Court in support of President Obama's executive order to grant relief
from deportation in order to keep immigrant families together on March 18,
2016.Â (Photo: J. Scott Applewhite, AP)Trump and Clinton will be seeking home-
state bragging rights asÂ **New York holds its primaries for both parties**.Â A
whopping 247Â delegatesÂ are at stake that day in the Empire State for Democrats
â€” the largest single delegate prize in April. Most of the state's 44
superdelegates have already said they are backing Clinton.Â On the GOP side, 95
delegates are at stake.The **Republican National Committee** gathers for its
**spring meeting**Â in Hollywood, Fla. Normally, these are boring
organizational affairs where little news is broken. This year, with candidates
in an uproar over delegate fights, convention rules and Secret Plans to Stop
Trump, it should be more fun to watch.This is also the deadline for people
seeking the presidency â€” and the super PACs trying to boost or kill their
chances â€” to spill the beans on their **March fundraising and spending**.
March was a very busy,Â and costly, monthÂ on the primary calendar, so the
political world will want to know how much leftover funds candidates had
remaining for Aprilâ€™s big contests.Â The filings also will give us a sense of
whether GOP front-runner Donald Trump borrowed any more funds from Donald
Trump, the real-estate mogul. (His investment was nearing $25 million at the
end of February.)Senate and House candidates also must file reports to the
Federal Election Commission by April 20.Donald Trump speaks during a campaign
rally at St. Norbert College on March 30, 2016, in De Pere, Wis.Â (Photo: Scott
Olson, Getty Images)**Obama kicks off a big international trip**, starting
with a stop in Saudi Arabia for aÂ Gulf Cooperation Council summit, followed by
a trip to the United Kingdom the next day and then on to Germany. We hope he
will bring back gifts for everyone.**HBO'sÂ _Veep_ returns**, motivating
political nerds everywhere, if they haven't already done so after last
season's finale,Â to calculate what might actually happen in a real Electoral
College tie in November.In this image released by HBO, Julia Louis-Dreyfus
appears in a scene from "Veep."Â (Photo: Patrick Harbron, AP)In the most
crowded day of contests since mid-March, all eyes willÂ turn East as
**Connecticut**, **Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island hold
their primaries both both parties**. Pennsylvania offers the biggest delegate
haul of the day with 71 for Republicans and 189Â for Democrats (there are 21
superdelegates here). Note that as many as 54 of the Republican delegates may
be uncommitted, maintaining the same freedom as Democratic superdelegates to
support the candidate of their choosing.**The Supreme Court hears oral
arguments inÂ McDonnell v. United States**, the political corruption case
that'll determine what type of action by a public official on behalf of a
political benefactor bearing gifts constitutes corruption.Â The justicesâ€™
review of former Virginia governor Robert McDonnellâ€™s conviction for accepting
gifts in exchange for government favors could set a new ethics standard.The
final day of the month marks **one year since the launch of Bernie Sanders'
2016 campaign**. It isÂ also President Obama's finalÂ **White House
Correspondents' Association dinner**. Prepare to ROFL.President Obama delivers
remarks during the WHCA dinner at the Washington Hilton on April 25, 2015.
(Photo: Evan Vucci, AP)_Contributing: Fredreka Schouten_
title: April political datebook: 19 key days to watch

Award-winning architect Zaha Hadid died of a heart attack at age 65 on
Thursday. The Baghdad-bornÂ architect who made her home in London became the
firstÂ woman to receive the Royal Institute of British Architects Gold Medal in
2016 andÂ the first woman recipient of the renowned Pritzker Architecture Prize
in 2004. Her designs have been commissioned and erected around the globe â€“
Hong Kong, London, Germany and elsewhere. Here are five of her most famous
works:The MAXXI, or the National Museum of the 21st Century Arts, took over
ten years to complete.Â (Photo: Pier Paolo Cito, AP)**The MAXXI, or the
National Museum of the 21st Century Arts, RomeÂ **Hadid won the Stirling Prize

cost $223 million. The museum is locatedÂ on the grounds of a former military
barracks in a residential area of Rome.Dame Zaha Hadid poses in front of the
Serpentine Sackler Gallery in London.Â (Photo: Oli Scarff)**Serpentine Sackler
Gallery, London**The gallery is located in Kensington Gardens inÂ London and
displays contemporary art. It "consists of two distinct parts, namely the
conversion of a classical 19th century brick structure â€“ The Magazine â€“ and a
21st century tensile structure," Zaha Hadid Architects said in a statement.The
London Aquatics Centre built for the 2012 Olympic Games was designed by Dame
Zaha Hadid.Â (Photo: John Walton, AP)**London Aquatics Centre**The Centre
designed byÂ HadidÂ for the 2012 Summer OlympicsÂ is "inspired by the fluid
geometries of water in motion, creating spaces and a surrounding environment
that reflect the riverside landscapes of the Olympic Park," according to

zig-zagging roof and houses over 3,000 objects of transportation, including
skateboards and velocipedes.This museum was Hadid's first major public
commission in the UK and was completed in 2011.Chanel's "Mobile Art" was a
futuristic pavilion created by architect Zaha Hadid.Â (Photo: Kin Cheung,
AP)**Chanel Contemporary Art Container**Hadid designed this traveling art
spaceÂ to resemble Chanel's iconic 1955 quilted handbag. The structure,
containing work by contemporary artists, stopped in New York's Central Park on
its worldwide tour in 2008.

PARIS â€“ The City of Lights is a visual feast, from the Seine below, to the
sidewalk cafes, to the mansard roofs overhead. The wandering eye lands on
works of art at every turn: sculptures, bridges, fountains, Space Invaders.
Wait, what?If you spend much time promenading Parisian streets, eventually
youâ€™ll spot at least one of more than a thousand brightly colored tile mosaics
that are scattered throughout the city.They are the result of a worldwide
â€œinvasionâ€ that began in 1998, the brainchild of an anonymous French street
artist who is known only by his pseudonym, Invader. The moniker is a reference
to his favorite subject: Space Invaders aliens from the classic arcade game.
The 46-year-old career street artist has remained incognito while installing
more than 3,000 unique mosaics around the world.In Paris alone, the prolific
artist has placed 1,182 mosaics, at least thatâ€™s what he reported late last
year when I visited his outpost in the outskirts. In his 1,600-square-foot
workshop, Invader continually designs and constructs pixelized works that
range from the size of a paperback to commanding 8-foot-high portraits.Invader
feels embraced by his hometown. â€œI think they have accepted me as a cultural
interest for the city,â€ he said. â€œMost people, if they wake up in the morning
and see a Space Invader on their building, they are happy.â€Over the decades,
the artist has built a lucrative career from his illicit medium, selling his
work in galleries, accepting public commissions and selling one copy, or
â€œalias,â€ of each of his street pieces, starting at $15,000. In 2015, with an
assist from the European Space Agency, he placed a small mosaic in the
International Space Station.Although heâ€™s not entirely predictable (the No. 1
trait of any street artist), his signature spot in Paris is near the classic,
blue street signs on the corners of buildings, a good reminder to lift your
eyes on your next stroll through Paris.And the next?â€œThere are still some good
spots waiting for my intervention,â€ he says.

Insurers increasingly areÂ dropping agents' commissions toÂ discourageÂ the sale
of the Affordable Care Act plansÂ they're losing the most money on, especially
when the consumers are more likely to be sick, according to health care
industry officials and experts.TheÂ moves by nearly every major insurerÂ over
the last few months areÂ often focused on times of the year and plans that
attract the sickest people andÂ starting to prompt action by state officials
and legislators. Some,Â including the head of California's state insurance
exchange,Â say federal regulators should helpÂ assure consumers get the help and
plans they need,Â especially during special enrollment periods when they lose
jobs, move or have babies.Some insurers, including Anthem and Humana, say they
dropped commissions to keep rates down. Humana spokesman Mark Mathis said the
insurer believesÂ agents are "an important source of information and guidance,"
but itÂ sometimes makes "changes in order to maintain sustainable and
affordable health plans for our members."Others say insurers are cutting
commissionsÂ to save money by reducing the number of sick people who
enroll."Many states are looking at doing whatever can do to support to agents
in their states and not allow health plans to game their commissions so they
enroll only healthy people," Â Peter Lee, executive director of the Covered
California exchange, said in an interview. "It flies in the face of the ACA
... to say in code to agents, 'Donâ€™t bring us sick people', or to make it
harder for some.to enroll."People who lose their jobs are most likely to
quickly sign up for insurance if they're sick,Â saysÂ Larry Levitt, senior vice
president of the Kaiser Family Foundation,Â who has discussed the issue with
insurance company actuaries and state and federal ACA exchange
officials.Insurance agentsÂ now enroll about half of those who buy insurance on
the government exchanges. Low-income people, who tend to have more health
problems, need to buy their plans on the government websites to get federal
subsidies and often need the most help.Aetna, United Healthcare and Cigna have
all complained they're losing money on ACA plans and enrollment drops off
sharply as subsidies fall. A study out Tuesday by theÂ Â Blue Cross Blue Shield
Association found the cost of medical care for those newly enrolled in ACA
plans were 19% higher in 2014 and 22% higher in 2015 than those who were
insured through employer plans by BCBS companies those years.The Centers for
Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) called the report "seriously flawed," in
large part becauseÂ those with serious health problems trying to buy individual
insuranceÂ could be discriminated against because of their conditions before
the ACA took effect.Insurance was supposed to be easier to buy, Lee and Levitt
say, so it was assumed agents would not be needed to buy ACA plans. The
opposite happened, however, as fewer states created their own exchanges than
expected, the federal Healthcare.gov site had massive problemsÂ and Republicans
in Congress kept the federal government from hiring moreÂ "navigators" to help
people navigate the site and health insurance system toÂ buy policies, says
Levitt.Despite improvements with the exchanges, many consumers still need
help, saysÂ Lee, who acknowledges he was wrong the exchanges would "make buying
insurance asÂ easy as buying a book on Amazon."The process isÂ especially
confusingÂ for consumers eligible for subsidies. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of
Michigan, which still pays commissions, has found that 80% of consumers are
eligible for subsidies, but only 40% know that when they first contact the
company, spokesman Andy Hetzel says."If insurance agents are not paid, the
consumer loses becauseÂ they have to travel down this road alone without an
expert," agreesÂ Ronnell Nolan, CEO of Health Agents for America.Some insurers,
including Humana,Â have dropped commissions on different types of plans in
different states, especially gold and platinum plans, which Levitt says
attract people with the most health problems because of their low deductibles.
While Humana dropped commissions on these plans after open enrollment ends,
othersÂ including United Healthcare nearly eliminated them altogether for 2016
plansÂ for individuals and families. AetnaÂ recently eliminatedÂ commissions on
all new individual plans with effective dates between March 31 and Dec.
31.Katherine Hempstead, director of the health insurance coverage team at the
Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, says cutting commissions is a "cry for help"
by insurers that shouldn't be ignored.Â (Photo: Robert Deutsch, USA
TODAY)Katherine Hempstead, director of the insurance coverage team at the
Robert Wood Johnson Foundation,Â says droppingÂ commissions should be seen as a
"cry for help" by insurers as it shows they are "signaling that in the current
market there are some products that they really don't want to sell."Insurers
have criticized the federal government for allowing customers to abuse the
special periods by signing up for insurance when they needed health care and
then dropping insurance after the crises had passed. CMS recently limited the
circumstances that allow people to sign upÂ for the special enrollment
periods.A bill passed the Georgia House last week that would require insurers
there to pay agents a minimum commission, but it failed to make it through the
Senate. The Louisiana state House is expected to vote onÂ a bill within days
that would require insurers to give agents 90 days notice before dropping
commissions.Under the ACA, insurers have to spend 85% of premiums on medical
care, leaving only 15% for overhead, including commissions. Insurers started
reducing the size of commissions soon after the law passed.Pennsylvania state
Rep. FrankÂ Farry, a Republican, is researchingÂ whether to introduce
legislation requiring insurers to pay commissions, butÂ worries that requiring
themÂ to spend a portion of the 15% on commissions couldÂ "put them in a
pinch."Peter Lee, executive director of Covered California, that state's
health insurance exchange, told federal regulators commission should be
required.Â (Photo: Covered California)Earlier this year, the Connecticut
Insurance DepartmentÂ blocked United Healthcare from eliminating commissions
because the company included them in its 2016 rate filing that was approved.
The insurer instead reducedÂ itsÂ commission from $20 to $10 a month.Colorado
and California both require commissions for agents.Lee, ofÂ Covered California,
urged Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell in January to mandate
minimum commissions year-round to prevent insurers from steering certain
consumers from their plans.CMS spokesman Aaron Albright declined to comment
about the commission cuts, but said in an emailed statement that,Â â€œWhether
through HealthCare.gov, the call center, navigators, enrollment through an
agent or web broker, consumers have many channels to choose from most
convenient to them."

I thought we were done with this stuff, Tiger Woods. I thought this was
settled. I thought, finally â€”Â _finally_ â€” you had acceptedÂ reality.â€œI played
through a lot of injuries, I played through some situations I probably
shouldnâ€™t have,â€ Tiger said earlier this March, adding that he was taking
things slow and had no timeline for return. â€œI cost myself some
tournamentsâ€¦Iâ€™ve cost myself months and years because of it. Thatâ€™s what
athletes do. They play through pain.â€But now the Masters is almost upon us and
people are starting to wonder if Tigercould make a sneaky appearance. All
signs would suggest â€œno,â€ but thereâ€™s enough reasonable doubt to keep the
flames of the Twitterverse roaring hot.Tiger Woodsâ€™ agent, Mark Steinberg,
said the 14-time major champ was â€œabsolutely notâ€ practicing at Augusta
National last week amid rumours he was, but added to Golf Channel that there
was â€œno further updateâ€ on his general condition.Â Heâ€™s still yet to officially
withdraw from Masters field, which is getting everyone excited, so much so
that now people are interpreting this â€œcoming homeâ€ tweet as a cryptic
foreshadowing of an imminent Augusta return.Coming back to my roots. So Cal!!
https://t.co/p1qehnervUâ€” Tiger Woods (@TigerWoods) March 29, 2016We know that
he can hit a few nine irons,Â chips, and putts, so my pet theory is that heâ€™s
angling to make an appearance at the Mastersâ€™ annual par-3 contest. Even that
seems unlikely, though. I donâ€™t know if Tiger is planning on coming back, but
I know for sure that he absolutely shouldnâ€™t.Tiger fans right now
pic.twitter.com/NzQmWsbum3â€” No Laying Up (@NoLayingUp) March 31, 2016Itâ€™s easy
to forget in the constant furor that surrounds Tiger, but the guy is still
only 40 years-old. Not a young gun by any stretch of the imagination, but he
still conceivably has 10 years of PGA Tour golf left in him.Â Even if he
doesnâ€™t even think about touching a club for the rest of this year and targets
a return in 2017, he could still playÂ the equivalent of three average-length
NFL careers.Tiger WoodsÂ canâ€™t beat a back injury; the only way he can succeed
is if he fully heals and figures out a way to prevent further injury going
forward. And to do that, he needs to go slow. Really slow.Making a dramatic
return at theÂ Masters may be tempting for Woods, but he needs to remember that
time is on his side more than he realizes. IfÂ he truly cares about closing-out
his career on a high note, he needs to have the strength to say no next week.

Whether you think _Batman vÂ Superman: Dawn of Justice _is _a hot, jumbled
mess_ or worthy of _one of the greatest opening weekends in movie history_,
thereâ€™s one thing we can all agree on: the two main superheroes got, like,
ripped.Ben Affleck bulked up bigger than any on-screen Batman yet, while the
already-buffÂ Henry Cavill got even _more_ muscular for his second turn as
Superman.â€œThis isnâ€™t the Adam West Days. You canâ€™t just roll out of bed and
put the suit on,â€ Affleck _said during a red-carpet premier_ for the film.
â€œAudiences expect you to look like a superhero. And that took me about a year
of training to do.â€From Westâ€™s Batman to Affleckâ€™s version of the Dark Knight,
and from George Reeveâ€™s 1950s portrayal of Superman to Cavilâ€™s Man of Steel
today, every on-screen iteration of both heroes seems to get bigger and
brawnier.Hereâ€™s a look at how Batman and Superman have bulked up over the
years:According to _Muscle & Fitness_, Cavill bulked up to about 190
pounds for his Superman debut in 2013'sÂ _Man of Steel_, cutting down to about
6% body fat. Before filming the shirtless scenes, Cavil pushed his body fat to
3-4%  
Before stepping into Christopher Reevesâ€™ red boots for this revival of the
original Superman series, Brandon Routh wasnâ€™t big on lifting weights. Â â€œWhen
youâ€™re new to it, your body really can put on a lot more muscle easier the
first time,â€ Routh _told Menâ€™s Fitness._Â He said that he â€œput on 20 to 25
pounds in about five to six months.â€When Tom Welling brought Supermanâ€™s
younger days to the small screen, the TV dramaâ€™s producers made sure he stayed
swoon-worthy. Welling wasnâ€™t allowed to gain weight, according to a profile in
_Seventeen_, and couldnâ€™t even play pickup basketball. "What would happen if I
got a black eye?" Welling said.Credit Dean Cainâ€™s physique in the '90s TV
series to his days as a football player. Cain played defensive back at
Princeton before signing with the Buffalo Bills in the late '80s. But a knee
injury prevented Cain from ever playing in the NFL, which led him to
acting.Filmmakers behind the classic _Superman_ series first thought
Christopher Reeve wasÂ â€œtoo young and maybe even too skinnyâ€ for the role,
_according to one documentary_. Reeve recalledÂ wearing a giant shetland
sweater to his audition to hide his â€œstring beanâ€ physique. After landing the
role, he hit the weights and ate four times a day, mixing a meat-heavy diet
with vitamin pills.In this TV series, Reevesâ€™ barrel-chested Superman
displayed a classic physique that seems almost quaint by todayâ€™s superhero
standards. But even he had help, using a padded suit that augmentedÂ his size,
according to _Den of Geek__._At 43, Ben Affleck is the oldest actor to debut
as Batman. Heâ€™s also the biggest. He points to daily 6 a.m. workouts and the
do-or-die pressure that comes with donning the iconic cowl. â€œI knew the camera
was going to be looking at me, and the guillotine was there so I knew I had to
be ready,â€ said Affleck, who claimed he gained 20 pounds of muscle for the
role.When cast as Batman, Christian Bale weighed 130 pounds, thanks to a
previous role as an insomniac, _Today__ notes_. It took him six months to pack
on 100 pounds before his debut in 2005â€™s _Batman Begins_, which ended up being
_too_ much muscle for director Christopher Nolan.â€œ(I was) eating, just eating
like crazy, just trying to put on pounds and pounds and pounds,â€ Bale told
_Sci-Fi Wire_. "I actually went â€¦ way overboard. By the time I arrived in
England, you know, Chris kind of looked at me in shock and kind of went, 'God,
you're like some grizzly bear.'â€In sequels to Tim Burton's _Batman_ movies,
both of these actors inherited the rubber-muscled Batsuits made famous by
Michael Keaton. And while both filled them out just fine, we just remember one
thing: the nipples. Their Batsuits had nipples. Why?Tim Burtonâ€™s modernization
of Batman for the big screen debuted a suit with rubberized muscles, requiring
little of the wearer's physique. Keaton had played mostly comedic roles before
_Batman_, and didnâ€™t bulk up much, if at all, for the role. Action hero
Sylvester Stallone later lamented Keatonâ€™s Batsuit, which he said ushered in a
new era. â€œThe action movies changed radically when it became possible to
Velcro your muscles on,â€ _he told the __Los Angeles Times_.Laugh all you want
at Westâ€™s goofyÂ take on Batman. But at 6 feet 2 andÂ 210 pounds, Westâ€™s
physique was the closest to that of Batmanâ€™s in the comic books, according to
_an analysis by __the Economist_. And while his spandex Batsuit wasnâ€™t the
most flattering, West _didnâ€™t look too shabby underneath_.

Chipotle Mexican Grill said Wednesday it has applied for a trademarkÂ for

applied to a wide variety of foods," said Chris Arnold, a Chipotle
spokesman.ShopHouse, a Southeast Asian food chain, opened in 2013. Last year,

pizza, beyond its initial locations in Denver and Boulder, Colo.Shares of
