from an E.coli outbreak and other health safety issues that slowed its
business much of last year.In February,Â Chipotle, based in Denver,Â reported
its worst quarterly performance as a publicly traded company. ItsÂ fourth-
quarter net income fell 44% year-over-year toÂ $67.9 million. And same-store
sales were down 14.6%.Chipotle didn't elaborate on its plans. With Americans'
everlastingÂ love of burgers, the gourmet burger market has gotten crowded in
recent years, with new competitors hoping to emulate the success of Five Guys
Burgers and FriesÂ and Shake Shack.U.S. burger restaurants generated about $73
billion in sales in 2014, according to trade publicationÂ _Burger Business,
_citing data from food industry research firmÂ CHD Expert_._Â Burger joints
account for 7.4% of all U.S. restaurantsÂ nationally, it said.Shake Shack,
founded by restaurateur Danny Meyer, said earlier this month its fourth-
quarter sales roseÂ 49.2% to $49.3 million. Same-restaurant sales, reported by
the locations that have been openÂ at least a year, climbed 11%.By emphasizing
its use ofÂ organic produceÂ and naturally raised meat, Chipotle's popularity
and sales have surged since its founding in 1993. But the companyÂ has been
under investigation since October last year after an E. coli outbreak sickened
more than 50 people in 11 states. A second outbreak of a different strain of
E. coli in December affected five people in three states. Health officials
also linked a Chipotle location in the Boston area in December to a norovirus
outbreak in the region.The outbreaks forced Chipotle to temporarily close
multiple locations and implement new safety standards and food-handling
procedures.Â The Centers for Disease Control and PreventionÂ on Feb. 1 ended its
investigation into the E. coli incidents at Chipotle, saying the outbreaks

The Associated Press is refuting aÂ historian's assertion that the news agency
collaborated with the Nazi regime in the 1930s and supplied American
newspapers with material from the Third Reich'sÂ propaganda ministry.In an
article published in the academic journalÂ _Studies in Contemporary History,
_historian Harriet Scharnberg asserts that the AP was able to continue
operating under the Nazi regime, long after other news agencies had been
forced out, by cooperating with the fascist GermanÂ government.The AP agreed to
abide by the Nazi "editor's law," forbidding any publication "calculated to
weaken the strength of the Reich abroad or at home," according toÂ _The
Guardian,Â _which first reported on the research Wednesday. The news agency
also hired reporters who worked in the Nazi party's propaganda division,
including photographer Franz Roth, who was in the propaganda unit of the SS
and whose photos were approved by Hitler himself.ScharnbergÂ also contends the
AP allowed the use of its photographs in antisemitic propaganda, including the
publications "The Sub-Human" and "The Jews in the USA."By working with the
Nazis, the AP helped that totalitarian regime "portray a war of extermination
as a conventional war," the historianÂ said in the interview with _The
Guardian_. For example, Roth's photos following the 1941 Nazi invasion of Lviv
in western Ukraine focused on the atrocities carried out by Soviet troops
before the arrival of the Nazis, and ignored the violence of the German forces
against the Jewish residents."The pictures played their part in disguising the
true character of the war led by the Germans," Scharnberg said. "Which events
were made visible and which remained invisible in AP's supply of pictures
followed German interests and the German narrative of the war."The Associated
Press said in a statement that Scharnberg's research "describes both
individuals and their activities before and during the war that were unknown
to AP." The news agency says it is conducting a review "to further our
understanding of the period.""AP rejects the suggestion that it collaborated
with the Nazi regime at any time," the statement goes on to say. "Rather, the
AP was subjected to pressure from the Nazi regime from the period of Hitler's
coming to power in 1933 until the AP's expulsion from Germany in 1941. AP
staff resisted the pressure while doing its best to gather accurate, vital and
objective news for the world in a dark and dangerous time."The AP removed
Roth'sÂ photographs from its website after the study's publication,Â _The
GuardianÂ _reported. The news agency is looking into photographs credited to
Roth after Scharnberg's "new-to-us reference to him," an AP spokesman told
_The New York TimesÂ _.A German photo agency that was a subsidiary of AP
Britain produced the images from Nazi Germany and the territory it occupied,
and "U.S. newspapers were supplied with some of these images through the
German subsidiary," the AP's statement says. Images that came from the Nazi
government or its propaganda wings wereÂ "labeled as such in their captions or
photo credits."The news agency also says that it had no control over the use
of its photo archive after the U.S. declared war on Germany on Dec. 11, 1941,
and the regime expelled all foreign news organizations.

By now, youâ€™re likely very familiar with theÂ top fiveÂ presidential candidates:
RepublicansÂ Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and John Kasich, and Democrats Hillary
Clinton and Bernie Sanders.But there are many other candidatesÂ running for
president, but given their lack of clout and media time, itâ€™s likely youâ€™ve
never heard of them.USA TODAYÂ College caught up withÂ six candidates who want
their voices to count in the 2016 election.**Party:Â **Democrat  
**Website:** http://www.lloydkelsoforpresident.com  
**Platform:**The North Carolina lawyer, the only child of middle-class parents who dropped out of school in eighth grade, comes fromÂ humble roots. While his candidacy has garnered little coverage, Kelso has big plansÂ if elected.â€œI think we need to expose our legislators for all the buying and selling thatâ€™s going on in Washington,â€ Kelso tells USA TODAY College. â€œThey need to be exposed for what they are: political prostitutes. We need to end that and make the government by and for the people again.â€Committed to his cause, Kelso says he has spent 20% of his net worth on the campaign.â€œIâ€™m a patriot,â€ heÂ says. â€œI believe in helping the United States of America. And Iâ€™ve shown that by going out there on my own and trying to make this happen. Iâ€™m fighting for Americans and their futures. I have comprehensive solutions to Americaâ€™s problems.â€**Party: **Democrat  
**Website:Â **http://adamsforpresident.com  
**Platform:**If his name alone didnâ€™t give it away, Adams is a distant cousin of former president John Adams. The formerÂ lawyer and college professor is from New York, but now lives in New Mexico. Oh, and he loves chess.â€œI think I could give the grand master a run for his money,â€ Adams says.But chess isnâ€™t the only arena for which Adams has strategies. If elected president, he says heÂ wouldÂ combat extremism, fight for the environment and champion equal rights.â€œIâ€™m running for president because Iâ€™m tired of fear mongering and hate mongering,â€ Adams says. â€œI think thereâ€™s nothing more patriotic than stepping forward to run for the president when your country is in need.â€**Party:** Democrat  
**Website:Â **http://www.electhenryhewes2016.com  
**Platform:**The publisher and civic consultant from New York is not a political rookie; he ran for mayor of New York City in 1989 and for U.S. Senate in 1994.Seemingly laid back â€” he was the only one of many at a C-SPAN â€œlesser-known candidatesâ€ forum in New Hampshire to forgo a jacket for an argyle sweater â€” Hewes left the Republican party to become aÂ Democrat in 2007 because heÂ opposedÂ the Iraq war and use of drones. But he retains his pro-life position.â€œMy pro-life position is something that resonates,â€ Hewes says. â€œThatâ€™s the primary ethos of my campaign.â€Hewes says he was among the first Democrats to adopt a strong and clearÂ anti-police violence platform.â€œPolice violence concerns young people and I donâ€™t really see Bernie Sanders or Hillary Clinton talking about it except for in really abstract generalities. Thereâ€™s no discussion,â€ Hewes says. â€œI make the point that Barack Obama suddenly discovered police violence against black people after Ferguson.â€**Party:**Â Socialist Party USA  
**Website:**Â www.rev16.us**Platform:**The tattooed, T-shirt-wearing former national co-chair of the Socialist Party USA once calledÂ Bernie Sandersâ€™ record â€œimperialist.â€â€œBernie Sanders seems to advocate more of a social democracy,â€ Soltysik says. â€œItâ€™s an expanded social safety net based upon the welfare state, maybe more like what we see in Scandinavia, whereas socialism starts with worker control over the means of production, community control and full democratic participation. They are very different things.â€Soltysik says capitalist societies simplyÂ can notÂ fosterÂ true equality. And now, more than ever, he thinks change is imperative.â€œWith the science of climate change, we really donâ€™t have time to spend on reforming capitalism or greening capitalismâ€ Soltysik says.Â â€œThe planet is literally telling us it cannot hold a capitalist society or economic system. Change has to happen now.â€**Party:** Democrat  
**Website:** http://www.stewartforliberty.com  
**Platform:**The snowboarding entrepreneur â€” reportedly theÂ first to register forÂ the New Hampshire presidential ballot â€” calls himself a â€œDemocratic libertarian,â€ which essentially means heÂ identifies as a Democrat but does not consider himselfÂ progressive.Instead, he championsÂ a small government and says he would like to see theÂ Democratic Party to return toÂ Thomas Jeffersonâ€™s and James Madisonâ€™s original design.â€œElecting a libertarian is exactly what (Thomas) Jefferson wanted for this Republic,â€ Stewart says. â€œIt allows conservatives to do their thing, liberals can do their thing.â€He hopes his policies stimulate the economy and allow for more personal freedoms.â€œIâ€™m certainly the only presidential candidate that snowboards,â€ Stewart says. â€œMaybe ever. Itâ€™s a beautiful activity.â€**Party: **Republican  
**Website: **http://andymartinforpresident.com  
**Platform:**Martin, credited with starting the birther movement â€” which erroneously claimed President Obama was born in KenyaÂ â€” has spent much of the last decade researching and publishing controversial material on ourÂ current commander in chief.â€œItâ€™s kind of like Draculaâ€™s heart. They keep putting a stake through it and I keep on moving,â€ he says.Martin is also a perennial presidential candidate â€“ he ran for president in 2000 and 2012.â€œMy basic view is that I have a record of experience and proven competence, and Iâ€™m a Republican,â€ Martin says. â€œI have a solid record in politics. Iâ€™ve been on Capitol Hill. Iâ€™ve been overseas to Iraq.â€

Guidelines the Food and Drug Administration issued Wednesday could expand
womenâ€™s access to an abortion-inducing pill in states that have sought to
limit its use.The new guidelinesÂ strike directly against laws passed by
several statesÂ â€”Â including North Dakota, Ohio and TexasÂ â€”Â that require doctors
to adhere to 16-year-old FDA regulations. Several other states have tried to
limit use of the drug, but their efforts faceÂ legal challenges around the
country.The new rules allow women to use the medication for 70 days after the
start of their most recent menstrual period, up from 49 days under the
previous guidelines. The agency also lowered the dosage of the medication,
called mifepristone, from 600 milligrams to 200 milligrams, and made it easier
for women to get a prescription for the pill.The previousÂ requirements had
been in place since 2000, but the FDA said in a statement that more recent
scientificÂ data showed that it was time for the update."After reviewing the
supplemental application, the agency determined that Mifeprex is safe and
effective when used to terminate a pregnancy in accordance with revised
labeling," the statement said, referring to the brand name of the
drug.Abortion rightsÂ groups hailedÂ the move as a long-needed dose of common
sense given the history of the medication.President Ilyse Hogue of NARAL Pro-
Choice America, a network of groups dedicated to protecting and expanding
reproductive freedoms, said the abortion pillÂ has provedÂ through decades to be
safer than Tylenol, Viagra and other common medications used around the
world."Unlike state and federal anti-choice laws that restrict a women's
access to an abortion, the FDA decision to make mifepristone available to more
women in this country is based on science that shows this usage is safe and
medically sound," Hogue said. "It'sÂ high time to put medicine back into the
hands of medical professionals and take it out of politicians' hands."Abortion
opponents disagreed, arguing thatÂ lengthening the time that women can use the
pill will lead to more "incomplete" abortions and more risks to mothers.
President Troy Newman of Operation Rescue, a Kansas-based anti-abortion group,
said pharmaceutical companies will useÂ the FDA's decisionÂ to persuadeÂ more
"vulnerable pregnant women" to use the "unpredictable" drug."The FDA should be
more about protecting the public from exploitative and predatory uses of drugs
rather than pandering to Planned Parenthood and the rest of the Abortion
Cartel," Newman said in a statement.Ohio's lawmakers had passed the
requirement to follow FDA guidelines in 2004, but the law didn't take effect
until 2011 because of a court order.Â From 2010 to 2011, when the law went into
effect, surgical abortions dropped to by more than 75% to 1,234Â fromÂ 5,862,
according to state health department records.By 2014, non-surgical abortions
including the abortion pillÂ were 5% of all procedures, compared to 13.2% in
2004.Women's Med in Sharonville, Ohio, which ceased surgical abortion in 2014
after losing a legal battle with the state, still provides medication
abortions. But itÂ has usedÂ methotrexate injections rather than the abortion
pill because administeringÂ Mifeprex according to the old FDA guidelines was
too expensive and time-consuming, said Dr. Martin Haskell, the clinic's
owner.But Wednesday's FDA decision gives Haskell another cost-effective
alternative for abortions â€” one heÂ said heÂ will consider offering to patients
in the future.â€œTheyâ€™re finally catching up with reality,â€ Dr. Franz Theard, a
physician who operates Hilltop Womenâ€™s Reproductive Clinic in El Paso, said of
the FDA. Texas law requiresÂ pregnant women seeking abortions to first fill out
paperwork, get an ultrasound and receive counseling.They return 72 hours later
to take mifiprex. Then they are sent home where they take a second drug,
misoprostol, all in keeping with the FDA's 2000 guidelines because state law
prohibits off-label use of drugs that can be used for abortions.â€œWe tell them,
â€˜Donâ€™t go to work,â€™ â€ because the procedure causes cramping, Theard said. But
it is much less invasive than a surgical abortion and so trouble-free for some
women that almost a third don't return for a recommended follow-up after the
abortion.In Arizona, where a court order has put its state law similar to Ohio
and Texas on hold, lawmakers sent a new bill to the governor last week
requiringÂ abortion-inducing medications be administered according to FDA
protocol that was in effect as of Dec. 31.The legislation is sitting on Gov.
Doug Ducey's desk,Â awaiting his signature or veto. Bill proponents are
scrambling to figure out what to do."They will not be following the (current)
FDA recommendations if this bill becomes law," said stateÂ Rep. Randall Friese,
a Tucson Democrat and a surgeon who asked Ducey to veto the bill.Â "I'm hoping
this information makes it to the governor's office to help him
decide."_Contributing: Jessie Balmert, The Cincinnati Enquirer;Â Marty
Schladen, El Paso Times;Â Alia Beard Rau, The Arizona Republic. Follow Alan
Gomez on Twitter:Â @alangomez_

Bill Cosby marked a small â€” but onlyÂ temporary â€”Â legal victory in Los Angeles
on Wednesday. This was 24 hours after he marked a legal loss in a different
case on Tuesday in Los Angeles.The two cases involve civil defamation and
sexual battery lawsuits filed against him by two of the five-dozen women who
have accused him of drugging and/or raping them in episodes dating back
decades.Meanwhile, Cosby is fighting aÂ criminal sexual-assault case in
Pennsylvania, currently on hold while he appeals pre-trial rulings.On
Wednesday, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Craig Karlan ruled thatÂ Cosby will
not have to immediately answer more questions under oath in a deposition
sought by Judy Huth, a California woman who says Cosby forced her into a sex
act at the Playboy Mansion in Los Angeles around 1974, when she was 15.The
ruling gives Cosby moreÂ time to resolve the criminal case before answering
more questions from Huth and her attorney, leading Cosby legal foe Gloria
Allred, who represents dozens of his accusers.But the judge warned he's not
freezing the Huth sexual battery case indefinitely.Â "I don't want this case to
be here three, four, five years from now. That's not justice," Karlan
said.Attorney Gloria Allred at the Santa Monica Courthouse on March 30, 2016
in Santa Monica, Calif.Â (Photo: Frederick M. Brown, Getty Images)Cosby
attorneyÂ Christopher Tayback said in court he expects Cosby to be exonerated
in the criminal case "inÂ six months," according to the Associated Press.Cosby
lawyers said they were pleased with the ruling."The court recognized the
dilemma faced by a defendant who must choose between defending civil
litigation by providing testimony on one hand, and losing the case by
asserting the constitutional right to remain silent on the other hand, and
rightly issued an order eliminating the necessity of such an untenable
choice," said Cosby lawyer Monique Pressley in a statement.But Allred said she
was pleased she won the right to proceed with third-party depositions in the
Huth case, including taking testimony from 90-year-old Hugh Hefner and other
women who have accused Cosby. And Cosby is not off the hook, she warned."He is
still under order to be deposed so it's going to happen; it's just a question
of when," she told USA TODAY. "The judge said he wants to move our lawsuit
along, to 2017."Janice Dickinson on March 29, 2016 in Los Angeles.Â (Photo:
Nick Ut, AP)On Tuesday,Â Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Debre Katz Weintraub
ruled that ex-supermodel and Cosby accuser Janice Dickinson's defamation suit
against him can proceed."Victory!" Dickinson shouted, alongside her attorney
Lisa Bloom (Allred's daughter), after the hearing. Dickinson says Cosby
drugged and raped her in a Lake Tahoe hotel in 1982, and then defamed her by
denying her accusation.Cosby had sought to have Dickinson's suit dismissed;
he's already been successful in getting another of the defamation suits
against him dismissed.But the judgeÂ ruled that a jury could determine the
credibility of Dickinson's claims and whether a statement by Cosby's former
lawyer branding her a liar was legally defamatory.Pressley said in a statement
Tuesday that the Cosby team was happy that some of bases for the Dickinson
lawsuit were dismissed, butÂ still maintains the entire suitÂ should be thrown
out and is considering an appeal.

Most people would to love to wipe the mosquitoes that spread the Zika virus
off the face of the Earth.But fighting these nasty little biters â€” a species
called Aedes aegyptiÂ â€”Â is harder than most people imagine, experts say. USA
TODAY's Liz Szabo talked to mosquito control experts to find out why this
species is such a formidable foe.**Q. What makes these mosquitoes
different?**A. They love humansÂ â€” but not in a good way.Like the dog, the
Aedes aegypti has evolved to live among people. Yet while dogsÂ seek human
approval, and willingly work for us, the mosquitoes that spread Zika simply
wantÂ our blood.Although theÂ Aedes aegypti originated in jungles, breeding in
tree holes or in water that collected in leaves,Â it now thrives in ourÂ homes,
according to theÂ World Health Organization."It's a domestic mosquito," said
biologistÂ Laura Harrington,Â Â professor andÂ chairwomanÂ of the entomology
department atÂ Cornell UniversityÂ in New York.Â  "You won't find it in places
without humans."FemaleÂ mosquitoes need the protein and other nutrients in
blood to make eggs.The Aedes aegypti produces more eggs and lives longer after
dining on our blood than when they feed on other animals.All mosquitoes
release a numbing substance in their saliva, so that people don't feel them
bite, Harrington said. They also release chemicals that prevent blood from
clotting, so that they can suck longer. The Aedes aegypti produces a less
painful bite than other mosquitoes, so it's possible that they produce more of
this numbing substance, Harrington said.The Aedes aegyptiÂ "hones in on the
volatile chemicals that come off our skin," said Grayson Brown, a professor of
entomology at the University of Kentucky who recently returned from a trip to
Brazil to study way to protect people from Zika. "If you're sitting next to a
monkey, it's much more likely to bite you than the monkey."**Q. How does this
mosquito exploit human weaknesses?**A.Â Unlike the mosquitoes that spread
malaria, which breed in depressions in the ground or swamps, the Aedes aegypti
prefers to lay eggs in our man-made containers and even rests under our beds
or in our closets. It prefers clean water, like the rain water that people in
developing nations store in jars outside their homes, Harrington said.The
Aedes aegypti also has adapted to live among human waste. It thrives inÂ the
trash-strewn streets of crowded, impoverished cities of developing countries,
breeding in the water that collects in old tires, plastic cups and bottle
caps, according to the WHO. Other favorite locations: construction sites and
clogged rain gutters.Females â€” the only ones that biteÂ â€”Â can also lay eggs in
the "microbial stew" found in septic tanks, toilet tanksÂ and shower
stalls.**Q. Why isÂ this mosquito so good at spreading disease?**A. Several
features help the Aedes aegypti spread Zika as well as other diseases,
including yellow fever, dengue, chikungunya and West Nile virus.While most
mosquitoes feed on blood only when they're laying eggs, feeding on plant
nectar the rest of the time, Harrington said the Aedes aegypti feeds on blood
almost every day. Female are infectious throughout their lives.The Aedes
aegypti is an "aggressive daytime biting mosquito," according to the WHO.
Although it's most active at dawn and dusk, it also can bite at night in well-
lit homes. Females mount "sneak attacks," approaching people from behind and
biting ankles and elbows, where they're less likely to be noticed and
slapped.Instead of taking lots of blood from one bite, these mosquitoes take
multiple sips from multiple bites, which increases the number of people that
females can infect, according to the WHO.**Q. How dangerous are
mosquitoes?**There are more than 3,000 species of mosquito in the world,
including 176 in the USA, according to the American Mosquito Control
Association. Together, they spread diseases that kill 725,000 people a year,
according to Gates Notes, the personal blog of Bill Gates, co-founder of
Microsoft and theÂ Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Malaria alone kills
438,000 people a year, according to the WHO."There's nothing good about
mosquitoes," Â Fauci said. "People say, 'But mosquitoes feed the birds.' I say,
'Give the birds bird seed.'
title: Bold Zika mosquitoes love to hang with humans

Zika can linger months longer in the blood of pregnant women than in other
patientsÂ infected with the virus, according to a report published online
Wednesday.Although most people clear the virus from their blood within a week,
one pregnantÂ woman's bloodÂ tested positive for Zika for 10 weeks after being
infected,Â according to a report inÂ _The New England Journal of Medicine_. The
33-year-old woman, who was infected with Zika while traveling in Central
America when she was 11 weeks pregnant,Â only tested negative afterÂ the
pregnancy ended. She hadÂ an abortion 21 weeks into the pregnancy, after tests
showed extensive brain damage to her fetus.Doctors can't say for sure why the
woman harbored Zika in her blood for so long, in spite of having developed
antibodies against the virus.Although antibodies protect the body from foreign
invaders such as viruses, the immune system doesn't usually attack a fetus.
That could have allowed the Zika virus to survive and multiply in the fetus'
body. Authors of the study found large amounts of Zika virus in the fetus'
brain, as well as in the placenta and umbilical cord.Viruses coming from the
fetus or placentaÂ could have reinfected the motherÂ throughout her pregnancy,
said study coauthorÂ Rita Driggers,Â medical director of maternal and fetal
medicine atÂ Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. That might also explain
why the woman's blood tests for Zika were negative after the pregnancy ended
and there was no longer a source of virus in her body.It's also possible that
the womanÂ cleared the Zika virus from her blood just as quickly as others, but
that genetic material from the virus remained behind, said Peter Hotez,
director of the National School of Tropical Medicine at the Baylor College of
Medicine in Houston, who was not involved in the new study.Scientists don't
know whetherÂ the woman's case is unique or if other pregnant women would also
test positive for Zika throughout pregnancy,Â said Anthony Fauci, director of
the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, who was not
involved in the new study. The only way to know for sure would be to take
blood samples from many pregnant women throughout their pregnancies."You can't
get all the answers from one case," Fauci said.Doctors in Brazil are currently
conducting large studies of pregnant women, comparing those infected with Zika
to those who are uninfected, to see how infection affects the health of the
women and their babies.The woman's case could make other pregnant women with
Zika infections uneasy.The woman, who originally hailed from Finland but lived
in Washington,Â had ultrasounds during the 13th, 16th and 17th weeks of
pregnancy. When the results were normal, the woman's doctors reassured her the
her fetus was developing normally, Driggers said.During the 19th week of
pregnancy, however, an ultrasound showed abnormal brain anatomy in her fetus.
The next week, doctors performed an MRI, a sophisticated scan that provides
more detail than an ultrasoundÂ butÂ doesn't involve radiation. TheÂ MRI found
that much of the fetus' brain had wasted away, according to the
study."Normally, you would expect the brain to fill up the skull," said
Driggers, who is alsoÂ an associate professor of gynecology and obstetrics at
the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore. "There was fluid
around the brain, filling up the spaces where the brain wasn't."Zika has been
strongly linked to microcephaly,Â a birth defect in which babies are born with
abnormally small heads and, in most cases, incomplete brain development. In
this study, the fetus' brain didn't meet the standard definition of
microcephaly.Driggers said her studyÂ shows that that fetuses can have
extensive brain damage, even if their brains are normal size.Doctors should
consider performing an MRI "if there are any doubts about the diagnosis," said
study coauthor Adre du Plessis, director of Childrenâ€™s National Health
Systemâ€™s Fetal Medicine Institute and chief of the fetal and transitional
medicine division.But it's not practical to order an MRI for every pregnant
woman,Â saidÂ Laura Riley, a spokeswoman for theÂ American College of
Obstetricians and Gynecologists.That's because the procedures can cost
thousands of dollars. Also, there are relatively few experts who specialize in
interpreting the results of MRIs in fetuses, which aren't commonly
performed.Even the most sophisticated tests won't answer all of a pregnant
woman's questions, Riley said. It's possible that babies born after being
exposed to Zika could have subtle problems that aren't obvious on imaging
tests."MRI may give you a better look at brain structure, but nothing is
availableÂ to tell you about the brainâ€™s function," Riley said.

Fitbit fanatics who can't stop competing for steps have a new measurement to
obsess over:Â lowest resting heart rate. And people in Hawaii, Massachusetts,
South Dakota and New York are the clear winners.Resting heart rate refers to
the number of times your heart beats per minute when youâ€™re awake and relaxed.
A lower heart rate can indicateÂ a higher fitness level and better overall
cardiovascular health. Basically, your heart doesn't have to work as hard, or
pump as often, to do its job.If youâ€™re very fit, a resting heart rate could be
around 40, according to the American Heart Association.Â A less active person
might have a heart rate between 60 and 100."Hawaii is definitely the clear
winner, with Massachusetts over 0.8 beats per minute higher," Fitbit says,
based off of anonymous data it's collected from users. "Once you get to New
York, the rest of the states are really close in terms of resting heart rate,
essentially tied. By the end of the list, Mississippi is almost 2.7 beats per
minute higher than Hawaii on average."  
The association says, in addition to fitness, a number of other factors can
play into your resting heart rate. When temperatures and humidity go up, the
heart pumps a little more blood so your heart rate will go up a few beats per
minute. "If youâ€™re stressed, anxious or 'extraordinarily happy or sad,' your
emotions can raise your pulse," the association writes on its website.Fitbit
found that 50-90 beats per minutes is the typical resting heart range for
adult Fitbit users around the world. The company's data also shows that being
thin doesnâ€™t imply heart health.On average, underweight Fitbit users have
similar resting heart rates to overweight and obese users. The association
backs that up: "Body size usually doesnâ€™t usually change pulse. If youâ€™re very
obese, you might see a higher resting pulse than normal, but usually not more
than 100."Fitbit BlazeÂ (Photo: Fitbit)"If you're really very overweight, your
heart rate has to be higher to support the extra tissue," says Dr. Melvin
Scheinman, professor of medicine at University of California, San Francisco
Medical Center. "But you have to be very, very obese."Low heart rate can,
however, indicate heart disease. "If you have a slow heart rate and you feel
fine, there is no reason to worry about it," Scheinman says. "It you have
sypmtoms like fatigue, dizziness and blackout spells, then you should see a
physician."**Here are the states with the lowest resting heart rates (the
number indicates the average number of beats per minute when resting)

A top political aide to Alabama Gov. Robert Bentley is resigningÂ a week after
he apologized for making inappropriate remarks to her but denied the pair were
engaged in an affair.Rebekah Caldwell Mason said in a statement Wednesday that
she is resigning as Bentleyâ€™s senior policy analyst, theÂ _Montgomery
Advertiser_ reports.Â The decision comes a week after Bentleyâ€™s contriteÂ news
conference in whichÂ he apologized to hisÂ family and Masonâ€™s for his
behavior.Mason said she would no longer be paid from the governor's political
campaign or the Alabama Council for Excellent Government,Â a private entity
created to support Bentley's policies."My only plans are to focus my full
attention on my precious children and my husband who I love dearly," the
statement said. Â "They are the most important people in my life. Thank you for
your prayers for our family.â€Mason had served as Bentleyâ€™s senior policy
adviser since January. Mason, a former television news anchor in Bentleyâ€™s
hometown of Tuscaloosa, signed on as spokeswoman for the little-known
legislatorâ€™s longshot bid for governor in 2010. She worked as the governorâ€™s
communications adviser before leaving to work on his 2014 re-election.The
Alabama Ethics Commission appears to be preparing to investigateÂ allegations
surrounding Bentley and Mason.The commission informed the state auditor it has
assigned case numbers stemming from an auditor's reportÂ last week. That
reported summarizedÂ allegations that the pairÂ were having an affair and may
have misused state resources or broken state laws, theÂ _Montgomery Advertiser_
reported.Â Bentley andÂ Mason have denied the allegations.The commission saysÂ it
willÂ assignÂ a special agentÂ in the "near future"Â to conduct an investigation
into the complaints, the newspaper reported, quoting from a commission letter
to the auditor.Central to the allegations are recently releasedÂ audio excerpts
in which the governor engagesÂ in sexually charged talk with the
staffer.Republican Gov. Robert Bentley, shown in a 2014 file photo, listens to
a phone call as Rebekah Mason, right, announces his win for Alabama governor,
in Montgomery, Ala.Â (Photo: Brynn Anderson, AP)â€œI love you. I love to talk to
you,â€ the governor says to Mason onÂ the tapes. â€œBaby, let me tell you what
weâ€™re going to have to start doing, weâ€™re going to have to start locking the
door. If we are going to do what we did the other day, we are going to have to
start locking the door.â€The tapes were recorded two years agoÂ by Dianne
Bentley, the governor's former wife, who divorced him last year. The
conversation, in which only the governor's voice is heard, was reportedly
capturedÂ on her cellphone, which she left behindÂ in a room atÂ the couplesâ€™
beach home, WKRG-TV reported.The case has spurred calls for the governor's
resignationÂ by some state legislators."Much is required for Gov. Bentley to
repair his relationship with the state," said an editorial Tuesday by Al.com,
an Alabama mediaÂ consortium. "If he remains unwilling to provide a full
reckoning, then he should resign."In a new twistÂ in the case, the pastor of
the First Baptist Church of Tuscaloosa confirmed that Bentley andÂ MasonÂ are no
longer members of the church following the release of the audio tapes.Senior
PastorÂ Gil McKee told the Christian News Network that while "church discipline
is a church family matter" he can confirm that both Bentley and Mason are no
longer members of the church.Â "I continue to pray for each of them," he
says.McKee doesÂ not indicate the timing or circumstances of their departure.
Bentley has served as Sunday school teacher and deacon at the church.Perhaps
the most damaging allegations came last week whenÂ former Alabama Law
Enforcement Agency Secretary Spencer Collier, a longtime Bentley ally,Â accused
the governor and stafferÂ of having an affairÂ and charged thatÂ the governor
usedÂ state resources to pursue it.Collier went public one dayÂ after he was
fired by BentleyÂ following a report raising concerns of "possible misuse of
state funds" at ALEA.Collier, who strongly denies the allegation, said Bentley
and Mason were "furious" with him after he submitted an affidavit in an
unrelated case involving the Alabama house speaker, who facesÂ felony ethics
charges for allegedlyÂ using his public positionÂ to benefit his businesses and
clients, theÂ _Advertiser_Â reported.The release of the tapes, in turn, prompted
Bentley's contrite remarksÂ at a news conference.Bentley denied participating
in a â€œphysical, sexual relationshipâ€ but said he made a mistake in judgment
and apologized to his family and the Masons.â€œI made a mistake,â€ Bentley told
reporters. â€œTwo years ago I made a mistake. ...I have apologized many times to
my family. I have apologized to the family of Mrs. Mason. I would now like to
apologize to the people of Alabama. I ask them to forgive me.â€One reporter
asked Bentley if he was in love with Mason, to which he replied, â€œI love many
members of my staff, in fact, all the members of my staff. Do I love some more
than others? Absolutely.â€_Contributing: Brian Lyman, Montgomery (Ala.)

Donald Trump drew a wave of immediateÂ rebukes from abortion rights advocates
and opponentsÂ Wednesday after saying that women should face "some form" of
punishmentÂ for abortion should the procedure be made illegal in the U.S.Trump
later issued a statement clarifying his position, sayingÂ that, if abortion is
banned, "the doctor or any other person performing this illegal act upon a
woman would be held legally responsible, not the woman."But that was after his
earlier comments sparked widespread outrage, bringing about what is rarely
seen in American politics: advocates on both sides of a hot-button issue
vehemently denouncing the same remarks.â€œMr. Trumpâ€™s comment today is
completely out of touch with the pro-life movement and even more with women
who have chosen such a sad thing as abortion,â€ said Jeanne Mancini, president
of the March for Life Education and Defense Fund.Â â€œNo pro-lifer would ever
want to punish a woman who has chosen abortion. This is against the very
nature of what we are about. We invite a woman who has gone down this route to
consider paths to healing, not punishment.''Ken Blackwell, senior fellow at
the Family Research Council, said Trump's comments underscored the candidate's
"lack of any in-depth of involvement with the pro-life movement.''"We have
always considered the baby and mother as victims in abortion,'' Blackwell
said. "He (Trump) has been all over the map on issues of principle. He has
established a pattern that is indicative of his inexperience.''Pro-choice
NARAL also took aim at Trump, saying the candidate had "hit a new low.''"Not
only is this an unhinged position far from where the American people are, but
it is sure to endanger women were he to become president,'' the group said in
a written statement.Trump made his statement in an interview with MSNBC's
Chris Matthews, declaring himself Â "pro-life.''Pressed on whether punishment
should accompany any law outlawing abortion, Trump said: "The answer is that
there has to be some form of punishment.''"For the woman?'' Matthews
asked."Yes, there has to be some form,'' Trump replied.As the criticism rained
down, the Trump campaign issued a statement from the candidate completely
reversing his earlier remarks.Trump's Republican opponents pounced on the
front-runner's initial statements, suggestingÂ Trump was out of touch.Texas
Sen. Ted Cruz, Trump's main rival for the GOP nomination, said in a statement
that Â "Once again Donald Trump has demonstrated that he hasnâ€™t seriously
thought through the issues, and heâ€™ll say anything just to get attention."Ohio
Gov. John Kasich also slammed the New York billionaire, predicting that Trump
wouldn't maintain his position amid the controversy.â€œProbably Donald Trump
will figure out a way to say he didnâ€™t say it, or he was misquoted, or
whatever,â€ Kasich told _MSNBC_.
title: Trump abortion comments spark outrage on both sides

JACKSON, Miss. â€”Â The Senate on Tuesday passed the "Mississippi Church
Protection Act" to allow armed security in churches, concealed carry without a
permit and provide for attemptsÂ to nullify federal regulations and executive
orders that would limit gun rights.There was much debate. Sen. Hillman
Frazier, D-Jackson, waved a sheathed sword and quoted Bible Scripture as he
argued against passage of the bill. Proponents also quoted Scripture, and even
the Five Man Electrical Band â€” "signs, signs, everywhere signs" â€” as they
fended off an amendment to require churches with armed security to post
signs."We don't need to pimp the church for political purposes," Frazier said
as he held an ornate sword at the podium. "If you want to pass gun laws, do
that, but don't use the church."Sen. Sean Tindell, R-Gulfport, spoke for
passage of the bill and said, "This will allow a church to have a sergeant-at-
arms to protect the church body, just like we have (in the Legislature)." He
said church violence such as the shootings in Charleston, S.C., last summer
are prompting such measures.The Senate voted 36-14 to pass an amended version
of House Bill 786, authored by Rep. Andy Gipson, R-Braxton. It now heads back
to the House for more deliberation.The bill would allow churches to create
security programs and designate and train members to carry concealed weapons.
It would provide criminal and legal protections to those serving as church
security.The bill also would allow concealed carry in a holster without a
permit in Mississippi, expandingÂ a measure passed last yearÂ that allowed
concealed carry without a permit in a purse, satchel or briefcase, and another
recent law that allows open carry in public.The bill also seeks to prohibit
Mississippi officials from enforcing any federal agency regulations or
executive orders that would violate the state constitution â€” an attempt to
nullify federal gun restrictions not passed by Congress.Senators argued
whether this last provision would violate the Supremacy Clause of the U.S.
Constitution."Where did you go to law school?" Â Sen. Hob Bryan, D-Amory,Â asked
Tindell during the debate. "Are they telling people there that the Mississippi
constitution trumps federal law? ... You may have been wrong about things
before, but you've never been more wrong than this. This is like arguing
whether the freezing point of water is 32 degrees Fahrenheit. This is
embarrassing, hopeless."But Tindell drew applause from several other lawmakers
when he answered "Yes I do," to a question of whether the state could
challenge federal agency regulations and executive orders not passed by the
representative body of Congress.Shirley Hopkins Davis with the Mississippi
chapter of Moms Demand Action in a statement called the Senate vote a
"dangerous setback" that could dismantle the state's concealed carry permit
system.Gipson, also a pastor, after the House recently passed his bill,Â said:
"I wish we lived in a world where this bill wouldn't be necessary."_Follow
Geoff Pender on Twitter:Â _@GeoffPender
title: Miss. Senate approves concealed carry, guns in church

WASHINGTON â€”Â The Drug Enforcement Administration and Pentagon spent a combined
$86 million on a surveillance aircraft for planned operations in Afghanistan
that never left the ground, a Justice Department review found.Seven years
after the aircraft was purchased to support the so-called Global Discovery
Program, it now rests on jacks in a Delaware hangarÂ and "has never flown in
Afghanistan,'' Justice's inspector general concluded Wednesday in a 59-page
report."The...aircraft, which was originally intended to be completed in
December 2012, has missed every intended delivery date, is not yet complete
and is no longer intended to fly in Afghanistan,'' Justice auditors
found.Since the DEA removed all aviation operations from Afghanistan last
July, the aircraft is now being planned to support operations in the
Caribbean, Central America and South America. The new promised delivery date
is this June.The inspector general called into question millions of dollars
that were either determined to be unauthorized and unsupported for a project
that was originally estimated to cost $22 million. The ATR 42-500, purchased
in 2008, was intended to support counter-narcotics efforts in Afghanistan, and
the Defense Department had agreed to modify the aircraft with "advanced''
surveillance equipment'' to operate in combat zones.As of last February, the
DEA had spent $10.1 million on the failed project, while DOD-related costs
totaled $67.9 million and included funds to modify the aircraft and for the
construction of a hangar at Kabul International Airport."The DOD considered
scrapping aircraft (in 2014)Â because, while the DOD had already expended more
than $65.9 million on the aircraft's modifications, an additional $6 million
was required to repair damages observed during attempts to modify the
aircraft,'' the report concluded. "Yet, at that time, the market value of the
aircraft was only $6 million.''In a written response, the DEA said that it had
collaborated with the Defense Department on successful aircraft modification
projects in the past, but because modification funding for Global Discovery
was being provided largely by the Pentagon, the DEA was limited in its
involvement in the overall modification process."Based upon that previous
experience,'' DEA Deputy Chief Inspector Michael Stanfill wrote, "DEA had no
indication that the Global Discovery modification would encounter significant
delays and problems that ultimately occurred.''In a statement Tuesday, the DEA
said it "welcomes recommendations that make us better.''"DEA agrees that it
can should provide better oversight of its operational funding,'' the agency's
statement read. "We are reviewing policies and procedures to ensure the
limited resources allocated to DEA are utilized in the most responsible and
effective way possible.''The Justice inspector general has referred the
findings to the DOD's inspector general for review.
title: U.S. spent $86 million on plane never flown

Do you have enough money to retire? Thatâ€™s not an easy question to answer, but
there are some ways to tell if youâ€™re on track. Experts like to use the
following methods to determine if you have enough to fund your desired
lifestyle.**â€¢ Crunch the numbers.**Â Map your projected income â€” from personal
assets, earned income, pensions Â and Social Security â€”Â against projected
expenses.Â This is perhaps the most accurate way to determine whether youâ€™re
financially ready. But it will require more than a weekend of number
crunching.Whatâ€™s involved? On the income side, it means calculating how much
youâ€™ll receive from Social Security (and pensions if any); how much income you
can safely withdraw from investment accounts earmarked for retirement (assume
2% to 4% per year); and how much income you might earn from working during
retirement.On the expense side, it means calculating how much youâ€™ll spend on
essential expenses, such as housing, health care, foodÂ and transportation, and
how much youâ€™ll need for discretionary expenses, hobbies, trips, gifts,
etc.This method, though time-consuming, is best for those 10 years or less
away from retirement.**â€¢ Use an income-replacement ratio.**Â Determine what
percentage of your current salary youâ€™d need to generate in retirement to live
comfortably. Generally, advisers say youâ€™ll need to replace 80% of your pre-
retirement income. So, for instance, households that have gross incomes of
$50,000, might need $40,000 of income in retirement.Part of this exercise
requires figuring out what portion of your income will come from whichÂ sources
in retirement.In 2012, the average retiree had aÂ household income of $51,000,
and Social Security accounted for 35.3% of that amount. The rest came from
other sources, such as savings and earned income. So in our example of a
household needing retirement income of $40,000, $14,120Â of itÂ would come from
Social Security and the rest, $25,880, would have to come from savings and
other sources. That means a person would need a nest egg of about $1Â million,
using aÂ withdrawal rate of under 3%,Â to make up the gap.**â€¢ Divide assets by
salary.**Â Divide how much youâ€™ve saved for retirement by your current salary.
To be financially ready for retirement, Fidelity Investments suggests having
10 times your salary saved at retirement, eight times your salary saved by age
60, six times by age 50, Â three times by age 40, and one time by age 30.**â€¢
Use an online calculator.** Fidelity created aÂ toolÂ that lets you determine
how ready you are for retirement. Answering six questions at
https://communications.fidelity.com/pi/2015/retirement/Â gives you a retirement
score to show you how onÂ trackÂ you are.Online calculators can give you a
ballpark estimate.Â (Photo: Getty Images)Other organizations have calculators,
too. Those include: Ballpark E$timate and AARP.Before using any online
retirement calculator, experts suggest considering the following: Many
calculators will give you a ballpark answer, but not necessarily the correct
answer.Â That might be fine if youâ€™re more than 10 years away from retirement,
but less so if youâ€™re not. If youâ€™re close to retirement, there may be no
substitute for using actual income and expense numbers to determine your
readiness, says Chuck Yanikoski, the owner of Still River Retirement Planning
Software in Harvard, Mass.â€œI say that even though I am a strong believer that
for people who are more than, say, 10 years from retirement, simple tools are
the most appropriate, precisely because it's not possible in most cases to
make financial forecasts about individual retirement 15, 20, or 40 years ahead
of time,â€ he says.Other things to consider when using an online retirement
calculator:_Robert Powell is editor ofÂ Retirement Weekly, contributes
regularly to USA TODAY,Â The Wall Street JournalÂ andÂ MarketWatch. Got questions
about money? Email Bob at rpowell@allthingsretirement.com._So, what might you
do if youâ€™re not ready?Jim Otar, developer of the Otar Retirement Calculator
in Thornhill, Canada.Â (Photo: Handout)Benjamin Cummings, an assistant
professor at Saint Joseph's University in Philadelphia.Â (Photo: Handout)
title: 4 ways to tell if youâ€™re financially ready for retirement

Whoopi Goldberg is lending her name and financial backing to a new line of
medical marijuana products designed specifically for women.Goldberg, whoÂ has
been public about her own marijuana use, is one of aÂ handful of Hollywood
celebrities jumping into the marijuana marketplace. Bob Marleyâ€™s family has
partnered with a cannabis company to produce Marley Natural products, and
Snoop Dogg backs Leafs by Snoop. Goldberg said herÂ â€œWhoopi & Mayaâ€ company
received financial backing from three friends and family members, and sheÂ will
serve as chairwoman.â€œI want to go nice and slow with this. I donâ€™t want this
to be a joke to people. Itâ€™s not a joke to women,â€ Goldberg told USA TODAY.The
company she's co-foundedÂ offers four products: a balm, a tincture, sipping
chocolate, and a bath soak. All are infused with marijuana and aim to reduce
the pain and cramps from periods. Pricing has not yet been set.The products
sold under the "Whoopi & Maya brand" will be available only in California
to people with their medical marijuana cards, and they'llÂ be on shelves in the
next several weeks in at least five marijuana dispensaries around the
state.Because marijuana remains illegal at the federal level, the product
today is unavailableÂ elsewhere.The new "Whoopi & Maya" line of marijuana
products aims to offer relief to women suffering from cramps and period pain.
(Photo: Courtesy photo/Michael Osborne/Whoopi & Maya)The marijuana
industry is one of the countryâ€™s fastest growing industries, increasing
annually by 31%,Â with a nationalÂ market worth $5.7 billion, say the two
research firms.By launching in California, Goldberg and partnerÂ Maya Elisabeth
are entering one of the worldâ€™s largest marijuana marketplaces, with
California producing $2.7 billion in sales last year, according to the
cannabis-focused data firms New Frontier and ArcView Market
Research.California voters this fall are widely expected to pass a ballot
measure legalizing recreational marijuana. In many cases, medical and
recreational products are identical; the only difference is whether a user
needs a doctorâ€™s recommendation.California lawmakers this summer approved
series of measures formalizing the stateâ€™s medical marijuana system. Those
measures lay the groundwork for a legal recreational system, and could
potentially give anyone offering medical marijuana products a leg up in
selling recreational products if theyâ€™re legalized this fall."Success at the
ballot box would massively increase Californiaâ€™s total legal market share,â€
Troy Dayton, CEO of The ArcView Group, said in a statement.Elisabeth said she
and Goldberg believe their niche â€” if you can call 50% of the population a
niche, she laughs â€” is ripe for success. She said women have for generations
been herbal healers, and she believes the companyâ€™s marijuana products are no
different.Thereâ€™s very little scientific research available about the benefits
of medical marijuana use, largely because the federal government has sharply
restricted it. Researchers only now are starting to conduct sophisticated
trials about its potential benefits for PTSD and seizure sufferers. England's
Queen Victoria is widely believed to have used a similar tincture to relieve
her own cramps, Elisabeth said."I'm excited for people to feel comfortable
using cannabis," said Elisabeth, a founder of theÂ all-female Northern
CaliforniaÂ edibleÂ marijuana products cooperativeÂ Om Edibles.Goldberg said
smoking pot or drinking marijuana-infused tea has helped control her own
cramps and pain, and she currently uses a "vape" pen filled with marijuana oil
to combat glaucoma headaches. Â She said sheâ€™s not interested in creating a
recreational cannabis company to sell joints to people who just want to get
high. Goldberg cameÂ up with the idea for the company with a friend, and found
Elisabeth to partner with.Goldberg said that at her age, 60, she's willing to
take the risk of violating federal law because she believes so strongly in the
company's mission.Another interest of the two women is in breaking whatÂ some
are calling the "grass-ceiling"Â Â in the semi-legal cannabis industry, which
hasÂ seen limited participation of minorities and women in leadership
roles.When it comes to starting marijuana-focused businesses, state regulators
have written rules that tend to favor established small-business owners with
access to capital and clean criminal records. And because marijuana remains
illegal at the federal level, some would-be entrepreneursÂ feel unwilling to
stick their heads above the water, Elisabeth said, especially those whoâ€™ve
seen how police and prosecutors disproportionally punish minorities when it
comes to drug use.â€œA lot of white men donâ€™t have to think about this,â€ said
Elisabeth, who is white.Goldberg, anÂ actress and comedianÂ known for films like
"Ghost" and TV shows like "Star Trek:Â The Next Generation," has been open
about using marijuana,Â penningÂ a columnÂ forÂ _The Cannabist_ and arguing for
legalization on "The View". This venture into the public spotlight is
different: It's her first investment in a small business like this.â€œThis is a
nice quiet way that I can be part of this,â€ Goldberg said of the new company.
â€œIt had to help people if I were going to be involved."
title: Whoopi Goldberg founds medical marijuana company for women

DALLAS â€” A federal appeals court WednesdayÂ granted a stay of execution for a
Dallas man who was scheduled to die Wednesday night for killing his two
daughters.Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton must now decided whether to
challenge that decision.John Battaglia was scheduled to be executed Wednesday
night for the 2001 murders of his daughtersÂ â€” ages 6 and 9.Attorneys for
Battaglia, 60, argued he deserved a court-appointed attorney to investigate
and a fair hearing to determine claims he may be mentally incompetent for
execution.The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals agreed, halting the punishment
about seven hours before Battaglia's tripÂ to the Texas death chamber.On May 2,
2001, theÂ little girls â€” Liberty and FaithÂ â€”Â were visiting Battaglia, their
father,Â in his apartment near downtown Dallas when the unthinkable
happened."He tried to kill the children!"Those are the chilling words from a
911 recording on the night that Liberty and Faith were murdered.The little
girls were on the phone talking to Mary Jean Pearle, their mother, when
Battaglia shotÂ them.Pearle described the horror when Battaglia went on trial
for murder one year later."And then I hear Faith go, 'No, daddy! Please don't
do it!' And I heard [gunfire], and I hear him yell: 'Merry F---ing
Christmas!'"Evidence showed that Battagalia, an accountant, shot each of his
daughters six times.Pearle rushed to the apartment and paced while police
entered. They told her the little girls were dead.In court, Mary Jean Pearle
recounted the horror of hearing her daughters being shot and killed by her
estranged husband.Â (Photo: WFAA-TV, Dallas-Fort Worth)In an interview with ABC
News, Pearle talked about that moment. "It's the most empty feeling you could
ever have in your life. They are everything. All your hopes and dreams ...
everything is gone," she said.Battaglia was arrested hours later outside a
tattoo parlor where he had just had two roses â€” one for each girl â€” inked on
his arm.Before his arrest, Battaglia left this chilling message on his
daughters' answering machine:"Goodnight, my little babies. I hope you're
resting in a different place."There had been a long history of domestic
violence between Battaglia and Pearle, but no one thought he would kill the
children, so he was allowed to have unsupervised visits.The murders sent shock
waves through the community. Lawmakers were outraged, and a law was changed.
It is now mandatory for judges to ask about a history of violence during
divorce proceedings."In a lot of cases, it was not brought up that there had
been domestic violence in that relationship that was dissolving ... or there
had been some danger to the child," explained Paige Flink, director of The
Family Place, which offers assistance to abused spouses.Battaglia, 60, Â was
scheduled to die by lethal injection at 6 p.m. CT Wednesday in Huntsville. But
a brighter lasting image will remain.After the little girls were slain, The
Family Place openedÂ Faith and Libertyâ€™s Place, where parental visits are
supervised by armed off-duty police officers.Liberty and Faith Battaglia were
shot and killed by their father on May 2, 2001.Â (Photo: Submitted)Itâ€™s also a
place where estranged parents can exchange children safely."I am certain Faith
and Liberty's Place has helped prevent children from being kidnapped, children
being harmed," Flink said.Tiffany Ratcliff and her abusive ex-husband were
ordered to go to Faith and Liberty's Place by a judge to exchange their son."I
was scared. I didn't know what to expect," she said. "I didn't know if I was
going to live or if I was going to die."After eight years of supervised
exchanges and visits, Ratcliff said she and her ex built an amicable
relationship and things changed.This center helps more than 100 families every
month. Ratcliff has a message for Faith and Liberty's mother.Faith and
Liberty's Place provides a safe setting for parents to exchange children.
(Photo: WFAA-TV, Dallas-Fort Worth)"I'm sorry for your loss, but I am grateful
â€”Â and I don't mean to be selfish. I don't because I had another chance at
life, and I am so sorry for your loss," she said._Contributing: The Associated
Press. Follow Rebecca Lopez on Twitter: @rlopezwfaa_

by backers of Hillary Clinton filed three complaints Tuesday with the Federal
Election Commission against Sen. Bernie Sanders and two super PACs that
support him.The American Democracy Legal Fund, established by David Brock,
charges that Sanders and his campaign repeatedly accepted contributions in
excess of the $2,700 legal limit for individuals per election.Another
complaint alleges a Facebook ad encouraging donations after Sandersâ€™ New
Hampshire win did not disclose who paid for the communication. Finally, the
legal fund accuses the super PAC Progressive Kick of illegally using Sandersâ€™
name and claims that group and the super PAC Nurses National Nurses United for
Patient Protection are illegally coordinating with the Sanders campaign.The
Sanders campaign last month described an FEC warning about excessive
contributions as â€œstandardâ€ and said the campaign would address the FECâ€™s
questions. On Tuesday, the campaign dismissed the Brock groupâ€™s complaint as
frivolous and noted it follows Clintonâ€™s chief strategist Joel Benenson call
for Sanders to change his negative tone."Just one day after the Clinton
campaign said we needed to change our tone, the leaders of their coordinated
super PAC, which is funded by millions from Wall Street, filed baseless and
frivolous complaints with the FEC,â€ Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver said
in a statement. â€œTells you all you need to know."The Clinton campaign declined
to comment on the complaints.Brock, founder of the pro-Clinton super PAC
Correct the Record, has targeted Sanders throughout the campaign, raising
questions about his commitment to the Black Lives Matter movement and his
medical records._MSNBC_ reports this is the first time ADLF has filed a
complaint against a Democrat.Sanders has long denounced the unlimited money
super PACs spend in support of candidates. His lack of affiliation with a
super PAC is a distinction he draws with Clinton at his rallies.Last month in
Massachusetts, whenÂ Sanders was introduced at a rally byÂ Karen Higgins, co-
president ofÂ National Nurses United, the campaign saidÂ it is not coordinating
with or raising money on behalf of theÂ super PAC and highlighted the
difference between that PAC and others."This is a PAC that is supported by
nurses, one of the most respected and admired professions in the country, and
to compare nurses to the billionaires and Wall Street special interestsÂ who
are supporting other candidates is a preposterous stretch," Sanders' spokesman
Michael Briggs said after the rally.

content:
Sean Miller never requested all of this.Five times since his hiring in 2009,
his bosses at the University of Arizona have amended his coaching contract
with sweeteners, including multiple pay raises and 15 more hours of use per
year on a charter jet.In 2013, they even talked about increasing his salary by
another $100,000, but Miller said he didnâ€™t need it and declined. A year
later, they awarded him a stake in a privately donated investment deal
currently valued at nearly $4 million.â€œIâ€™m being proactive,â€ said Millerâ€™s
boss, Arizona athletics director Greg Byrne. â€œI donâ€™t believe heâ€™s asked for
it one time.â€Unlike other top coaches in college basketball, Miller doesnâ€™t
even have an agent to help maximize his earning potential. He doesnâ€™t need
one, apparently, because heâ€™s already got all the leverage he needs â€” even if
heâ€™s never quite reached the Final Four of the NCAA tournament, including this
year, when his team was bounced in the first round.Coaches with credentials
like his are in high demand â€” beneficiaries of a pay market that keeps
spiraling upward, according to a USA TODAY Sports analysis of documents it
acquired in conjunction with the Sports Capital Journalism Program at Indiana
University-Purdue University Indianapolis and the Grady Sports Media Program
at the University of Georgia. This year, Miller was one of 24 coaches in the
tournament making at least $2 million, up from 11 in 2011.And that creates a
dilemma of sorts for Arizona, just like other top programs with big budget
challenges: They can say enough is enough and risk starting over with a
cheaper coach. Or they can keep upping the ante, hoping to keep their coach
from leaving for greener pastures.Arizona has made its choice, providing a
case study on the challenges of how to pay for it all while tensions rise in
the quest for revenue.In recent years, the school has tried to keep up by
foraging for new money streams on campus and off, leading to creative
enticements this year that helped make Miller one of the five highest-
compensated coaches in the tournament. USA TODAY Sportsâ€™ analysis measured his
compensation value this year at $4.9 million, up from about $2.3 million in
2011, thanks largely to an unusual deferred compensation package derived in
publicly traded units of an oil pipeline and storage business.Meanwhile,
Arizonaâ€™s bottom line is still stretched enough that the school has considered
imposing a new $200 fee on students to help fund football stadium
upgrades.â€œThere are limits to this in my mind, to how far (the market) goes,
and we just havenâ€™t really hit them yet,â€ Arizona Board of Regents Chairman
Jay Heiler told USA TODAY Sports. â€œBut at some point I think things will
settle down a little bit, and we wonâ€™t be in such a white-hot, overheated
environment of escalating coaching salaries. We havenâ€™t gotten there yet. So
far weâ€™re still riding the delta upward.â€Growing up in western Pennsylvania,
Miller lived in a middle-class home and spent much of his time on the court
with his father, John, the legendary former coach at Blackhawk High.â€œWe
werenâ€™t going on big vacations,â€ John Miller said. â€œWe were in the gym most of
the time.â€It paid off. Sean Miller, the oldest of four siblings, played for
his dad before moving on to play at Pitt. His brother, Archie, did the same
before playing at North Carolina State, where Sean was an assistant coach.
Both followed their father into coaching and are still picking golden apples
off its tree.As the head coach at Dayton, Archie, 37, just received an
undisclosed pay increase and a third consecutive contract extension from the
private school after making his third appearance in a row in the NCAA
tournament.For Sean Miller, 47, his star rose after four 20-win seasons at
Xavier, leading him to Arizona, where he and his family have a 6,800-square-
foot home purchased for $3.25 million shortly after his hiring in 2009,
according to property records. He has a 308-108 career record and is one of
the best active coaches never to have made the Final Four, falling short four
times in the Elite Eight.â€œArizona has reached out and really made it pretty
darn good,â€ John Miller said. â€œNow if he would leave, I guess I would have to
say maybe more towards an NBA thing, you know? But knowing him the way I know
him, I just donâ€™t know if heâ€™s meant for the NBA. Some guys arenâ€™t quite meant
to do all the traveling and game after game after game. Heâ€™s more of an in-
the-gym guy.â€Through a spokesman, Sean Miller declined to comment for this
story. So did his attorney, who reviews the contract improvements initiated by
Byrne.Byrne and John Miller say money is not a motivator for Sean. But
ambition can be even more influential. John Miller has noticed that some of
his sonâ€™s friends have moved on to coach in the NBA, particularly former
Florida coach Billy Donovan, now with the Oklahoma City Thunder, and former
Arizona star Steve Kerr, now with the Golden State Warriors.â€œI donâ€™t know if
thatâ€™s maybe got him looking,â€ John Miller said. â€œAt this point, I donâ€™t know.
I havenâ€™t really discussed it with him too much lately. I think heâ€™s happy
whereâ€™s heâ€™s at, and I think he has his mind set on getting into that Final
Four.â€Maryland nearly lured him away in 2011, a dalliance that was followed by
the first of his five contract amendments at Arizona, which included a two-
year extension, a pay raise and more time on the jet for recruiting. It was
â€œclose,â€ Byrne said of Millerâ€™s decision in 2011.Like many of his peers in
similar situations, Byrne doesnâ€™t want to risk losing the head of a successful
program that accounted for $22 million of $87 million in total operating
revenues for Arizona athletics in fiscal year 2015, according to the
school.â€œCoach Miller obviously is a high-demand coach in his sport,â€ said
Heiler, chairman of the regents that oversee the stateâ€™s three public
universities and approve such contracts. â€œItâ€™s driven not only by the rest of
the college basketball world. Itâ€™s also driven by the professional basketball
world. Scarce leadership resources puts constant upward pressure on
compensation. â€¦ We deal with it like any board would in any industry in any
setting regarding its top leadership talent.â€They also know there are limits
out there. Just ask Arizona students.Arizona is one of the last holdouts in
the Pac-12 Conference â€” one of only two public schools in the league that
didnâ€™t receive funding in athletics last year from student
fees.â€œPhilosophically, itâ€™s something Iâ€™d prefer not to do,â€ Byrne said.But
heâ€™s starting to wonder if he might have no other choice. After in-state rival
Arizona State recently added a mandatory $150 annual student fee to fund
athletics, Arizona is under pressure to enter that race for revenue. This
year, Arizona officials considered adding a $200 student fee to help fund
football stadium upgrades and might push for it again next year.Huge
television contracts have dramatically boosted the revenues of college sports,
helping Arizonaâ€™s operating revenues more than double from $40 million in
2005, not adjusting for inflation. At the same time, the rising revenues of
college sports have fueled escalating expenses.In Arizonaâ€™s case, athletics
had about $78.2 million in generated operating revenues last year, compared to
$80.7 million in operating expenses, which ranked sixth among public schools
in the Pac-12.To bridge the shortfall, Arizona receives university subsidies
much like most of its public-school peers in the Power Five conferences. In
Arizonaâ€™s case last year, that came in the form of $1.5 million for utilities,
plus $7.4Â million in tuition waivers from the state board of regents to help
pay for athletics scholarships, a benefit also given to ASU.By adding a
student fee, Arizona would be keeping up with the competition in one respect.
It would be gaining opposition in another.â€œIâ€™ve heard overwhelming negative
feedback from students (on the student fee),â€ said Joe Zanoni, an Arizona
student and senator for the universityâ€™s Associated Students. â€œLots of
students, especially in engineering, are here for five years and theyâ€™d be
paying $1,000 to the athletic department. Thatâ€™s a big chunk of change for our
generation, especially because weâ€™re getting buried in student loan debt,
too.â€Byrne said the football stadium needs the funding, arguing that parts of
it are nearly 100 years old and need to be updated to stay operational. Such
improvements also are relevant to the whole athletics department because
football is its biggest cash cow and one of at least two critical sources
Byrne cites for increasing revenue and funding rising expenses.The other is
fundraising, one of Byrneâ€™s strengths and the biggest reason Millerâ€™s
compensation value jumped so high this year.Itâ€™s called the Longevity Fund.
Byrne said it comes from a private donor who offered a gift of 500,000 units
in a master limited partnership to be used at the discretion of university
President Ann Weaver Hart. Of that amount, a block of 175,000 units each is
allocated to help in retaining Miller and football coach Rich Rodriguez, with
another 100,000 going to help retain Byrne._Financial Times_ identified the
donor as Jeff Stevens, the CEO of Western Refining Logistics, a limited
partnership in El Paso. Stevens didnâ€™t return a message seeking comment, and
the school has declined to identify the source of the fund. The full value of
Millerâ€™s Longevity Fund is nearly $4 million, according to the unit price this
week.â€œWe thought that was a creative solution and one that also incentivized
staying at Arizona,â€ Byrne said.The university added the fund to Millerâ€™s
contract with amendment No. 4 in 2014, stipulating then that he could become
vested in a quarter of the fundâ€™s value by this year and then receive a cash
equivalent of the fundâ€™s full value if he stayed at Arizona through May 2022.
The contract also said he would receive the vested value of the fund even if
he were fired â€œwithout causeâ€ before then, which usually means getting fired
for not winning enough games.On the other hand, he doesnâ€™t get any of the
fundâ€™s value if he voluntarily leaves for another job. A separate retention
fund in his contract gives him $2.1 million if he stays at Arizona through
April 30.That means if Miller were to leave Arizona before the end of next
month, heâ€™d be forfeiting about $6 million. Last week, Miller quickly
squelched speculation about returning to his alma mater, which recently had an
opening.â€œI have one of the great jobs in college basketball at Arizona,â€
Miller said in a statement. â€œI have no interest in becoming the head coach at
Pitt.â€The longevity and retention funds provide an incentive to stay, but just
in case it wasnâ€™t good enough in 2014, Arizona reworked his contract in 2015
with amendment No. 5. This time, the contract was changed to let him collect
on the full value of the Longevity Fund in 2020 instead of 2022. It also
vested him at two-thirds of the unitsâ€™ value last fall instead of one-quarter,
accounting for a big one-time bump in his compensation value this year.Miller
â€œknows that President Hart and I have been very pleased with the job he has
done as our menâ€™s basketball coach, and weâ€™ve tried to reflect that by keeping
him between four and five years on his contract,â€ Byrne said.Asked why the
university accelerated the vesting and payout dates for Miller last year,
Byrne said, â€œThat was a discussion between Sean and myself. â€¦ We were looking
at the marketplace and thought this was a good solution and the best chance to
have our team in place during this time frame.â€Another way to explain it is
that Miller simply had the upper hand. The leverage comes from his record and
the market. And the market will keep going up until it canâ€™t, possibly because
of legal, political or economic factors.Legal challenges continue to seek the
possibility of more compensation for college athletes, who can receive
scholarships and money for expenses but not salaries. The more money coaches
make, the more it seems unfair that the players donâ€™t share more of the
wealth.Sports economist Andrew Zimbalist called it an artificial market.â€œThe
reason why the coaches are able to command those salaries is because the
players arenâ€™t getting paid,â€ Zimbalist said. â€œThe coaches are getting paid
for the value of the players they are recruiting.â€And when subsidies and
student fees are being used to balance the books and fund other expenses, the
market starts looking like a bubble destined to burst, Zimbalist
said.â€œPolitically, itâ€™s not sustainable," he said. "Legally, itâ€™s not
sustainable. Economically, itâ€™s not sustainable. And itâ€™s going to be
changed.â€Heiler, the chairman of the Arizona regents, said he wonders where
the ceiling might be.â€œI think institutions are going to have to â€¦ realize
thereâ€™s something to be said for having coaches who at some point feel like
they are being adequately compensated to reach all of their goals and
aspirations,â€ Heiler said of the market in general. â€œHow much is enough, you
know, to be a collegiate coach in basketball and football and to be happy and
fulfilled and to live a wonderful life?â€**PHOTOS: Top 15 highest paid men's
NCAA hoopsÂ coaches****Contributing: Jodi Upton****_Follow sports reporter
Brent Schrotenboer on TwitterÂ @Schrotenboer. E-mail:
bschrotenb@usatoday.com_**

viewers.Thatâ€™s what happened to Tyra Riedemonn, a 17-year-old high school
senior at the Young Womenâ€™s Leadership Academy of East Harlem. She thought she

RiedemonnÂ would be receiving $60,000 a year in financial aid (annual tuition

French authorities charged terror suspect Reda Kriket with membership in a

ProsecutorÂ Francois MolinsÂ said Wednesday.Molins said an arsenal ofÂ guns and
bomb components wasÂ found in Kriket's apartment when he was arrested last
week,Â France24Â reported. Authorities had no information on specific targets,
but based on the weaponry, the attack would have been "extremely serious,"

Investigations showed Kriket played a key role in financing the network with
money from robberies and stolen goods, France24 reported.Two other suspects
charged over the foiled attack plot are in custody in Belgium, Molins said.In
Belgium, plans toÂ partially reopen Brussels Airport on Wednesday were shelved
because ofÂ extensive damageÂ from last week's attack on the airport and a metro
station that killed 32 people.Arnaud Feist, directorÂ of the nation's largest
airport, said temporary facilities designed to processÂ about 800 travelers an
hourÂ â€” about 20% of the normal flowÂ â€” were still being completed and tested.
Authorities had hoped to partially reopen the airport Tuesday."There will be
no passenger flights into or out ofÂ #brusselsairportÂ today 30 March. As soon
as there's an update, we'll let you know," the airport tweeted Wednesday.
Hours later came this tweet:Â Â "The evaluation of the trial is still ongoing
and will take at least till tomorrow afternoon. No flights till then."Adding
to the concerns: A strike threat from airport police who have complained since

The station was evacuated because ofÂ a suspicious vehicle a week ago.VTM also
was among media reporting that a laptop, found in a Brussels trash can near

Michel."Nothing indicates ... preparations for an attack on the government of
Charles Michel," officials with the Belgian federal prosecutor's office told

Most Hall of Fames in professional sports have some majorly dysfunctional
components aboutÂ them, especially whenÂ deciding who to induct. Golfâ€™s Hall of
FameÂ faced some trouble on that front, too, but after the furor that
surrounded Colin Montgomerieâ€™s induction in 2013 despite him never winning a
major, the World Golf Hall of Fame made some much-needed and admirable
reforms.The latest re-jig of the system seesÂ Jack Nicklaus, Nancy Lopez, Gary
Player and Annika Sorenstam appointed co-chairs of the selection committee,
and a raise of the minimum induction age from 40 to 50 years old.According to
the PGA Tour:Effective immediately, candidates must be at least 50 years of
age at the start of the year in which selections are made, replacing the
previous age requirement of 40. The exception would be if a player was at
least five years removed from being an active participant on his or her
respective tour.â€œWe work very closely with our Hall of Fame Members to ensure
all aspects of the Induction criteria are shrewd and judicious,â€ added Peter.
â€œAs players continue to elevate their fitness levels and continue to play at a
high level for a longer period of time, moving the age requirement to 50
ensures that we are able to celebrate their careers at the proper time.â€The
unfortunate part of all of this is that Tiger Woods â€” who turned 40 late last
year â€” will now have to wait another 10 years before he walks into the Hall.
Some people will make a fuss, but Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s that big a deal.Yes, it
wouldâ€™ve been nice to see him get inducted sooner rather than later, but itâ€™s
always awkward when players take their place in the Hall of Fame while their
career is still active. Ultimately, I think all parties would prefer to see a
player like Tiger Woods assume his place when his PGA Tour career is well and
truly over, and have the Hall of Fame be a cherry on top of one of the most
astonishing golfÂ careers ever.
