The outgoing chief executive of embattled drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals
InternationalÂ  (VRX) has been subpoenaed to testify at a Senate hearing
examining sudden price spikes in decades-old medications.J. Michael Pearson,
whose planned departure from the slumping company was announced last week, is
among several witnesses scheduled for the April 27th hearing, the committee
said Monday.The session is the panel's third public hearing on the impact that
drug price increases have had on patients, health insurers and medical
professionals."Valeant has been cooperating with the committee's investigation
and Mr. Pearson looks forward to testifying at the hearing," said company
spokeswoman Laurie Little.Pearson had been credited for leading Valeant's
rapid expansion in recent years through acquisition of other pharmaceutical
firms and their medications. But his tenure has been marred by questions about
steep price hikes in dermatology drugs and other medications the Canada-based
company acquired as part of itsÂ expansion.A February memo issued by a House
oversight committeeÂ conducting a separate Valeant reviewÂ showed the company
raised the respective prices on heart medications Isuprel and Nitropress by
525% and 212% immediately after acquiring them in February 2015.Valeant and
Pearson have also drawn questions and criticism about the company's since-
cancelled business dealings with Philidor Rx Services, a specialty mail-order
pharmacy that distributed some of Valeant's medications to patients.The
drugmaker cut ties with PhilidorÂ in October afterÂ reportÂ by activist short-
sellerÂ Andrew Left'sÂ Citron ResearchÂ accused ValeantÂ of creating aÂ "network of
phantom captive pharmacies"Â to steer pharmacy benefit managers toÂ Valeantâ€™s
more expensive drugs, instead of less-costlyÂ alternatives.Valeant denied the
allegations, but named a special board committee to investigate the Philidor
relationship. The companyÂ subsequently said it would restateÂ $58 million in
financial earnings from late 2014 into 2015Â based on preliminary results of
the review.The continuing internal examination review prevented Valeant from
filing its annual report before a March 15 deadline, which raised the risk of
potential default on itsÂ bonds.The drugmakerÂ is also under separate
investigations by federal prosecutors in New York and Massachusetts andÂ the
Securities and Exchange Commission. The company's stock has plungedÂ 88% since
it reached a $262.52 a share peakÂ in early August.Valeant shares fell Â 7%
Monday to closeÂ at $28.86.Â The decline followed a Â Bloomberg NewsÂ reportÂ that
investors in Sprout Pharmaceuticals, the firm Valeant bought last year along
with rights to a libido-boosting drugÂ in a $1 billion deal, said Valeant
overcharged patients for prescriptions of the so-called female Viagra.The
investors said Valeant "predatorily priced" the drug, calledÂ Addyi, at $800 a
month, or roughly double the price Sprout had established, theÂ report said. As
a result, some health insurers have refused to cover the cost. The refusal,
along with inadequate marketing of the drug, could putÂ Valeant at risk of
violating the Sprout merger'sÂ terms, the investors wrote.Valeant said it
planned a response to the group'sÂ contentions._Follow USA TODAY reporter Kevin
McCoy on Twitter: @kmccoynyc_

LOS ANGELES -Â **I**nstagram, the no. 1 photo sharing app, is about to change
the way it displays photos.The Facebook owned firm will be rolling out a new
system that ditches the old way--chronological listings, for an algorithm.Â **_
_**In other words, now Instagram will show you photos it thinks you want to
see.The newÂ algorithm was announced last week, but is being currently tested
with just a small percentage of Instagram's 400 million monthly users. Most
Instagrammers won't see changes to their news feeds for weeks, if not months,
says Instagram spokesperson Gabe Madway.Photographer Jasmine StarÂ (Photo:
Jefferson Graham)Photographer Jasmine StarÂ has looked into the new algorithm,
and how it will affect the user experience. SheÂ wrote a terrific blog post
about it, and explains in the accompanying video and audio what the changes
meanÂ to users and small business owners."The order of photos and videos in
your feed will be based on the likelihood you'll be interested in the content,
your relationship with the person posting and the timeliness of the post,"
Instagram said in a blog post.Â "As we begin, we're focusing on optimizing the
order â€” all the posts will still be there, just in a different order."In other
words, bBased on how active the post is, if there are a lot of comments and
likes, that will be shown first to viewers," says Star. That'sÂ similar to how
it works with Facebook. Instagram is a unit of the social network."At the end
of the day, the people who will benefit the most are advertisers," says Star.
"You pay to play, and the more you pay, the more people will be seeing you."In
announcing the changes, Instagram said it was making the move because most
users miss 70% of what people post--a function of how many times they check
the app to keep up with what's new."The goal is to make sure you see what you
want to see," says Madway. "People think they're seeing everything, but
they're not."_Follow USA TODAY tech columnist and #TalkingTech host Jefferson
Graham on Twitter, @jeffersongraham.Â _

WASHINGTON â€”Â An armedÂ man was wounded Monday by U.S. Capitol PoliceÂ when he
arrived at the Capitol VisitorÂ Center and brandished a weapon at authorities,
police said.U.S. Capitol Police Chief Matthew Verderosa said the man, who is
known to authorities, appeared to draw his weapon when he was shot by police.
One other person, described as a 35-Â toÂ 45-year-old female bystander,Â suffered
minor injuries fromÂ flying shrapnel or debris.A federal law enforcement
official, who is not authorized to comment publicly, said the man was armed
with a handgun.Verderosa said the matter was "the act of a single person who
has frequented the Capitol before.''Â The suspect was identified by a federal
law enforcement official asÂ Larry Russell Dawson of Antioch, Tenn., who had
been charged last year in a Capitol disturbance.Dawson was charged Oct. 23
with assaulting a police officer and unlawful conduct on Capitol grounds,
according to D.C. court records. He was releasedÂ but never appeared in court.
A bench warrant was issued Nov. 19 for his arrest.In another matter, Dawson's
re-application forÂ a license from the Tennessee Board of Funeral Directors and
Embalmers was rejected in August 2014, according to board records.The
confrontation MondayÂ transpired in a matter of seconds near the entrance to
the visitor center, which was the scene of an active shooter drill earlier in
the day. The real-lifeÂ incident promptedÂ authorities to issue aÂ shelter-in-
place order, which was later liftedÂ as police massed near the scene.Â The
shootingÂ came during a congressional recess but at aÂ time when the city is
packed with tourists, many on spring break or in the nation's capital for the
annualÂ Cherry Blossom Festival.Following the reports, the Washington, D.C.
police department tweeted that there was "no active threat to the
public."Dawson was being treated at a local hospital and was in stable but
critical condition late Monday, the Associated Press reported. Police told
_The Washington Post_ that DawsonÂ would appear in D.C. Superior Court after
his release from the hospital.There has been an isolated incident at the US
Capitol. There is no active threat to the publicUnidentified young people
embrace after being evacuated on Capitol Hill following a shooting in the
Capitol Visitors Center on March 28, 2016.Â (Photo: Michael Reynolds, European
Pressphoto Agency)The Capitol Visitor Center remained closed Monday following
the incident, and the Capitol was available only for official business.
Verderosa told reporters that police had located Dawson's pickup on the
Capitol grounds and were processing it.Per USCP, shelter in place has been
lifted and the Capitol is open for official business only. Capitol Visitor
Center remains closed. #alertDiane Bilo of Cincinnati said her husband heard a
single shot in the visitorÂ center and a clip of bullets being fired. Her
husband,Â Robert, was in the center with theirÂ two younger sons, Michael and
Matt, waiting for her to return from Ohio Sen. Rob Portman's office with
gallery passes."It was scary," Bilo said. "Police said, 'Run, run as fast as
you can.'"She was communicating with her husband and children, who were still
in the center's theater, by text."They are sheltered," she said, adding that
she was relieved to hear from them.Matthew Melucci of Connecticut said the
situation seemed under control relatively quickly, but it was frighteningÂ as
it unfolded."We were coming out of the Capitol when we heard 'Shots fired,
shots fired,'" he said, before being pulled into a security area for a half-
hour."It was scary. I've got three children with me and my wife," he said. "It
was a scary moment about what was going to happen next. We felt lucky we were
there with several police officers."Trotter and Anne Cobb of Birmingham, Ala.,
were eating lunch in the lowerÂ level of the centerÂ when Trotter Cobb said he
heard a "crack" of aÂ gunshot, resulting in dropped trays andÂ glassesÂ crashing
to the floor."Capitol Police came out of nowhere," he said.Â Â "They were
amazing."Tune Chang, 42, and his wife, Angie, and 10-year-old daughter Amanda
were headed toÂ the centerÂ when they were stopped on the south side of the
Capital andÂ directed across the street.Police look at a grey truck that is
believed to belong to the suspect in a shooting at the Capitol Visitors Center
on Capitol Hill, in Washington, DC, USA, 28 March 2016. EPA/MICHAEL REYNOLDS
(Photo: MICHAEL REYNOLDS, EPA)Tune Chang said he didn't consider safety issues
when the family decided to travel from Los Angeles to Washington for a one-
week vacation."We're in a better situation than the rest of the world" as far
as security,Â he said._Contributing: Christopher Doering and Bill Theobald_

Donald Trump says he wants to study a petition that calls for allowing the
open carry of guns at the Republican convention this July in Cleveland.While
proclaiming himself "a very, very strong person for Second Amendment," the
Republican front-runnerÂ told ABC's _This WeekÂ _that "I have not seen the
petition.Â I want to see what it says.Â I want to read the fine print."Posted on
the website change.org, the petition of unknown origin notes that "though Ohio
is an open carry state, which allows for the open carry of guns, the hosting
venue --Â the Quicken Loans Arena --Â strictly forbids the carry of firearms on

of Sunday.Then-Republican presidential candidate Rand Paul and his wife Kelley
Ashby walk outside the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland before an August
debate.Â (Photo: Andrew Harnik, AP)The other Republican presidential candidates

and accepts online message only from networked supporters,Â theÂ _Akron Beacon
Journal_Â reported.According to the website cnet on Sunday, the petition may

claimed responsibility.He or she writes: "It just doesn't seem right that

not exactly of the Republican cause.Â For example: "Win-win for the Trump
people at last night's rally: a protester got beat up and a black guy got
arrested. This was accompanied with the #NeverTrump hashtag."The Ohio
Republican Party said it was not aware of the petition, theÂ _Journal_
reported, nor was the host committee overseeing the convention, although it
noted that the Secret Service, in conjunction with Cleveland, Cuyahoga County
andÂ state and federal authorities, is handling security for the event.â€œThey
are coordinating and will be continuously refining security plans leading up
to the national convention,â€ said Alee Lockman, a spokesperson for the
Republican National Convention, theÂ _JournalÂ _says.In 2012, firearmsÂ were
banned by the Secret Service at the Republican convention in
Tampa.Contributing: Doug Stanglin

Maybe itâ€™s wishful thinking, but a former college basketball star thinks
change could be coming to the top of the womenâ€™s game.Chiney Ogwumike, the
2014 No. 1 pick in the WNBA draft out of Stanford, says she sensesÂ a shift if
Connecticut, as widely expected, wins its fourth consecutive national title
next week in Indianapolis. The Huskies take a 72-game winning streak into
Mondayâ€™s Bridgeport (Conn.) Regional final against second-seeded Texas (7
p.m., ET, ESPN).â€œI think the landscape of womenâ€™s basketball is changing in
the respect that players want to develop themselves, develop their own brand
and create their own story,â€ Ogwumike said. â€œI donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m crazy, but I
feel like the younger generation, they are making decisions for themselves
that are different. I just feel like the top players are staying home, top
players are going to different schools.â€œUConn would get the top five or six of
the top five or six. Now those top five or six, they want to do their own
thing on their own terms. UConn will still get amazing talent, but the talent
is definitely going to disperse.â€According to ESPNâ€™s HoopGurlz recruiting
rankings for 2015, seven of the top 15 players committed to in-state schools
or to a school in the same region. In the 2016 class, nine of the top 15
players stayed close to home, including the Nos. 1 and 2 players who were from
Texas â€” five-star recruits Lauren Cox chose Baylor and Joyner Holmes picked
Texas. Though there havenâ€™t been many commitments from the 2017 class yet, at
least three top-20 prospects arenâ€™t leaving home, either.Jewell Loyd, the
former Notre Dame star who was selected first overall by the Seattle Storm in
the 2015 WNBA draft, can relate to this. She was also recruited by UConn, but
coming from Chicago, she chose the Fighting Irish because she wanted to stay
close to family.â€œI wanted my own destiny, my own story,â€ said Loyd, currently
playing overseas for Galatasaray M.P. Istanbul in Turkey. â€œIâ€™ll never forget
when I was going through the (recruiting) process, Geno wrote me a handwritten
letter saying how he was excited to coach against me and he wished me the best
of luck. â€¦ It was hard saying no to him because not a lot of players say no to
him. Or get the opportunity to talk to him.â€But this style of creating your
own way is becoming more of a trend.â€œI think at the grassroots level, kids
have more access of how to develop their skills and stay dedicated to
improving themselves in a way thatâ€™s different,â€ Ogwumike said.â€œYou have
technology now that can help you figure out how to improve your shot. You
donâ€™t need to go to a certain place to get that kind of instruction. You can
go to YouTube, watch on Instagram and try to mimic things.â€The womenâ€™s
tournament so far has seen some significant upsets. South Carolina and Notre
Dame, both No. 1 seeds, were upset on Friday. Big Ten champ Maryland, a No. 2
seed and Final Four team last year, lost to No. 7 Washington in the second
round. Washington then beat No. 3 Kentucky.UConn didnâ€™t always dominate.
Ogwumike, heavily recruited by UConn, traces the Huskiesâ€™ monopoly on talent
really since winning their first national championship in 1995. As the program
was rising to power, Tennessee, who won eight titles under Pat Summitt, was at
the peak of its reign. But Tennessee won its last championship in 2008 and
hasnâ€™t won one since. No program has filled that void.That said, until thereâ€™s
an obvious change â€” more teams winning championships, UConn not beating
opponents by margins of 20 points or more â€” the goal will be to figure out a
way to overthrow this team.And to set the record straight,Â though the Huskies
are often told theyâ€™re killing the game, their opponents feel the opposite.â€œI
knew every time we played them I was going to learn a lot. I loved playing
UConn,â€ Loyd said. â€œI always knew the games would be really competitive and it
would bring out another side of me that I loved being, I loved feeling. I mean
we had some great games, overtime games and just back and forth. There were
also games we lost by 20.â€œAgainst UConn, for a couple of minutes you can feel
like youâ€™re in there. And then by the last five they take off and itâ€™s kinda

WASHINGTON â€” Former Illinois governor Rod Blagojevich won't get his day at the
Supreme Court.The colorful Democratic politician known as 'Blago' was rejected
Monday in his effort to get the high court to reconsider his conviction on
corruption charges for trying to sell the vacant Senate seat once occupied by
President Obama.The saga ended quietly in the last year of Obama's White House
term,Â as the ex-governor's petition was denied without comment.Blagojevich,
59, wasÂ convicted in 2011 of 17 felonies,Â including 11 counts stemming from
what federal prosecutors called his attempt to sell Obama's Senate seat. He is
serving a 14-year sentence at a federal prison in Colorado.A federal appeals
court tossed out five of the convictions, but the Supreme Court refused to
hear his lawyers' arguments that the remaining counts also were examples of
commonplace political favors rather than illegal corruption.The justices
agreed earlier this year to hearÂ a similar case from Virginia, where former
Republican governor Bob McDonnell is challenging his conviction for accepting
more than $175,000 in gifts and loans from a wealthy businessman in exchange
for government favors. The case will be heard on April 27, the court's last
day for oral arguments this term.
title: Supreme Court rejects ex-Illinois governor Blagojevich's conviction appeal

LOS ANGELES â€” A year ago, live video streaming to a smartphone app was mostly
talk.But today, as Twitter's live video streaming app Periscope celebrates its
first birthday, the company announced a big milestone â€” some 200 million live
broadcasts have been streamed to date.Thatâ€™s up from 100 million in January,
â€œSo weâ€™re seeing extraordinary growth in a short period of time,â€ says
Periscope co-founder Kayvon Beykpour.The company says there are now so many
live streams, they equateÂ to 110 years of live video being watched every day
on the app, which is available for Apple and Android devices.A year ago, the
South by Southwest conference had just ended, and live video via the Meerkat
app was the talk of the show. Then Periscope popped out of the gateÂ and stole
the thunder, with its ease of useÂ and ability to stream video directly to
Twitter feeds. (Meerkat has since announced it was switching its focus.)By the
end of 2015, Apple had named Periscope "App of the Year," and Facebook jumped
loudly into live video streaming as well. Now Facebook users can record live
directly into News Feeds.And just last week came word that Google may be
looking to start a new live video streaming app forÂ YouTube, YouTube
Connect.BeykpourÂ isn't worried about the competition.â€œLive streaming has been
around for ages,â€ he says. â€œWe werenâ€™t the first.â€ Justin.tv, Hang w/,
Ustream, YouNow and many others predate Periscope. â€œWe donâ€™t pay much
attention to what other people are doing;Â weâ€™re just focused on making the
best mobile experience. That more people are getting involved is great, it
shows people are taking a broad view of the space.â€Fans took to Periscope as
the easiest form of video making. There's no big production skills â€” just hold
up the smartphone to your face and show what you see, and when you're done,
press stop. There's no fancy video editing or transfer process needed. Along
the way, get massive feedback from folks all over the world, who respond with
animated hearts and questions.Periscope took off thanks to a â€œconfluenceâ€ of
events â€” better network, software and ubiquity of smartphones able to pull in
high-speed connections, says Beykpour. â€œLive video used to mean a 30- to
60-second delay. You could get it done with a video camera tapped Â  to a big
backpackÂ and a laptop, but that wasnâ€™t for the consumer.â€Peter Csathy â€”Â CEO of
Manatt Digital Media, which invests in and consults with tech start-ups â€”Â says
consumers responded, thanks to apps like Periscope and Facebook pushing the
cause.â€œItâ€™s easy, they tried itÂ and now they understand the power of it,â€ he
says.Beykpour says â€œbeing able to see whatâ€™s happening in real time anywhere
in the world is a super power.Â You can see a map of the world, zoom into a
neighborhood, and go someplace with a breaking news event and step into the
shoes of someone there and talk to them â€” thatâ€™s crazy.â€While Periscopeâ€™s
numbers are booming, Csathy says it has a big monkey on its back â€” â€Facebook
is a monster,â€ he says. â€œFacebook is now very focused on live video, and that
will make it much more challenging.â€Periscope needs to become a regular part
of peopleâ€™s daily lives, like Facebook is, says Csathy. â€œThatâ€™s a huge
undertaking.â€And with Google reportedly entering the live video space, based
on the 1 billion monthly users for the worldâ€™s most popular video site, Google
is primed to take a major chunk of the audience as well, Csathy says.
title: 200M broadcasts in 1 year for Periscope

The Justice Department issued aÂ scathing report on Ferguson, Mo. a year ago,
confirming to the broader public what many blacks and Latinos had been saying
for years: that the criminal justice system is rigged against them, sometimes
with deadly results. The rage of the #blacklivesmatter movement seemed sure to
dominate the comingÂ election campaign.YetÂ now in the midst of that campaign,
an important national conversation about police brutality and discrimination
has faded into the background. Instead, an angry white working class is center
stageÂ voicing, subtly perhaps, that this election is about recapturing a
nationÂ now led by itsÂ first ever African-American president.Some people have
had trouble coping with Barack Obama's raceÂ since he was first elected.
Justice investigators even unearthed evidence of thisÂ in Ferguson, where they
found emails mocking the first lady, comparing Obama to a chimp and opining
that he wouldnâ€™t hold office for long because â€œwhat black man holds a steady
job for four years?â€Today there is a palpable anger in the air about Obamaâ€™s
presidency. â€œWe donâ€™t need a president like Obama no more. Heâ€™s ruined our
country. Heâ€™s ruined Christmas. Heâ€™s let the Muslims in. We canâ€™t say that
word. Weâ€™ve got to be ashamed of everything. And weâ€™re not a shamed people.
Weâ€™re a proud people and weâ€™re going to take our country back so watch out
Obama, weâ€™re coming,â€ Nancy Mcfadzean said on C-SPAN afterÂ a Mechanicsville,
Va. rally for Sen. Ted Cruz.As Donald Trump has made explicit with his â€œMake
America Great Againâ€ campaign slogan, thereâ€™s also a desire to regain or
resurrect something that was lost. What might that be? One possibility is the
influence white voters used to have.Obama did well in 2012 in part because
black and Latino voters, who were his strongest supporters, comprised 29% of
the electorate.Â In this election almost one-in-three eligible voters is
projected to be a member of a minority group.Â At least 44% of the Latino
electorate are millennials, and 800,000 new Latino voters turnÂ 18 each
year**.**At the same time, relations between blacks and whitesÂ are eroding. In
2008, 70% of whites believed that relationships between the two racesÂ were
somewhat or very good, according to Gallup. By last year, after a sharp drop
over the last three years, that number had fallen to 45%.When an NPR reporter
asked Obama what he thinks is â€œbothering people,â€ he replied: â€œIf you are
referring to specific strains in the Republican Party that suggest that
somehow I'm different, I'm Muslim, I'm disloyal to the country, etcâ€¦what I'd
say there is that that's probably pretty specific to me and who I am and my
background, and that in some ways I may represent change that worries
them.â€That change should not be what white voters worry about. They have
plenty in common with minorities when it comes to the economic issues at the
forefront of this election â€”too much in common for either voters or
politicians to be creating a racial divide by ignoring the anger roiling
minority communities.Yet the #blacklivesmatter movement, meant to shine light
on the reasons for that anger and to bring change, is not having a major
impact on either partyâ€™s contest. Part of that is rooted in its own lack of
cohesion. But part is because politicians have not been eager to focus on its
concerns.**POLICING THE USA:Â AÂ look at race, justice, media**Bernie Sanders
faced early protests for his lack of understanding of the movement. And while
Hillary Clinton was able to capitalize on her strong support among blacks,
police brutality has hardly been the centerpiece of her campaign. Thatâ€™s even
more true on the Republican side, despite a once huge field and months of
debates and interviews.Itâ€™s perhaps ironic that a conversation about police
brutality and discrimination has been overshadowed in an election year in
whichÂ the candidates have included an African American, two Latinos, a Jew and
a woman. Not even the two Latinos, running as historic firsts, have talked
muchÂ about discrimination.The presence of the #blacklivesmatter movement is
mostly felt these days in protests that some candidates are trying to hijack
for their own purposes. Trump has had protesters forcibly ejected from his
rallies.Â He sometimesÂ counters them by saying that all lives matter,Â an
attempt to reclaim the conversation about race from blacks and make it about
whites. He really doesn'tÂ need to do that. In this first election after our
first black president, it has already happened._Soledad O'Brien,Â an award-
winning producer, journalist, documentarianÂ and news anchor, is CEO of
Starfish Media Group. Follow her on TwitterÂ @soledadobrien.__In addition to
its own editorials, USA TODAY publishes diverse opinions from outside writers,
including ourÂ Board of Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to the
Opinion front page._
title: Soledad O'Brien: #Blacklivesfade on 2016 trail

INDIANAPOLIS â€”Â A 22-year-oldÂ arrested in connection with the death of an
Indiana toddler has been charged withÂ rape, murder, child molesting and a slew
of other charges, according to online court records.Kyle Parker of Spencer,
Ind., was arrested Thursday night after authorities found the body of 1-year-
oldÂ Shaylyn Ammerman of SpencerÂ in a remote area beside a tree about 10 miles
away near Gosport, Ind. She went missing Wednesday morning from her
grandparents' Spencer home.Parker was a friend of a friend who had visited the
house about a dozen times, even once rocking the child back to sleep when she
awoke in her crib, Tamera Morgan, Shaylyn's grandmother, has said.MorganÂ said
sheÂ put Shaylyn to bed in her crib around 8:30 p.m. ETÂ Tuesday but checked on
her throughout the night until about 1:30 a.m.Â Morgan lives in the residence
with her husband, Danny Morgan; and two grown sons, including Justin and Adam
Ammerman. Justin Ammerman is Shaylyn's father.Parker was visiting the home
that night, Tamera MorganÂ said. He and her sons were drinking and hanging
out.When TameraÂ Morgan woke up around 8 a.m. Wednesday, Shaylyn was gone, the
grandmother said.Â Police and crews searched the White River and rural Owen
CountyÂ for Shaylyn for two days before they found her body.Kyle Parker, 22, of
Spencer, Ind., is accused of killing a 1-year-old girl after he visited the
house of the child's father.Â (Photo: Owen County (Ind.) Jail)Prosecutors
allege that Parker removed Shaylyn from her crib, took her in his car and
started driving toward Gosport. But then he pulled over and brutally raped the
toddler before smothering her with a cloth in his vehicle.He then used bleach
to wipe down Shaylyn's body and poured it inside the dead girl, court papers
indicate.On Friday, aÂ forensic pathologist ruled that Shaylyn's death was
homicide by asphyxiation.Â Shaylyn hadÂ "numerous very apparent injuries
sustained in a sexual assault," the autopsy found, according to an affidavit
filed Monday.Forensic pathologist Donna Stewart of Louisville, who specializes
in pediatric autopsies with sexual battery and molestation, called it the
worst case of sexual trauma that she had seen in her career.Such horrific
cases of child abuse are fairly rare, said Sandy Runkle, director of Prevent
Child Abuse Indiana. Cases of neglect are more common."When things happen,
it's usually not a stranger," Runkle said. "Over 90% of the time,Â it's someone
aÂ child knows."The child's mother, Jessica Stewart, shared custody of Shaylyn
with Ammerman.Â She learned her child was missing when police came to her door,
according to news reports."I'm just devastated," Justin Ammerman said after
his daughter's body was found. On Friday, aÂ forensic pathologist ruled that
Shaylyn's death was homicide by asphyxiation.Parker â€”Â originallyÂ wasÂ arrested
on charges of failure to report a body, obstruction of justice and improper
disposal of a bodyÂ â€”Â appeared for Monday in Owen County Circuit CourtÂ via
video conference. Judge Lori Thatcher Quillen denied bail.Emotionless,Â Parker
said little, except to ask for a court-appointed lawyer and say he understood
the charges he faced.The affidavit reveals a horrifying conclusion to the two-
day search for Shaylyn, during which family members clung to hope that she
would be found safe.Crews used sonar equipment to plumb the depths of the
White RiverÂ and covered wide expanses of land in rural Owen County with all-
terrain vehicles.Â But not until Parker, who was questioned as were the others
in the home that night,Â agreed to show police on a map where Shaylyn layÂ did
the details of what happened to the girl began to come together.Parker was at
the Morgans' house because Adam Ammerman invited him over to drink and watch a
movie, court documents indicated.Sometime between 3 and 4 a.m. Adam Ammerman
awoke to the sound of the front door shutting. He opened his window and saw
Parker walking away carrying somethingÂ â€” and he thought he saw a foot dangling
in the darkness, the documents show.Friends of Parker say he showed up at
their Gosport home at around 3:40 a.m. Wednesday, pulling his car into their
garage and closing the door. He then came inside and began washing his
clothes, according to Indiana State Police detectives.The friends told police
that Parker was quiet and distantÂ and not acting like himself. They also told
detectives that Parker is attracted to girls ages 12 to 14.Parker initially
told investigators that he had left the Morgans' home between 12:30 and 1:15
a.m. and went straight to his friends in Gosport. But detectives talked with
Parker's stepfather to ask the man to talk to Parker about telling the
truth.The stepfather later told police that Parker confessed and said he acted
alone.When talking to investigators and showing themÂ on a map where Shaylyn's
body could beÂ found,Â Parker had implicated Adam Ammerman.Parker now alsoÂ is
charged with kidnapping, strangulation andÂ aggravated battery._FollowÂ Madeline
Buckley on Twitter:Â @Mabuckley88_

NEW YORKâ€”Leave it to my enthused 9-year old son Samuel to explain why he
thinks Oculus Rift is â€œso coolâ€ that he wants me to buy it for him.Â â€œIt makes
you feel like youâ€™re actually in a new world.â€Sam mentioned this after being
chased by (and spit at) by a dinosaur in a museum gallery, after encountering
an alien on some distant unidentified planet, and especially after driving a
virtual race car at high speeds.Almost two years to the day when Facebook CEO
Mark ZuckerbergÂ announced that the social networkÂ was spending $2 billion on a
hot virtual reality startup known as Oculus, the first of the highly
anticipated Oculus Rifts finally comeÂ to market Monday, with people who
preordered the VR system getting their units over the next several weeks.Iâ€™ve
gotten a chance to check out a review unit of Rift at home a couple of days
ahead of launch and, notwithstanding a few hiccups during set-up, was almost
as thrilled as Sam and other friends and family members I showed it to.I would
likeÂ to spend more time with it before deciding whether the high price tag is
justified. But Oculus was an early hit in my house.**VR WAVE**Alternate and
mixed reality technologies areÂ poised for theÂ big time. Beside Oculus Rift,
the HTC Vive is on the way. Sony's PlayStation VR is coming in the fall.
Microsoft is pushing HoloLens, and Google isÂ looking to expand beyond
Cardboard, according to _The Wall Street Journal_. The early target market for
Oculus Rift are gamers, but there are other, broader experiences for those of
us more casual about gameplay.The Rift review unit arrived in an enormous box
along with an Oculus-ready PC and LCD monitor from Asus. The PC (sold
separately from the $599Â Oculus headset)Â supplies the requisite horsepower and
graphics capabilities to make Rift work.Thatâ€™s a big difference in the gear
required forÂ the $99 Samsung Gear VR headset which Oculus also powers, where
you supply theÂ select Samsung smartphones you snap into the headset.While I
like Gear VR and suspect more people will try it than Rift based on price
alone, the Rift experience is far more engrossing and comfortable. Excellent
audioÂ enhances the realism.Oculus Rift sensorÂ (Photo: Edward C. Baig)**WHAT
YOU GET**RiftÂ consists of the headset, sensor, remote control and Xbox
wireless controller, plus all the required cables to tether it to the PC. An
adventureÂ game called Lucky's Tale is bundled (as is Eve:Valkyrie Founder's
Pack for those preordered Rift).Â An optional Touch controller I've previously
tried out to play virtual ping-pong and tetherball has been delayed until the
second half of the year.Bundles where you can get Rift plus an Oculus Ready PC
start at $1499. My test system (without the price of the monitor) costs closer
to $2,000.The computer features high end graphics from Nvidia, required so the
games youÂ playÂ won't stutter or make you feel uncomfortable.**SET-UP**Among
the installation challenges is to find a clear enough space in your home in
which to enjoy the VR experience. Youâ€™re often standing up and walking around
a bit. The 4-meter custom headset cable and 2 Â½ meter sensor cable that tether
the Rift to the computer are plenty long enough, but you can easily lose your
bearings.Â I occasionally bumped into physical objects or watched others do
so.Speaking of watching others, itâ€™s fun to gauge peopleâ€™s reactionsâ€”you can
see what theyâ€™re seeing (minus the thrills) on the PC screen.As part of the
setup, you choose a profile picture, pick privacy settings, supply credit card
information, evenÂ add your height (to help the sensor with calibration). The
Oculus remote and sensor werenâ€™t immediately recognized and I had to summon
help from the company.I also had to fiddle a bit with the headset to focus and
get a proper fitâ€”I felt a bit of pressure on the bridge of my nose. Before
long, though, I donned the headgear, pulled the attached (but removable)
headphones over my ears, grabbed the remote and was good to go.Oculus Rift and
Oculus RemoteÂ (Photo: Edward C. Baig)**ENTER OCULUS**You're initially taken to
the Oculus Home virtual environment, a large handsomely-decorated loft-like
space. You can walk onto a sizable area rug that has books and pillows on it
and is crumpled in one corner.As you look in front of you, you can move your
head to position a pointer onto an icon for the Oculus Store, which promises
more thanÂ 30 games at launch.Youâ€™ll also see an icon for the Library, where
the apps youâ€™ve already downloaded reside. Some games require Internet access,
some donâ€™t, and some are multiplayer.One annoying feature: on some of the apps
IÂ started installingÂ through the headset, I hadÂ to complete the processÂ on the
PC. Some downloads are large and take awhile.You can launch menus and apps
while wearing the headset via the Oculus remote or the Xbox Controller, the
latter of which is required for some games. You don't need an Xbox
itself.**TENNIS, DREAMDECK, RACING**I started out exploring some of the
experiences in Oculus Dreamdeck and was freaked out when I found myself on an
exposed platform near the top of a skyscraperâ€”Iâ€™m afraid of heights and it was
all-too-real.I was more relaxed at center court in a fun game called VR Tennis
Online, even though I couldnâ€™t win a point off my virtual opponent.And I
enjoyed travelingÂ through the bloodstream learning about cells and such inside
The Body VR, which Oculus describes as one of the experimental â€œconceptsâ€ that
are on the cutting edge of VR.Project Cars in actionÂ (Photo: Oculus)Alas, I
didnâ€™t fare as well as Samuel driving on the Scottish race track Bannochbrae
Road Circuit inside a game called Project Cars. Not only was my driving lousy,
but afterwards I felt a bit nauseous.Samâ€™s reaction was very different and
portends a positive reception for Oculus: â€œOh my God, this is awesome, this is
sick!â€Email: ebaig@usatoday.com; Follow USA TODAY Personal Tech Columnist
@edbaig on Twitter**The bottom line**Oculus Rift$599 for Rift; $1499 on up for
Rift and Oculus-Ready PC bundles;Â www.oculus.comPro. Very cool engaging and
immersiveÂ experienceCon. Pricey. Requires robust PC with high end graphics and
open space. Few setup hassles.

content: **Spoiler alert! The following contains spoilers for _The Walking Dead_ season 6, episode 1 "East." To read our recap of episode 14, click _here_.**â€œYouâ€™ll be alright.â€Thatâ€™s what we hear Dwight say after he shoots Daryl. Itâ€™s not clear who heâ€™s talking to, or why heâ€™s saying it, as itâ€™s after the screen goes black, but he might as well have been saying it to all of us. Youâ€™ll be alright, because even though you think it canâ€™t, _The Walking Dead_ can go on without its favorite son.Letâ€™s get this over with right away -- after the Great Glennâ€™s Not Dead Fiasco of 2015, there is _bound_ to be speculation -- and say that, given the information in this episode, Daryl is gravely injured and possiblydead. We all just saw it. We saw someone shoot him in what looked like his chest or neck from point-blank range. We saw the blood spatter. It hit the camera lens. We heard the sound of the body drop. Minus some insane Glenn-like shenanigans (which we are not ruling out entirely), Daryl Dixon could be very much gone.Now you might be saying, heâ€™s only shot, weâ€™re not sure heâ€™s dead, maybe he can recover. Iâ€™ll remind you that the show very pointedly killed off its doctor last week. Iâ€™ll remind you that Dwight is not likely to want to get Daryl medical attention. Iâ€™ll remind you that they are far from Alexandria, and Glenn, Michonne and Rosita are captive and Rick and the rest donâ€™t know where they are. But, this show has showed a marked disregard for actual stakes when it comes to their truly mainÂ characters.This, by the way, is the biggest problem with the Glenn guessing game last fall. It wasnâ€™t that the show strung us along about Glenn specifically, it was that allowing him to survive the impossible makes us believe anyone can survive the impossible. And we will continue to do so. Even as I saw the blood hit the camera lens, I was unwilling to believe the show had really done this. I watched it over and over again just to make sure I saw what I saw. And yet, even as I try to convince you that he might beÂ dead or die soon, a small part of me is not convinced the show would ever really do this.That said, if Daryl ends up being alive, it will actual be kind of sad for the show, since it will beÂ impossible to believe any character on this show ever even _could_ die in the future. So as much as we love him, and as much as we wish the show hadnâ€™t taken away one of its strongest characters, he needs to be truly dead. Or someone needs to die at the hands of Negan and the Saviors.Â Because _The Walking Dead_ will lose so much more if people keep beingÂ magically alive.NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!Â (Photo: Gene Page, AMC)Carolâ€™s plan to leave in order to prevent herself from adding to her long list of killsÂ isnâ€™t working out so well thus far. In what appears to be just hours after she left, she comes across some Saviors on the road that she has to dispense with. In true Carol fashion, the deed is done quickly and efficiently (although not as thoroughly as it might have been in the past, she did miss one who may become a problem later). Once more the rosary sheâ€™s been bumming around with has come to good use, as well as her ability to come off as a meek and fearful victim.But as great a fighter as she is, her sojourn did not solve her problem of killing too much. Her conscience is still nagging her, and not having someone to fight for didnâ€™t stop the death. Because she at the very least always has herself to fight for. Â But all that may be moot, anyway, considering the final seconds of this episode. We doubt much could keep Carol and her knives away from the man who attacked Daryl.Morgan has been espousing a very different philosophy and morality from the rest of our survivors for awhile, and itâ€™s surprising that it took this long for him and Rick to truly hash it out. But they did, and with significantly less violence than when Carol and Morgan had the same conversation. Morgan fesses up to keeping the Wolf alive, but argues that it all happened for a reason (since he later saved Denise who later saved Carl). Rick is incredulous, but a little more moved by Morgan than we would have guessed. After the pair encounters what seems like yet another Savior (really charismatic leader, this Negan guy, huh?) on their hunt for Carol, Morgan convinces Rick to just leave. To stop killing (at least in that moment, not forever). To just wait and let him do the dirty work and find Carol. To go home to the people he loves.Too bad now that Rick finally has someone to come home to, sheâ€™s not there.What is the point, I ask you, of living in the most secure location in the post-apocalypse, if youâ€™re just going to up and leave all the time? We now have two deaths in as many episodes that could have easily, _easily_ been prevented by the respective people simply not wandering past the gate. Did Denise _need_ to go check out that apothecary? No, someone else could have or they could have lived without the medical supplies. Did Daryl _need_ to go on an avenging rampage after her? No, he really, really didnâ€™t. Especially not when his friends and family begged him not to.But he did. And Glenn and Michonne and Rosita went after him. And he had one chance to change his mind and go back and prevent all of this. But still, he made the rash, emotional decision to go and try to fix what he feels was his grave mistake. And then Glenn and Michonne were captured after following him into what are clearly Savior-controlled woods. And then even before he and Rosita were able to stage a rescue attempt (like Abraham last week), Dwight had a gun to his head. And then? We're not totally sure. But whatever it truly was, it wasn't good for Daryl.Like I said above, we donâ€™t know everything, and manyÂ signs point to Darylâ€™s death. It would beÂ a shame for us, as he isÂ one of the most interesting and fully-drawn characters the show has ever offered. Itâ€™s a shame for the show, as it would certainly feel the lack of Norman Reedusâ€™ presence in every episode after this. But if Daryl is truly dead or dies soon, we know one thing for sure: The war with the Saviors is only just beginning.Super great time for Maggie to be screaming in pain and clutching her stomach, right? That's definitely a good thing?Here's to hoping the season finale next week offers up some answers.
title: â€˜The Walking Deadâ€™ recap: Everybody dies

Syracuse is heading to the Final Four. Normally, that would never be a
surprise in college basketball. Jim Boeheim has led the Orange to five Final
Fours. But this wasnâ€™t a normal season for Syracuse.The Orange didnâ€™t deserve
to make the NCAA tournament, and now theyâ€™re two wins away from cutting down
the nets in Houston.Usually a bubble team can ride a win streak and momentum
into the NCAA tournament and maybe go on a Cinderella-like run. Not Syracuse.
Not these Orange. Boeheimâ€™s team lost five of their final six regular season
games including a 72-71 loss to Pitt in the ACC tournament.This was a team
that played a weak non-conference schedule (ranked No. 188 according to
Kenpom) and had no non-conference road wins. It wasnâ€™t a tournament team.But
come Selection Sunday, the Orange were rewarded with a No. 10 seed â€” not even
a play-in team. Even Boeheim was surprised.The biggest gift of all though came
in the Orangeâ€™s path to Houston. They handled the Atlantic 10â€™s Dayton in the
first round. Thanks to the stunning 15-2 upset of Michigan State, Syracuse
played No. 15 seed Middle Tennessee State in the second round.The Sweet 16
wasnâ€™t much tougher as the Orange lucked into a matchup with fellow-bubble
team Gonzaga. It wasnâ€™t until the Elite Eight that the Orange faced a
challenging opponent in a Virginia. Syracuse played Virginia in a 73-65 road
loss back in January. The familiarity was there. The belief was there.And at
the end of the day, Syracuse had no control over its NCAA tournament path.
Itâ€™s not their fault that upsets happen, but Syracuse fans should thank the
committee for the 2016 tournament.The Orange are more than Cinderella â€” they
won the lottery.Per @FiveThirtyEight, Syracuse started the tourney with less
than a 1% chance to win the title. pic.twitter.com/jP7gtmdymBâ€” Ben Baby

Nearly a year ago, officials from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
said work was underway to create a health-hazard standard for lead in drinking
water, records from agency advisory groupÂ meetings show.Yet despite growing
public concern about high levels of lead coming out of taps in Flint, Mich.,
as well as at homes and schools in all 50 states, the EPA still hasnâ€™t
released results of computer models estimating what level of lead in water
poses a serious health threatÂ and should trigger localÂ health department help
for families.â€œPeople across the country and in Flint need to know what EPA
thinks the level is at which a household should consider taking action,â€ said
Tom Neltner, a member of the EPAâ€™s lead and copper work groupÂ and chemicals
policy director for the Environmental Defense Fund.â€œI think itâ€™s stuck within
the EPA decision-making,â€ Neltner said. â€œI think they have it. I think they
are arguing about it.â€EPA officials declined to grant an interview and didÂ not
answer USA TODAY NETWORKÂ questions about why the analysisÂ is taking so long
andÂ what deadlines agency leadership has set to ensure timely progress.â€œEPA is
analyzing data on lead exposure, blood lead level models and exposure
pathways," the agency said in an emailed statement. "Once the agency has a
scientifically robust analysis, and completes internal agency reviews, we
intend to seek external peer review.â€The EPA hasn't begun an internal review
yetÂ because, among other things,Â itÂ stillÂ is evaluating approaches that at
least five offices within the agency use for predicting a person'sÂ blood-lead
levelÂ based on exposures, the statement said. The goal is for the level to be
included in a packageÂ of regulatory proposals the agency expects to publish
sometime in 2017.Current EPA regulations do not include a health-hazard
standard for lead in drinking water. In regulating water systems, the EPA has
set what it calls an â€œaction levelâ€ for lead of 15 parts per billion to
trigger water-treatment actions if more than 10% of faucets sampled exceed
that level.But the number is only an engineering standard that, when it was
set in 1991, was considered to be the lowest amount of lead in water that
systems could achieve reliablyÂ through adding anti-corrosion chemicals.â€œRight
nowÂ people are using the current action level as if it had meaning for health,
even though it is not based on health,â€ NeltnerÂ saidSome studies have
documented harm from drinking water contaminated at far lower levels. The EPA
and the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention both say lead in
drinking water is not safe at anyÂ concentration.The EPA has set a maximum
contaminant goal of zero for lead in drinking water.Â The goal is not
enforceable, and experts say it also is impossible to achieve because millions
of U.S. homes receive water that passes through lead pipes and
plumbing.WithoutÂ a health-hazard level,Â the public and water systemsÂ can't put
lead test results in any context or know when immediate action is needed, said
Marc Edwards, the Virginia Tech water engineering expert whose team has
independently investigated Flintâ€™s contamination issues.In this Feb. 25, 2016
file photo, signs warn not to drink the lead contaminated water from a water
fountain at Woodside Church in Flint, Mich.Â (Photo: Jacquelyn Martin, AP)â€œYou
have to have some level that requires people to know when their health is in
danger,â€ Edwards said. â€œWhatever they set, I think theyâ€™re fearful of the
fallout."People are measuring lead in schools again, and theyâ€™re getting
levels in the hundreds of parts per billion,â€ he said.This month,Â a USA TODAY
NETWORK investigation revealed that nearly 2,000 water systems serving about 6
million people have failed to meet the EPAâ€™s existing lead standard since
2012. About 350 of the failing systems are dedicated to serving schools and
dayÂ care centers, and about 600 of the systems had tests at some taps showing
lead levels topping 40 ppb, EPA enforcement data show."Your series has really
driven it home, more so than anyone else, how widespread this problem is,"
Edwards said. "EPA has to make a decision about some level of contamination
that poses a health threat."Meeting minutes from an EPA drinking water expert
advisory group indicateÂ agencyÂ staff made progress coming up with a health
hazard number last year and thought it might even be released by late 2015.As
of this past April, EPA staff told the lead and copper working group that the
agency had an existing computer model to help determine what level of lead in
a homeâ€™s tap water posed a serious health risk. Joyce Donohue of EPAâ€™s Office
of Science and Technology discussed factors that would need to be considered
in the modeling.At that time, the working group was in the process of drafting
recommendations for creation of a household action levelÂ for lead.The groupâ€™s
recommendationÂ was for the EPA to come up with a level of lead in drinking
water that posed a health danger to those considered.At greatest risk were
infants fed formula made with tap water, the group said. The modeling should
establishÂ a hazard level that would protect them from having dangerous levels
of lead in their blood.If a water test found lead above this household action
level,Â the group wanted public health experts notified so they could
investigate and help.In June, records show thatÂ members asked about the EPAâ€™s
progress in developing aÂ household action level, which EPA officials dubbed
HAL.Eric Burneson of the EPAâ€™s Office of Ground Water and Drinking Water
â€œindicated that EPA is working on establishing the HAL, but that it will take
some time because the HAL must undergo a peer review and quality assurance. It
may or may not be available for the full (advisory council) meeting in late
2015.â€ Burneson is the director of the water officeâ€™s standards and risk
management division.â€œNine months ago, EPA said it needed to complete quality
assurance and peer review before releasing a draft household action level,â€
Neltner said.But he said he believes that theÂ EPA has an obligation as a
public health agency to release information about a hazard level as quickly as
possible."It makes no sense to wait for rulemaking to help parents who must
decide whether to invest in a filter for the water they use to make up their
childâ€™s infant formula," he said.The lead and copper working group is part of
the EPAâ€™s National Drinking Water Advisory Council, which in DecemberÂ formally
sent numerous recommendations to the agency, including for theÂ creation of the
household action level. Jill Jonas, advisory council chairwoman and the
drinking water chief for the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources,
declined to be interviewed.In wake of the crisis in Flint, Mich., concern is
growing about lead in drinking water across the USA.Â (Photo: Juri Samsonov,
Getty Images)Several of the experts who served on the advisory council's
16-member lead and copper working group were traveling, unavailable or
declined to be interviewed.June SwallowÂ of the Rhode IslandÂ Department of
HealthÂ said through a spokespersonÂ that she doesnâ€™t recall the EPA committing
to a particular time frame for developing the health-action level. Evaluating
how long it should take â€œis not her area of expertise,â€Â she said.Leon Bethune
of the Boston Public Health Commission, declined to be interviewed about the
EPA's progress developing the action level.Â Through aÂ spokesperson, he issued
a statement:Â â€œIt wasÂ a great experience meeting with the folks from health
departments and water utilities from around the country, using our own
experiences, knowledge and research to come to consensus on how to improve the
lead and copper rule.â€Another working group member, Lynn Thorp of the advocacy
group Clean Water Action, said in an interview the EPA indicated last year
that agency staff were working to create the household-action level.â€œI donâ€™t
know why it hasnâ€™t come out yet,â€ Thorp said. â€œIf there is a gap in public
health and exposure science or other data that we need to answer this
question, then we need to know that so there can be public support for
government agencies undertaking that work.â€From at least 2002Â intoÂ 2004,
archived webpages show the EPAâ€™s website said a lead concentration of 40 ppb
or moreÂ in drinking waterÂ was cause for "immediate action."Â  At that level,
the water posed an â€œimminent and substantial endangerment to the health of
children and pregnant women.â€The agency acknowledged the level was on its
website for several yearsÂ butÂ told the USA TODAY NETWORKÂ itÂ never was formally
adopted and hadn't undergone peer review. The EPAÂ removed references to the 40
ppb hazard levelÂ during an earlier lead-contaminated water crisis in the
District of Columbia._Read the USA TODAY NETWORK's "Beyond Flint"
investigation of lead contamination in water nationwideÂ at
lead.usatoday.com__Follow investigative reporter Alison Young on Twitter:
@alisonannyoung_
title: EPA delay in releasing danger level for lead in water raises questions

"Parents took from small children."PEZ Candy abruptly canceled its annual
Easter egg hunt in Orange, Conn., on Saturday morning after parents disobeyed
rules and turned the child-focused tradition "into a mess," the company said
in a statement."We sincerely tried our best to create a fun, free activity for
everyone to enjoy. Due to the actions of a few, the good intent quickly turned
into a mess." PEZ wrote in response to a critical comment on its Facebook
page. "We only wanted to do good for the local community."One parent said her
son got a bloody nose from another parent pushing him to the ground, while a
third claimed her son's Easter basket was broken in the rush, theÂ _Hartford
Courant _reported.Orange Police said they did not respond to the event.PEZ
said it had over 9,000 eggs on three separate fields, each of which was
designated for a particular age group with start times 15 minutes apart, but
parents rushed onto the fields before the posted start times."Somebody pushed
me over and take my eggs and it's very rude of them and they broke my bucket,"
4-year-old Vincent Welch toldÂ NBC Connecticut."Unfortunately people chose to
enter the first field prior to anyone from PEZ staff starting the activity,"
PEZ explained."The crowd moved to the 2nd field, waited for only a couple of
minutes and proceeded to rush the field without being directed to do so and
before the posted start time. The crowd then immediately moved to the 3rd
field and took over and removed everything well before the activity was to
even start."PEZ says it scrambled to reach as many visitors as possible, to
make sure each child got an egg or candy."We made efforts to get everyone
something before they left and passed out tons of candy and coupons and the
front entry and tried to make the best of an unfortunate situation," PEZ
wrote. "This was not something created to frustrate or make people angry."Now
people are flocking to the PEZ Candy USA Facebook page to criticize the adults
and support the company."Grow up folks and teach your kids some responsibility
by acting like mature adults not rabid dogs," Don Bistro wrote on the
company's page."PEZ didn't do this," Nicole Arleen wrote on Facebook. "It was
the 'looting'Â mentality of the parents who thought they could get as much as
they wanted, no matter what the cost. If this event goes on for a fourth year,
PEZ should not have to hire security personnel to keep the parents in
check."#amuhrca, that 3rd-world country where adults will trample children in
an Easter egg hunthttps://t.co/VBRKeHI8JK"PEZ I hope you don't stop doing
these Easter events due to bad parents," Yasmin Kalish wrote. "It's not your
company's fault but the fault of selfish, greedy adults whose kids have to be
#1."Others did blame PEZ."Thanks for the waste of time and non-existent
organization of your egg hunt ... We drive 2 and a half hours to show up 30
min early only to receive a 'sorry, no one listened and they started early,'"
â€Liz Soares wrote on PEZ's page. "I'm sorry your establishment was so poor
with planning that they apologize for children not listening instead of being
unprepared for such [an] event."Pushy parents spoil @PEZofficial Easter egg
event in Orange
https://t.co/SZFl4gJxQepic.twitter.com/vhDiHfsCRD_Contributing: Greg Toppo,
USA TODAY_

Belgian authorities on Monday charged three people detained duringÂ Sunday's
raids with participating in terrorist activities, but a judge released another
suspect,Â according to state media and the Associated Press.Prosecutors ordered
the three â€” identified as Yassine A., Mohamed B. and Aboubaker O. â€”Â be held on
terrorism-related charges, according to broadcaster RTBF.The authorities said
the trioÂ were part of a group of nine people who were rounded up Sunday during
a series of raids across Belgium. Five of them were released later Sunday, and
authorities said Monday that the sixth remaining detainee was released without
charges,Â RTBF reported.AÂ man known as Faycal C., who was detainedÂ in
connection with theÂ attacks,Â has been released by a judge. The Belgian federal
prosecutor's office said the judge found no evidence to justify holding the
man identified in news reports as Fayal Cheffou,Â who faced preliminary charges
ofÂ â€œinvolvement in a terrorist group, terrorist murder and attempted terrorist
murder.â€Raids have occurred almost daily since last Tuesday'sÂ suicide bombings
at Brussels' main airport and a subway station near the headquarters of the
European Union. At least four Americans died in the attacks.OnÂ Monday, Belgian
health minister Maggie De Block said four of those wounded in theÂ attacks have
died atÂ the hospital, bringing the number of dead to 35.The Brussels Airport
remains closed. Eight hundred staff members are due toÂ testÂ the temporary
infrastructure and passenger check-in system Tuesday to determine whether the
airport can partially reopen. Belgian government officials must approve the
new passenger service arrangements."The simple fact is that a restart in the
short term is not possible in the devastated infrastructure," the airport
staff said in aÂ news release on the airport's website.Before the bombings,
Brussels Airport served aboutÂ 600 flights a day and 23.5 million passengers
per year.Meanwhile, the website of Belgiumâ€™s Federal Police on Monday began
carrying a 32-second video of a mysterious man in a hat suspected of having
taking part in the airport bombing, according to the AP.â€œThe police are
seeking to identify this man,â€ the site says.The video shows the man, wearing
glasses and a white jacket, wheeling a baggage cart through the airport along
with the two men identified by Belgian authorities as the bombers.Police did
not say why they had released the video._The Associated Press and USA TODAY's
Matthew Diebel contributed to this report._

BLOOMINGTON, Ind.Â â€”Â Back in 1978, Luke Gillespie was aÂ jazz musician and
educator in David Baker's officeÂ at Indiana UniversityÂ and saw the Miles Davis
LP _Kind of Blue_Â on the turntable. It looked worn and scratched, like it was
played over and over, Gillespie said.â€œWow,â€ Gillespie said to Baker, his
teacher. "You have gotten a lot of mileage out of this record.â€Baker's reply,
Gillespie said, changed his life."Yeah, that's my seventh copy," Baker told
him.Gillespie, a professor in the IU Jacobs School of Music andÂ performer of
jazz and classical piano music,Â surmised that Baker would have had to play the
vinyl record hundreds, or even thousands, of times, before the grooves became
too worn to allow the needle to stay within the line.And BakerÂ was on his
seventh copy.It was a moment, Gillespie said, that for him, encapsulates
Baker's influence as an educator."I thought I had listened a lot, but I had
never listened enough to wear out even one record," Gillespie said.Â "I
realized that I hadn't really listened as much as I needed to really absorb
the music."Baker, a renowned jazz performerÂ and composer,Â died Saturday,
colleagues and friendsÂ confirmed. He was 84.Baker wasÂ a professor at the IU
music schoolÂ and founder of its Jazz Studies program.An Indianapolis native,
Baker racked up numerous awards during an illustrious musical career that
began early in his timeÂ as a student at Crispus Attucks High School in the
1940s, when, according to a 2008 _IndianapolisÂ Star_ report, he would "sneak
into the smoky clubs of Indiana Avenue to soak up the atmosphere."At Crispus
Attucks, Baker cultivated a love of jazz."We went toÂ AttucksÂ at a time that
was very exciting. There was a great tradition of jazz already there by then,"
Baker said in 2008.Â "We had the creme de la creme of mentors â€” a large music
department of maybe four, five teachers. In retrospect, it was seemingly the
best of all possible worlds."Baker was an aspiring trombone player then, but
he would grow to be a Grammy-nominated artist with more thanÂ 1,000
compositions. He took up the cello after a car accident injured muscles in his
face.Among Bakerâ€™s honors are becoming an Indiana Living Legend in 2001, an
NEA Jazz Master in 2000, a Grammy nominee in 1979 and Pulitzer Prize nominee
in 1972.He taught and performed throughout the United States, Canada, Europe,
Australia, New Zealand and Japan, according to Baker's retirement biography,
written by Gillespie. He also co-founded the Smithsonian Jazz Masterworks
Orchestra, Gillespie said.Baker foundedÂ IU's Jazz Studies program after he was
hired at the school of music in 1966. He received a bachelor's and master's
degree in music education at IU."He kind of opened my eyes to a lot of
different things," said Rob Dixon, a jazz saxophonist who studied under Baker.
"When he said something, you would perk up, when he said,Â 'Listen to Sonny
Rollins;Â check out Joe Henderson.'"Brent Wallarab, a professor at IU's music
schoolÂ  and a trombone player, said Baker was an educator who had the ability
to see talents in students before they saw it themselves."He always had that
intuitive sense," said Wallarab, who studied under Baker first in 1987 and
continued a long professional relationship with him. "From the very beginning,
he seemed to see things in me as a young musician that IÂ hadn't even
recognized. He was able to provide opportunities that were kind of designed to
help me see my potential."Baker is survived by his wife, Lida Belt Baker;
daughter, April (Brad) Ayers; granddaughter, Kirsten (Nick) Bartalone; former
wife, Eugenia Baker; nephews David Michael Crawford (Dawn) and Kim Crawford;
great-nephews Elijah, Greyson and Trey Crawford; and great-nieces Temeley and
Tanzyn Crawford, according to an Indiana University press
release._Contributing: Dave Lindquist contributed to this story. Follow
Madeline Buckley on Twitter:Â _@Mabuckley88_._

I went to Stanford, and I voted for Donald Trump. So did my husband. He went
to Yale.And so we spent more than three hours standing in line in Washington,
D.C., to vote in theÂ Republican presidential caucus on March 12. We suspected
that this would be time spent quixotically, as Washington is theÂ bull's-eye of
the anti-Trump GOP political and intellectual establishment. Sure enough,
establishment favorite Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida won the majority of the
delegates, and Trump finished a poor third. Even so, we wanted to be part of
the nationwide rebellion against theÂ establishment that has resulted in
Trumpâ€™s becoming the clear GOP front-runner practically everywhere else in
America. And we werenâ€™t alone. Trump is actually enjoying surprisingly strong
support among highly educated people like us â€” and for good reason.The common
wisdom is that the majority of Trumpâ€™s supporters are barely literate knuckle-
draggers. Theyâ€™re â€œlow-information,â€ in the words of Trumpâ€™s leading GOP rival
nationwide, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas. And itâ€™s true that the largest education-
level cohort among the Republicans who have consistently given Trump a double-
digit lead in the primaries consists of people with high-school educations or
less.But in Massachusetts, home of Harvard and MIT and ranked as the No. 1
statefor residents possessing at least a bachelorâ€™s degree,Â a CNN exit poll
for the March 1 GOPÂ primary showed Trump winning over 46% of voters with
college degrees and even edging out Ohio â€œmoderateâ€ Gov. John Kasich (29% to
28%) among voters with postgraduate sheepskins. Exit polls in other states
show similar resultsFor nearly 25 years â€” since President George H.W. Bush
lost his bid for a second term in 1992 â€”Â the Republican Party has been unable
to field a presidential candidate who could excite enough of its own party
members to the ballot box so as to win a majority of the popular vote. (In the
lone exception, George W. Bush squeaked by with 50.7%Â in 2004 in a patriotic
surge afterÂ 9/11.) The main reason: the GOP establishmentâ€™s suicidally
inexplicable but intractable commitment to â€œcomprehensive immigration reformâ€
(amnesty for 11 million illegal immigrants and continued mass migration) and
so-called free trade.Voters of both political parties cite the U.S. economy,
faltering since 2008, as one of their top concerns. And Republican voters can
see perfectly well that it makes no sense to import aroundÂ 400,000 illegal
immigrants annually, the vast majority of them unskilled, into a labor market
where, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the real unemployment rate
is close to 10% if you count people who have given up looking for work because
they canâ€™t find it, or who are working part-time because they need the money
but would prefer to work full-time. Furthermore, only the most Pollyanna-ish
of economists would argue that unlimited immigration in a weak economy doesnâ€™t
depress wages.Free trade is an elegant concept in the 18thÂ century pages of
Adam Smithâ€™s _The Wealth of Nations_.Â The Portuguese export wine to Britain,
and the British export woolen goods to Portugal â€” a win-win situation, your
Econ 101 professor would say. In the real world of the 21st century, â€œfree
tradeâ€ means 25 yearsâ€™ worth of treaties and arrangements in which the U.S.
hews to the Smith playbook while China, for example, puts its thumb onto the
scales via rock-bottom wages, allegedly ignoredÂ labor violations, poison-level
air and water pollutionÂ and a manipulated currency. And free tradeÂ hasnâ€™t
exactly delivered Smithâ€™s promised export benefits to the U.S. We currently
run an almost $366Â billion trade deficit with China alone and a $484.1 billion
trade deficit worldwide.**POLICING THE USA:Â AÂ look at race, justice,
media**Iâ€™ve been a journalist by profession for more than three decades, and
my reporting trips have taken me on many occasions across the vast coast-to-
coast Rust Belt left behind as one U.S. company after another has outsourced
its manufacturing operations to low-wage havens abroad. Iâ€™ve seen the
construction industry, once a decentlyÂ paying bulwark for skilled working
class American men without much educational aptitude, turned over to non-
English-speaking illegal immigrants toiling for labor contractors at under-
the-table wages a fraction of what on-the-books employees make. The Republican
establishmentâ€™s response to this has been pathetic: a â€œreformiconâ€ agenda of
using the refundable earned-income tax credit to hand out welfare to the
displaced American workers.Trump promises to turn America into a country that
does what nations ought to do: Put the interests of its own citizens first.
Thatâ€™s why he hasÂ promised to build a wall along our southern border and to
change our tariff practices to comport with export-import reality. He has also
managed to grow the Republican Party, apparently generating record primary
turnouts and inspiring thousands of onetime Democrats to switch to the GOP.
Thatâ€™s why my husband and I will be casting our ballots for Trump in November
should he become the Republican nominee. Some would call that â€œanger.â€ I call
it â€œhope.â€_Charlotte Allen is a writer in Washington, D.C. Follow her on
Twitter:Â _@MeanCharlotte_In addition to its own editorials, USA TODAY
publishes diverse opinions from outside writers, including ourÂ Board of
Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to theÂ Opinion front page._

LAHORE, Pakistan â€” Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif vowed in a televised address
Monday to hunt down and defeat militants who carry out attacks like the Easter
bombing that targeted Christians andÂ killed 72 people.â€œWe will not allow them
to play with the lives of the people of Pakistan,â€ an emotional Sharif said.
â€œThis is our resolve. This is the resolve of the 200 million people of
Pakistan."Terrorists should know that failure is their fate," addedÂ Sharif,
who canceled a visit to the United States for a nuclear summit this week. He
said the governmentÂ would redouble its efforts to crack down on extremists who
increasingly attack "softÂ targets" such as parks and schools.AÂ Taliban
splinter group Jamaat-ul-Ahrar claimed it carried out the suicide bombing
against Christians celebrating Easter in a park. Most of those killed were
Muslims, many of them women and children, who also were in Gulshan-e-Iqbal
park. About 300 people were wounded.Pakistani police commandos stand guard at
the suicide blast site in Lahore on March 28, 2016.Â (Photo: FAROOQ NAEEM,
AFP/Getty Images)Parts of Pakistan began three days of mourning Monday, with
many schools and markets closed as families began burying the dead."My son had
gone to the park to spend his Easter holiday with his best friends. Who could
have known that he wouldn't ever return?"Â said Parveez Masih, whose 16-year-
old son,Â Waqar, was killed in Sunday's bombing.Â The teen had wanted to show
off his new clothes and shoes and hang out with his buddies, his father
said.Ruksana Bhatti said her 13-year-old son Arun was injured in the blast.
"A bomb exploding doesn't see the religion of the people it hits, and Muslims
dying next to Christians is an example of that," she said. "Mosques, churches,
temples â€”Â nothing means anything to these terrorists. We all are equal as
targets for them."Some residents said the target for the attackÂ was
particularly brutal because free parks and other public spaces such as the zoo
in Lahore are magnets for the poor during holidays such as Eid, Easter and
Christmas, as well as on Sundays.â€œThere was a lot of rush in the park and
especially because of Easter â€”Â the local Christian community came to
celebrate," said Dawood Ali, 24, who suffered fractures to his leg and was
hospitalized. "My cousin was injured in the blast, but his other two Christian
friends died on the spot.â€â€œIt was a distressing sight to see parents look for
their kids in the dark after the blast," he added. "Everyone was looking for
their family members with no help."Some said the Christian community has long
been under threat and complained the government has not done enough to protect
it.â€œI blame the government for not taking the security risk on Easter
seriously," said Samuel Benjamin, a Christian rights activist in Lahore. â€œThe
group who attacked and claimed responsibility said it was an attack on
Christians."Pakistan has struggled with extremism for years, analysts say,
despite a crackdown after the December 2014 school attack by the Taliban that
killed 134 studentsÂ in theÂ northwestern city of Peshawar."Pakistan has not
addressed the extremist mindset nor has it cracked down on all terrorist
groups," said Husain Haqqani, Pakistanâ€™s former ambassador to the United
States and a senior fellow at Hudson Institute, a WashingtonÂ think tank. "Its
policy of selective crackdown accompanied by tolerating some and even
supporting other terrorist groups is only making things difficult. In Lahore,
the terrorists made it clear that they won't give up."
title: Pakistan prime minister vows to defeat terrorists, as nation mourns

content: **Spoiler alert: This story contains substantial details about â€œEast,â€ Sundayâ€™s episode of AMC's _The Walking Dead_.**Blood sometimes seems to flow like water on _The Walking Dead_, so it can take something out of the ordinary to really jolt the audience.The end of Sundayâ€™s episode accomplished that, with blood flying into the viewerâ€™s face â€“Â or at least into the camera â€“ just before the picture wentÂ to black. The larger shock, however, is that the blood belongs to fan favorite Daryl Dixon (Norman Reedus), whose fate will remain unknown at least until next Sundayâ€™s Season 6 finale (AMC, 9 p.m. ET/PT).Reedus tells USA TODAY that thereâ€™s no sleight of hand in the tightly focused shot, which features Saviors enemy Dwight (Austin Amelio) sneaking up behindÂ Daryl, who is almost out of the frame, and shooting him when he turns around.â€œItâ€™s exactly what you see. Thatâ€™s (Darylâ€™s) blood that hits the camera. Thereâ€™s no trick there,â€ he says. As toÂ whether the shot kills Daryl, â€œYou donâ€™t know, but heâ€™s definitely not looking good.â€Saviors foe Dwight (Austin Amelio) has been a thorn in Daryl Dixon's side since they met earlier in Season 6 of AMC's 'The Walking Dead.'Â (Photo: Gene Page, AMC)Reedus, who appeared on the big screen this year in _Triple 9 _and stars with Diane Kruger in _Sky_ (April 15),Â suggests not reading too much into Dwightâ€™s post-shooting final words: â€œYouâ€™ll be alright.â€â€œYou donâ€™t know who heâ€™s talking to,â€ he says. â€œHe could be saying that to anyone there. Thereâ€™s other people standing there.â€Daryl and Dwight have been headed toward a deadly confrontation since they met earlier in the season, when Dwight and two female companions captured Daryl. Daryl regained control and considered inviting Dwight to join the survivors at Alexandria, before the Savior took Darylâ€™s signature crossbow and motorcycle at gunpoint.Dwightâ€™s rejection of compassion helped sourÂ Daryl on being open to outsiders. When Dwight uses the crossbow to kill Denise (Merritt Wever), it only strengthens Darylâ€™s resolve to destroy him, even if it means taking the risk of doing it on his own.â€œThat arrow to Deniseâ€™s head is something Daryl is not going to get over. â€¦ That was his arrow that went through her eye and killed her in front of him. He wants revenge,â€ Reedus says. â€œSometimes, when you think with your passion and your heart and not your brain, you put yourself in a situation that comes back to bite you in the (behind), which has happened to him at least twice with that guy.â€However, even Reedus is surprised Dwight got the drop on Daryl. â€œDaryl is an expert tracker and heâ€™s smarter than that, but he just wants revenge so badly that he let this guy sneak up on him and shoot him. I was shocked that that would happen to Daryl. But, when youâ€™re acting out of passion, sometimes you make a mistake. In that world, you canâ€™t make mistakes like that.â€Glenn (Steven Yeun) and Maggie (Lauren Cohan) were in different places in Sunday's episode of 'The Walking Dead,' but both were in trouble.Â (Photo: Gene Page, AMC)Daryl isnâ€™t the only one whose life hangs in the balance going into the season finale. Dwight and his fellow Saviors hold Michonne (Danai Gurira), Glenn (Steven Yeun) and Rosita (Christian Serratos) captive; a bloody trail is the only evidence of Carol (Melissa McBride); and pregnant Maggie (Lauren Cohan) is stricken by abdominal pains.â€œThereâ€™s absolutely nobody in the cast whoâ€™s untouchable,â€ Reedus says. â€œEveryone can go at any minute.â€And they havenâ€™t even met Savior boss Negan (Jeffrey Dean Morgan), a majorÂ character from _The Walking Dead _comic booksÂ whoÂ makes his much-anticipated debut in Sunday's season finale."I can say it's the most gut-wrenching episode we've ever done," ReedusÂ says.
