BRUSSELS â€”Â When staffers at the Hotel Thon deal with emergencies, it's usually
a guest losing a passport, burning themselves with a curling iron or a room
with an unmade bed.So when terrorists detonated explosives at the nearby
Maelbeek subway station on Tuesday, the hotel staff grabbed their first aid
kits and jumped in toÂ help.â€œWe have a small â€˜intervention team,â€™ which is
usually for a cook who cuts his finger,â€ hotel manager Hans Van der Biersen
said. â€œItâ€™s not for a major event like this.â€As Belgium continues to conduct
raids, make arrests and contact families of the victims, some unwitting first
responders continue to struggle with the aftermath, while trying to move
forward."It's not appropriate to say it's back to normal, because nothing will
be back to the way things were," Van der Biersen said. "But you try to go
on."Sunday, five days after the suicide bombings, the hotel is a quiet place.
Few rooms are booked, the dining room is mostly empty, and staff members
remember every detail of that day.Van der Biersen saidÂ he was at the reception
desk advising guests that the airports were closed because of the attacks
thereÂ when he heard anÂ explosionÂ at about 9:10 a.m. The staff grabbed the
first aid kits, towels and bottled water and rushed outside. TheyÂ knew it was
another attack.â€œWe realized the situation immediately because we knew about
the airport,â€ he said.Â â€œAt the time there was no one there from the official
authorities, so we did what we could.â€Emergency responders arriving at the
scene usedÂ the hotelÂ lobby as a triage center. Van der Biersen said 40 to 50
people with burns on their hands, arms and backs were treated at the Hotel
Thon.â€œIt was very disciplined, very calm â€¦ very quiet," he said. "I imagine it
was because everyone was in total shock. We just went into autopilot.â€Some
staff members said what happened began to sink in Wednesday, when authorities
allowed foot traffic back into the area so people could place flowers near the
station.â€œAt that moment, I had some tears,â€ Van der BiersenÂ said.Over the
weekend, the hotel's street reopened to cars, people strolled down the
sidewalk, and although the subway station remained closed, trains still ran on
the track.And next week, the hotel will haveÂ therapists come in to help
employees deal with the tragedy.For some, like Jean Sebastien Morelle, 18, a
hotel intern who was there, the attack was personal. He lost someone close to
him in the explosion.â€œI am not yet able to talk about it,â€ he said.
title: Hotel staff jumps into action after Brussels subway attack

If Oklahomaâ€™s Buddy Hield wasnâ€™t already a superstar, he certainly is now.The
Player of the Year favorite is on his way to the Final Four with Saturdayâ€™s
80-68 win over Oregon. But individually, Hield is in the midst of something
truly special. His 37-point performance against Oregon was a clinic that
showed just how lethal Hield is as an offensive force.Hield is the Steph Curry
of this NCAA tournament, and with two more wins, heâ€™ll surpass Curryâ€™s
breakout 2008 tournament run.As a team, the Sooners already have.In case you
werenâ€™t into college basketball back in 2008, a little-known, babyfaced guard
for No. 10 seed Davidson grabbed the NCAA tournament spotlight. Curryâ€™s 2008
run was everything we love about March Madness. With scoring games of 40, 30,
33 and 25, he led the Wildcats to the Elite Eight.He scored 40 points in the
first round against No. 7 seed Gonzaga with 30 points coming in the second
half. He did to Gonzaga what he currently does to NBA teams on a regular
basis, which made these highlights so fun to watch.Hield is that sort of
player for Oklahoma.Yes, the Sooners entered the tournament as a popular Final
Four pick, but to get there, Hield had to be on his game. But not many
expected Hield to overwhelm his opponents to the degree that he has en route
to the Final Four. Heâ€™s scored 27, 36, 17 and 37 points in his tournament
games. Heâ€™s made 47.5 percent of his 3s, and heâ€™s shot 56.7 percent from the f
loor.![hield_curry](https://usatftw.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/hield_curry1.p
ng?w=1000&h=499)Where Davidson had a great one-two punch with Curry and Jason
Richards, Oklahoma has far too many weapons to put all the attention on Hield.
So, when a team defends Hield well (which isnâ€™t often), Jordan Woodard or
Isaiah Cousins are more than capable of making teams pay. Hield finds space so
well off screens â€” it really is a nightmare.But letâ€™s say a team can stick
with him through all of that, Hield is capable of making the contested 3 with
consistency. Oregon learned that the hard way, as he was able to knock down
eight 3s â€” many of which were defended well.Buddy Hield made 8 threes today.

(@marchmadness) March 27, 2016Very few players can get on a roll like Hield
has in the NCAA tournament. Kemba Walkerâ€™s 2011 run was up there, but he shot
32 percent from the field in the Final Four and title game. Curry took 90
field-goal attempts through the Elite Eight. Hield has taken 67, and their
tournament scoring averages are nearly identical.Many compare Hield to Kobe
Bryant, and Bryant was in the crowd watching Hield put on a show in Anaheim.
But Kobe didnâ€™t play college basketball. Hield and Curry were both four-year
players. Theyâ€™ve both been underrated from NBA draft experts.But only one has

_Correction:Â An earlier version of this story mischaracterizedÂ the racial
make-up of Hawaii. According to the Census Bureau, the state is 37.5% Asian,
26.7% white, 23% two or more races, 10% native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, 2.5%
black and 0.4% American Indian/Alaska native._Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders
claimed political momentum in the Democratic presidential race Sunday after
scoring lopsidedÂ victories in Saturday caucuses in Alaska, Hawaii and
Washington State.But delegateÂ math continued to favor rival Hillary Clinton as
the campaign headed toward the Wisconsin primary on April 5 and the New York
primary on April 19. The former secretary of State now leads Sanders among
pledged delegates by 1,243 to 975, according to the Associated Press. When
unpledged "superdelegates" are included, her lead stretches to 1,712 to 1,004.
Needed for nomination: 2,383."We have won five of the six last contests in
landslide fashion," Sanders said on NBC's _Meet the Press_, then referred to
himself in the third person.Â "I think a lot of the superdelegates are now
beginning to look at which Democratic candidate is the best place to defeat
Donald Trump. I think some of them are beginning to understand that it's
Bernie Sanders."With all precincts reporting, Sanders trounced Clinton by
81.6%-18.4% in Alaska; 69.8%-30%Â in Hawaii, andÂ 72.7% to 27.1% in Washington
State.Â Democratic rules require that delegates be allocated proportionately,
making it harder for Sanders to make up the deficit he faces against Clinton
than under GOP rules that allow winner-take-all contests.All three states held
caucuses, the sort of partisanÂ contest in whichÂ Sanders has been boosted by
the enthusiasm of his supporters and their willingness to turn out to
participate. Of the 14 states Sanders has won so far, 10 were caucuses; four
were primaries. In the three states that voted Saturday, less than 5% of the
population in each are African-Americans, the voters who have given Clinton
her biggest marginÂ of victory.Looking ahead, just two of the remaining state
contests are caucuses, in Wyoming and North Dakota, and the big primaries
ahead include statesÂ such as New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, where more
than one in 10 residents are black.Sanders predicted he would "do well" in
Wisconsin, which holds the next primary on April 5, and has "a real shot in
New York," which holds its primary on April 19, "and then we go out to
California." The Golden State votes on June 7, the final big primary day.That
signaled his determination to stay in the race until the end, and he rebuffed
questions about what it would take for him to endorse Clinton. "I hope very
much, Chuck, that you will be asking her that question," he said to NBC's
Chuck Todd.Sanders defended his increasingly caustic tone toward his rival.
"Secretary Clinton has super PACS; she has raised some $15 million at least
from Wall Street, money from the fossil fuel industry and the drug companies,"
he said on ABC's _This Week_. "Do I think the American people need to know
that? Is that an important issue? I think it is. Our votes on the war: I voted
against the war in Iraq. She voted for the war in Iraq. That's an important
issue."On NBC, Sanders said he had "a little bit of concern" that Clinton
would not participate in more debates. In February, the two campaigns agreed
to add four debates to the original schedule, including a New Hampshire debate
that took place in February and a debate in Flint, Mich., that took place this
month.The Clinton campaign didn't immediately respond to a request for
comment."I would hope very much that as we go into New York State, Secretary
Clinton's home state, that we will have a debate -- New York City, upstate,
whatever -- on the important issue facing New York and in fact the country,"
Sanders said. Both contenders have roots in the Empire State: Sanders was born
in Brooklyn, and Clinton was twice elected to the U.S. Senate from New
York.The most recent statewide poll, taken by the Emerson College Polling
Society March 14-16, Clinton held a daunting lead, 71%-23%. The automated
surveyÂ of 373 likely Democratic primary voters, taken only of landline phones,
has a margin of error of +/- 5 percentage points.In Wisconsin, an Emerson poll
taken March 20-22 showed Clinton with a narrower lead, 50%-44%.Â The survey of
354 likely Democratic primary voters has an error margin of +/-5.2 points.
Clinton has scheduled campaign stopsÂ Monday and Tuesday in Madison, Milwaukee,
LaCrosse and Green Bay.
title: Momentum v. math as Sanders claims victories while Clinton keeps delegate lead

A bomb blast in a park filled with Christian families celebrating Easter in
the Pakistani city of Lahore killed 65 people and wounded hundredsÂ more, a
government official said Sunday.A breakawayÂ Taliban faction told the
Associated PressÂ that it was responsible for the explosion.Â Ahsanullah Ahsan,
a spokesman for the militant group, Jamaat-ul-Ahrar, said it deliberately
targeted Christians and warned of more attacks to follow.Salman Rafiq, a
health adviser to the chief minister of Punjab province, said many of those
injured wereÂ in critical condition and warned that the death toll could climb.
Zaeem Qadri, a spokesman for the chief minister, said at least 300 were
injured in addition to those killed.The explosion took place near the
childrenâ€™s rides in Gulshan-e-Iqbal park, local police chief Haider Ashraf
said. He said the explosion appeared to have been a suicide bombing, but the
investigation isÂ ongoing."Most of the dead and injured are women and
children," Mustansar Feroz, the police superintendent of the area, told
Reuters.Pakistani relatives carry an injured bomb blast victim.Â (Photo: Arif
Ali, AFP/Getty Images)Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif expressed grief
and shock over the bombing, and Punjab Chief Minister Shahbaz Sharif declared
three days of mourning starting Monday, according to_The International News_,
a Karachi-based newspaper. The prime minister on SundayÂ held a meeting to
assess the security situation in Lahore, the government said.Pakistan's army
chief, Gen. Raheel Sharif, also convened an emergency meeting of the country's
intelligence agencies to begin to track down those responsible for the
attacks, said army spokesman Gen. Asim Saleem Bajwa.In a statement, the
Vatican said the attack "casts a shadow of sadness and anguish on the feast of
the Easter. Once again cowardly, murderous hatred rages on the most
defenseless."In Washington, the White House condemnedÂ the bombing."This
cowardly act in what has long been a scenic and placid park has killed dozens
of innocent civilians and left scores injured," National Security Council
spokesman Ned Price said. "We send our deepest condolences to the loves ones
of those killed, just as our thoughts and prayers are with the many injured in
the explosion. The United States stands with the people of Pakistan at this
difficult hour."Ashraf said the park was manned by police and private security
guards. â€œWe are in a war-like situationÂ and there is always a general threat,
but no specific threat alert was received for this place,â€ he said.Footage
broadcast on local television stations showed chaotic scenes in the park, with
people running while carrying children and cradling the wounded in their
laps."When the blast occurred, the flames were so high they reached above the
trees and I saw bodies flying in the air," Hasan Imran, 30, told
Reuters.Nasreen Bibi waited at a nearby hospital for an update on the
condition of her injured 2-year-old daughter."May God shower his wrath upon
these attackers," she told Reuters. "What kind of people target little
children in a park?"After the attack, the Punjab government ordered all public
parks, many of the city's main roads and several shopping areas closed.Schools
and businesses in the city will remain closed on Monday, the city's schools
association and the Union of Lahore Traders said.Sunday's bombing struck in
the Punjab provinceÂ where the prime minister was bornÂ and now serves as
Sharif's political base. The region has long been more peacefulÂ than other
parts of Pakistan, which featuresÂ constant skirmishes along its borders with
Afghanistan and India. Critics have accused Nawaz of tolerating attacks in
other parts of the country in exchange for keeping his province safe, a charge
he strongly denies.In recent years, Punjab has increasingly become a target.In
February 2015, five people were killed when a suicide bomber aligned with a
Taliban splinter groupsÂ attacked a police complex in Lahore. The next month,
attackers targeted two Christian churches in Lahore, killing more than a
dozen,Â wounding 70 others and instigating protests from religious minorities
who felt they were not being protected by the nation's government. And in
August, a provincial minister and 16 others were killed when suicide bombers
destroyed the Â minister's home, where he was holding meetings._Contributing:
Greg Toppo, USA TODAY_
title: Bomb blast in Pakistan park kills 65

Belgian security forces conducted 13 raids in three cities Sunday, taking four
people into custody and continuing a crackdown on suspected terrorists in the
wake of Tuesday's deadly attacks.Federal prosecutor Frederic Van Leeuw's
officeÂ said nine people initially were detained in Brussels, Duffel and
Mechelen. Five were later released, state-owned broadcaster RTBF reported.Van
Leeuw said the arrests were madeÂ "in connection with terrorism" but did not
link them directly with the attacks at Brussels Airport and a metro station
that killed 31 people and wounded hundreds more. In addition,Â Italian police
said they hadÂ arrested an Algerian man accused of providing fake documents to
suspects in the attacks in Paris and Brussels.Also Sunday, police in Brussels
fired water cannons to disperse protesters at a "Rally Against Fear" heldÂ in
support of victims of terror. Authorities had canceled the rally, citing a
police force already strained by investigations in the wake of the attacks.
Several hundred rallied anyway, RTBF reported, including hundreds of right-
wing protesters dressed in black, some covering their faces with
balaclavas."They define themselves as (sports) hooligans, but their outfits
evoke their nationalist trend," RTBF reported.Brussels police Commissioner
Christian De Coninck said several of the men, supporters of three Belgian
soccer teams, were arrested in a clash with police hustling them to a train
station. Two police officers were injured, he said.Brussels Mayor Yvan Mayeur
expressed outrage that "this kind of scum" had addedÂ to the nation's pain
instead of aiding healing.Â Prime Minister Charles Michel chastised the group
for theirÂ "highly inappropriate" behavior at a solemn event.Belgium was
struggling to return to normalcy.Â Brussels Airlines juggled flights out of
alternative Belgium airports following the blast at its hub, Brussels Airport,
which won't reopen until at least Tuesday. The airport said police have
wrapped up their investigation at the site, and authorities are working on
plans to open temporary ticketing desks.On Saturday, officials charged three
men with terrorist offenses, including a man identified by Belgian media as
the "man in the hat" shown on surveillance video atÂ Brussels AirportÂ minutes
before Tuesday's attacks.While prosecutors have not officiallyÂ identified a
suspect as the man in the video, they confirmed they have charged a man
identified as "Faycal C." forÂ â€œinvolvement in a terrorist group, terrorist
murder and attempted terrorist murder.â€Â Belgian state TVÂ and the newspaperÂ _Le
Soir,Â _using a different spelling, identified the suspectÂ as_Â _Faisal Cheffou,
a Belgian freelance filmmaker and journalist.Prosecutors are awaiting DNA
evidence before making an official statement on whether they believe they have
the third terrorist in custody,Â RTBF reported.Â Prosecutors did say that they
have searched the latest suspect'sÂ home and turned upÂ no weapons or
explosives.On the surveillance video, the thirdÂ terrorist, wearing a hat and
light-colored clothing on the right, is shown walking beside the two other
terrorists. AuthoritiesÂ said theÂ man was pushing a cart with luggage
containing a 35-pound bomb that did not detonate.The other two men in the
airport surveillance video have been identified asÂ Ibrahim El Bakraoui, 29,
and Najim Laachraoui, a bombmaker linked by DNA to the Paris terror attacks in
November that killed 130 people.Â Also identified in the Brussels attacks is
Khalid El Bakraoui, 27, Ibrahim's brother, who blew himself up in a subway car
at aÂ metro station._Contributing: Doug Stanglin_

Many retirees rely on Social Security for most or all of their income in
retirement. Before you make a decision that will have major financial
implications for the rest of your life, it's important to know everything at
stake in the timing of when you take your benefits. Here are a few things to
consider.**Fewer big payments vs. more small payments**  
Most people have what amounts to an eight-year window to claim Social
Security. Earliest eligibility is at age 62, and 70 is the latest age at which
Social Security provides any financial incentive to wait. The key decision
with Social Security is whether to take a reduced benefit that will give you
the maximumÂ _numberÂ _of monthly Social Security payments, or whether to wait
and take a higher monthly benefit but receive it for a shorter period of
time.You can find plenty of articles discussing the trade-offs involved with
claiming at age 62Â versus waiting untilÂ full retirement ageÂ (currently 66) or
age 70 to claim. But a lot depends on your individual situation. For instance,
single retirees who won't have anyone else claiming on their work history can
look solely at their own personal situation to make a smart decision about
when to take Social Security. For those with family members who will receive
spousal or survivor benefits, decisions that might make sense solely from your
point of view might not be the best for your family as a whole. You can run
numbers projecting which choice will result in your receiving more total
money. But only you can make a personal assessment whether the true value of
that extra money is worth the trade-off of having to wait for it. The
important thing is not just to make a knee-jerk decision but rather to
consider all the factors involved and what they mean to you and your life.**If
you're working and claim early, Social Security could take back your benefits
anyway**  
The worst result in many people's eyes is to start collecting Social Security
benefits only to have the government take them away. Yet that's what happens
to some people who continue to work in their early 60s and choose to take
early benefits.If you haven't yet reached full retirement age, there's a limit
on how much you can earn before Social Security forces you to forfeit
benefits. If you will not reach full retirement age this year and earn more
than $15,720, then you'll lose $1 in annual Social Security payments for every
$2 above the limit you earn. For those who hit full retirement age during the
year, a higher limit of $41,880 applies to earnings before the day of the year
you reach full retirement age, and the forfeiture is $1 for every $3 above the
limit.This forfeiture doesn't result in a complete loss, because the Social
Security Administration treats you as if you had delayed taking Social
Security for any full month of forfeited benefits. But if that's what's going
to happen anyway, it can make more sense just to delay filing until your
income will be under the threshold â€” or until you reach full retirement age.If
you change your mind, you can get a do-over.Â (Photo: Getty Images)**You can
get a do-over on your decision, but only for a limited time**  
Many people regret their decision on when to take Social Security after the
fact. ThereÂ _isÂ _a way to undo your claiming decision, but you have only a
limited time to do so, and there are some key requirements that pose a
hardship for many.In order to get a do-over, you have to use a strategy that's
known as withdrawing your Social Security applications. Form SSA-521 provides
for this request, and it provides space for you to indicate the reason for the
withdrawal and other related information. You can only file Form SSA-521 once
in your lifetime, and it's only available within the first 12 months after
your initial application for Social Security benefits.The hardest part of the
withdrawal application is that if approved, you have to return any money you
received from Social Security since you claimed benefits. Many retirees aren't
in a position to pay back up to a year's worth of Social Security payments,
and that can make the strategy impractical for them.The decision of when to
take Social Security is a key one. Being informed is the first step toward
making sure you do the best thing for your situation.**SPONSOR CONTENT: The
$15,978 Social Security bonus most retirees completely overlook**  
If you're like most Americans, you're a few years (or more) behind on your
retirement savings. But a handful of little-known Social Security secrets
could help ensure a boost in your retirement income. In fact, one MarketWatch
reporter argues that if more Americans knew about this, the government would
have to shell out an extra $10 billion annually. For example: one easy,
17-minute trick could pay you as much as $15,978 more... each year! Once you
learn how to take advantage of all these loopholes, we think you could retire
confidently with the peace of mind we're all after.Â **Simply click here to
discover how you can take advantage of these strategies.**_Try any of our
Foolish newsletter servicesÂ free for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the
same opinions, but we all believe thatÂ considering a diverse range of insights
makes us better investors. The Motley Fool has aÂ disclosure policy.__The
Motley Fool is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news, analysis
and commentary designed to help people take control of their financial lives.
Its content is produced independently of USA TODAY._

Saturday marked the first time Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders swept a full round
of caucuses, defeating front-runner Hillary Clinton inÂ all three of the day's
presidential contests.But when the mainstream media was nearly silent on his
victory, voters took the electoral process into their own hands.Overnight, a
Google document built by a handful of strangers became theÂ go-to source for
the caucus results. Its creators were the first to project Sanders' victory,
as the mainstream media waited on stalling, overwhelmed caucus organizers.As
organizers in Hawaii scrambled to gather results,Â Alec Salisbury compiled his
own set of stats from his computer in his Ithaca College dorm. With a group of
three to 10 strangers, the 20-year-old college student broke the story of
Sanders' landslide victory."It's been a very hectic 15 hours since the caucus
results started coming in from WA, HI, and AK," Salisbury said in a statement
after news outlets made their final projections. "I was ecstatic to see how
incredibly close our projections came to the official results. It was amazing
interacting and collaborating with like-minded voters from all across the
country."The Associated Press gave the first official projection by 10 p.m.
HST/4 a.m.Â â€” at least three hours later than plannedÂ â€” and declared what
people following the spreadsheets already knew.Â The AP's data showed Sanders
crushing Clinton, 70.6% to 29.3%.The Google document? It showed Sanders at
69.7% and Clinton at 30.3%.Seeing loads of great unofficial results coming in
from Hawai'i. Thank you, #HIcaucus! pic.twitter.com/EvvH5aHHDz**Large turnout,
delays**The Democratic Party of Hawaii said it wouldÂ release the results by 8
p.m. HT/1 a.m. ET. Then by 9 p.m. Then 9:30 p.m., theÂ _Honolulu Star
Advertiser_Â reported. The delays in reporting came as the party experienced a
surge in voter turnout comparable to the 2008 caucus when then-senatorÂ Obama
was running against Hilary Clinton for president.Party chairwomanÂ Stephanie
Ohigashi told the Associated Press the polling station where she voted on Maui
was organized. Thousands of new members joined the party before the caucus,
and some polling stations had massive crowds, which may have contributed to
the delay.Some of the new party members were residents who had lived through
internment camps or immigrated to Hawaii, Ohigashi said. They joined to
bolster the party's chances of stopping Donald Trump from becoming
president.But another factor in the delay was the party leadership's decision
not to release partial results.The holdup drew ire from voters across the
country, including many Sanders supporters who called it a "media
blackout."March 26, 2016 will be forever known as the day when a Google doc
broke news of the #HIcaucus winner before mainstream media. #mediablackoutI
think I'd get results quicker by actually flying to Hawaii... âœˆï¸  
#HIcaucusIf only we had 24hr cable news networks or digital media outlets
somebody could be covering the Hawaii caucuses. #HIcaucusSalisbury, who
supports Sanders for president, echoed some of their sentiments. Before the
AP's projection, Salisbury said in a phone interview that he believesÂ the
media has treated Sanders unfairly, especially compared to its coverage of
Clinton and Republican front-runner Trump.But, he added, his concern Saturday
night was getting the caucus results to the peopleÂ â€” and getting it right."No
one has really commentedÂ on the accuracy because no one really knows how
accurate it is," he said early Sunday morning from New York. "Many are
grateful online. They're happy to have some idea of what might
happen."Gathering the results wasn't too difficult, he said. He and his
cohorts scrolled through tweets with caucus-related hashtags. If he saw a
number, he looked for other sources reporting the same results.**More
primaries, more crowdsourcing**The next contests could favor the former
secretary of State. Wisconsin, which has 96 delegates at stake, holds its
primary April 5. New York, whereÂ Clinton served as a senator,Â has 291
delegates at stake in its primaryÂ April 19.In Hawaii, Democrats packed
schools, waiting through long lines and sifting through confusing ballot
directions. It's a familiar problem for Democratic organizers. Precincts in
Arizona, Utah and Michigan, among other states, faced similar problems when
voting day arrived.If Saturday's caucuses are any indication, voters and
spectators may be seeing more Google documents going viral on social media."I
would like to thank everyone who helped us out, and especially those who
directly contributed to updating the document," he said. "Our group will most
likely do this again for the next caucus."
title: Amid Hawaii delays, the Internet turned to a Google doc for caucus results

Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders won the Hawaii Democratic caucus, claiming every
state up for grabs in Saturday's presidential contests, the Associated Press
projected after hours of delays from the state party.Sanders trounced front-
runner Hillary Clinton in the caucus, holding a double-digit lead, according
toÂ USA TODAY's election data page. With 88% of precincts reporting as of 5
a.m. EST, Sanders has 70.6% to Clinton's 29.2%."Nobody should have any doubt
that this campaign has extraordinary momentum and that we have a path toward
victory," Sanders said in a statement after the AP's projection. "In state
after state, our grassroots effort has taken on the entire political
establishment. We have taken on the senators and the governors and the mayors
and the members of Congress. Our political revolution is the best chance we
have to keep Donald Trump or any other Republican out of the White
House.â€Sanders swept to victory inÂ theÂ Democratic caucuses in Alaska and
Washington stateÂ Saturday, asÂ he soughtÂ to cutÂ intoÂ Clinton's commanding
delegate lead and gain fresh momentum in his bid for their party's
presidential nomination.Voters across the country held their breath for hours
as they waited for the official results in Hawaii, where 25 delegates were at
stake Saturday. The delays in results come as the party experienced a surge in
voter turnout comparable to the 2008 caucus when then- Sen. Barack Obama was
running againstÂ Clinton for president,Â theÂ HonoluluÂ Star Advertiser
reported.The delaysÂ made some voters restless, including some Sanders
supporters who claimed the delays were part of a "media blackout."#HIcaucus \-
It's 3:30 in Tampa Bay, Florida! I just want to go to sleep smiling at the 3
massive victories for @BernieSanders & us!I think I'd get results quicker
by actually flying to Hawaii... âœˆï¸  
#HIcaucusWashington state, with 101 delegates up for grabs, wasÂ Saturdayâ€™s
biggest prize. Sanders fought hard for the state, holding big rallies in the
last weekÂ to drive turnout among the kinds of young and liberal votersÂ who
have helped him prevail in earlier caucuses.Sixteen delegates were at stake in
Alaska."We are making significant inroads in Secretary Clinton's lead, and we
have a path toward victory," Sanders told a cheeringÂ crowd in Madison, Wis.,
on Saturday, following his Alaska win.Â "It is hard for anyone to deny that our
campaign has the momentum."Sanders'Â drive to win Saturday's trio of Western
states comes as the race heads back to the Midwest and Northeast next month,
territory that couldÂ prove favorable toÂ Clinton, who has outperformed Sanders
in more racially diverseÂ states.Â Next up: Wisconsin, which votes April 5.
Clinton's home state of New York, where a whopping 291 delegates are up for
grabs, will vote April 19.It was no coincidence that Sanders celebrated his
Western victoriesÂ in a Wisconsin college town Saturday night.Democratic
presidential candidates Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton.Â (Photo:
AP)Sanders, who outraised Clinton in January and February, isÂ expected to
parlay his weekend wins into a fresh roundÂ of online donations.Despite his
victoriesÂ Saturday, the delegate math still favors Clinton.She headed into
Saturday's contests with a bigÂ lead among pledged delegates.Â When party
officials, known as superdelegates, are added in, Clintonâ€™s advantage grows
even larger.The states making their choicesÂ Saturday were friendly ground for
Sanders, who relied onÂ caucus victoriesÂ in sevenÂ of the 11 states he had won
heading into this weekend. In addition, some ofÂ hisÂ strongest performances in
the nomination battle have come from states in which white voters make up a
large share of the electorate, indicating anÂ edgeÂ in Alaska and Washington.In
more diverse Hawaii, Clinton has the support to several top officials,
including Sens. Brian Schatz and Mazie Hirono. Sanders, however, has the
backing of a popular figure in the state, Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, a rising
Democratic star who resigned her post as vice chairwoman of the Democratic
National Committee last month to openly campaign for Sanders in the Aloha
State. Gabbard, a combat veteran, cut an emotional commercialÂ for Sanders,
highlighting the toll of overseas combatÂ and Sanders' opposition to the Iraq
war.Washington hadÂ been the mostÂ hotly contested of the three states staging
contests Saturday.Clinton dispatched her husband, former President Bill
Clinton, and daughter, Chelsea, there on her behalf. Sanders himself
crisscrossed the state.Even with Sanders' big wins Saturday, Clinton also
added delegates to her column because the party awards them
proportionally.Clinton and her allies already are looking past the nomination
fight to the general election and a potential match-up against GOP front-
runner Donald Trump, who is engaged an increasingly ugly fight with Texas Sen.
Ted Cruz for their partyâ€™s nomination. On Friday, the two bickered over Cruzâ€™s
accusation that Trump planted a tabloid story about Cruz allegedly having
extramarital affairs, a charge Trump denied. Cruz calledÂ the _National
Enquirer_ story â€œgarbageâ€ and â€œcompletely false.â€A pro-Clinton super PAC
recently announced it was reserving $70 million in television advertising to
start after the national convention in Philadelphia.Sandersâ€™ fundraising
prowess, however, could give him staying power deep into the primary election
calendar. He has collected nearly $140 million over the course of the election
cycle.Clinton's camp, anticipating a strong Sandersâ€™ performance Saturday,
issued a fundraising appeal before his wins had been announced. â€œWeâ€™re still
being outspent on the air in key states, we havenâ€™t caught up in online
fundraising,â€ campaign manager Robby Mook told supporters in the email.One
clear sign that SandersÂ intends to stick around: On Saturday, heÂ opened a
campaign office in Brooklyn â€”Â the same New York borough as Clintonâ€™s national
headquarters â€” in preparationÂ for the state'sÂ primary.
title: Three for three: Sanders wins Hawaii, Washington, Alaska

DUBLINÂ â€” Ireland on Sunday staged its largest ever military parade as it
markedÂ the 100th anniversaryÂ of the Easter Rising, a botched but historically
significant rebellion against British rule.Hundreds of thousands of people
linedÂ Dublin's streets to watch 3,600 members of Ireland's military and
emergency servicesÂ take part in a five-hour, three-mileÂ procession that wound
its way past some of the buildings seized during theÂ revolt that left parts of
this cityÂ in ruins.Irish President Michael Higgins laid a wreath in front of
the General Post Office. The building's bullet-riddled columns still reflect
that it was usedÂ for six days, starting on Easter Monday in 1916, as the
headquarters of a revolt that aimed, but failed, to overthrow 700 years of
British reign.AÂ minute of silence for those killed was observed,Â the Irish
flag was lowered to half-staff,Â andÂ there was aÂ flypast by the Irish air
force.More than 450 people were killed and 2,500 injured during the failed
uprising. The rebellion and the execution ofÂ 16Â of its leaders led to a series
of events that did giveÂ Ireland its independence in 1922.Outside the post
office Sunday,Â Capt. Peter Kelleher, an Irish military officer, recited the
rebels' 1916 proclamation of independence.Â Former IrishÂ presidents Mary
McAleese and Mary Robinson, as well asÂ former prime ministerÂ Bertie Ahern were
also present.#EasterRising parade. pic.twitter.com/hdUL8unKhHBen Phillips, the
great-grand nephew of one of the executed rebels, told USA TODAYÂ he continues
to be amazed by the valor and sacrifices made by the rebels 100 years later.
"They knew they were going to die when they started this," he said. "They were
taking on an empire that had never really, with the exception of in theÂ United
States, been beaten."Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny joinedÂ Higgins in leading
the commemorationÂ ceremony, saying it was "important that we bear witness this
centenary year to all those who gave their lives during Easter 1916."Ireland
has longÂ struggled to embrace Easter Rising as its national day of
independence, in part because the country's two dominant political parties,
Fine Gael and Fianna Fail, both claim to be the inheritors of the rebels'
nationalist ideals.ComplicatingÂ this year's event, after an inconclusive Feb.
28Â election,Â Fine Gael andÂ Fianna Fail are currently locked in a dispute over
whether to form a coalition government.Meanwhile, some ultra-nationalist
groups, such asÂ Republican Sinn FÃ©in or RSFÂ â€” not to be confused with Sinn
FÃ©in,Â theÂ Irish republican political party active in Ireland and Northern
IrelandÂ â€” sayÂ there is unfinished business to attend to north of the
border."The state is trying to dilute 1916, to turn it into some kind of
history-fest," Des Dalton, who runs RSF's offices in Dublin, told the _Irish
Times_Â on Saturday."We uphold the right, as of all peoples, to defend our
national territory from foreign aggression or invasion. Whether people like it
or not, as long as there is a British presence in Ireland, there will always
be an IRAÂ to oppose it," he said, a reference to theÂ six northern Irish
counties thatÂ votedÂ to stay with theÂ United Kingdom instead of joining
Ireland.Still, out on the streets of Dublin this weekend there was less
concern with the bigger political picture andÂ more worry about the hereÂ and
now.Colin Smith, aÂ New Yorker with Irish roots, was part of an American
marchingÂ bagpipe band performing near St. Stephen's Green, a public park in
Dublin. "I didn't know much about this (Easter Rising), but I looked into it
when I knew we were coming over," he said. "I'm having a great time."Ciaran
Mac Annraoi, an Internet technology worker from Dublin who for the past 12
weeks has been taking part in historical re-enactments of the Easter Rising,
had other concerns. He wore a replica of a militaryÂ uniform from 1916 and
carriedÂ a heavy rifle.Â "I can't wait for Monday, so I can take a break from
wearing this," he said.
title: Ireland commemorates Easter Rising centennial

DUBLINÂ â€” Ben Phillips looks and sounds more like a member of aÂ privileged
British social class than the great-grand nephew of the man who led Ireland's
Easter Rising in 1916, a daring, bloodyÂ and unsuccessful attempt by
nationalistsÂ to overturn British rule."When I was growing up in London, in an
English family, weÂ were really proud of Patrick Pearse's legacy," Phillips
said here Saturday, speakingÂ in a posh British accent that sets himÂ apart from
the average Irish brogue."The value of the Rising transcends nationality. It's
about equality for men and women, Catholic and Protestant, rich and poor," he
said.Phillips, 39,Â lives in Nairobi, Kenya, where he worksÂ for an aid
organization. Outwardly, he has the polish and comportmentÂ of a judge or a
BritishÂ financier. But he is also oneÂ of about 3,500 relativesÂ from around the
world whose family membersÂ either took part in the RisingÂ or were caught up in
its monumental act of defiance.Many areÂ in Dublin this weekendÂ to markÂ the
100th anniversaryÂ of the event, whichÂ acceleratedÂ Ireland to securing its
freedom in 1922.Â They have traveled from as far afield as Canada, England,
Germany, the United States andÂ Wales to giveÂ speeches, lay wreaths andÂ attend
aÂ parade, amongÂ other forms of remembrance.More than 450 people were killed
and 2,500 wounded, the majority of them civilians, when an untrained group of
volunteers determined to overthrow 700 years of British dominationÂ sought to
seize control of Dublin from the British army and proclaim a republic.The
group, whichÂ includedÂ actors, playwrights and poets armed with outdated German
rifles,Â held out for a week. Sixteen of the uprising's senior insurgents,
including Pearse, a teacher and political activist who would come to be seen
as the event's leader, were later executed.According to the diary kept by the
British army officer who commanded the firing squads, Pearse "whistled as he
came out of his cell."Phillips is Pearse's closest living relative. His great-
grandmother was the Irish rebel'sÂ first cousin on his mother's side. That
great-grandmother married anÂ Englishman and moved to England.Phillips is quick
to dismiss any awkwardness, real or imagined, that might arise from being an
English-sounding relation of an IrishÂ rebellion's most significant son. "When
Irish people hear my accent, no one is bothered by it," he said."It's a great
blessing to be able to do this (the commemoration).Â The Rising really is
Ireland's gift to the world. It showed that the British empire had an end
date. WhenÂ I talk to peopleÂ (in former British colonies) inÂ Africa now, for
example, they say they feel a connection to it," he said. "I hope I'm around
for the 150th."DublinerÂ CathalÂ Brugha, 67, also has deep familial connections
to the Rising. He isÂ the grandson of two well-known Irish nationalists. One of
them, his namesake, was second in command at an important position in south
Dublin held by the rebels that fended off several major assaults by the
British army.HeÂ was later foundÂ propped against a wall in a pool of his own
blood clutching a pistol andÂ taunting the BritishÂ troops."When the Rising
failedÂ the British didn't execute my grandfather because he was soÂ badly
wounded they thought he was going to die.Â He was very fit and very strong. He
stayed alive by singing to himself. HeÂ sangÂ 'God Save Ireland,'"Â Brugha said
Saturday at his home near University College Dublin, where he teaches in the
business department.That grandfatherÂ would later found the Irish Republican
Army and serve asÂ Ireland'sÂ first president. The other, Terence MacSwiney, was
a playwright andÂ politician in Cork who raisedÂ the profile of the Irish
struggle for self-determination after being imprisoned for sedition by the
BritishÂ in 1920. He died after 74 days on hunger strike."My grandfathers
realized itÂ wasn't enough to write and put on plays, you also had to have
action,"Â Brugha said.
title: Despite bloodshed, Easter Rising is Ireland's 'gift to the world'
